Tight, challenging, and well thought out. I'd be hard-pressed to think of a feature that wasn't essential to the experience. I'd recommend watching tutorials on YouTube to get acquainted with how the game works and basic strategies - the game does not do a good job at explaining these (but also, what 4x games really do that well?).

The AI has little sense of self-preservation but puts up a fight that'll keep you on your toes (due to cheating in the strategy layer and getting bonus resources, not necessarily playing well). It's quite satisfying to turn a tactical battle the AI autoresolved as a total loss into a flawless win. Sadly the AI doesn't have a sense of when you're nearing victory, so when it should be going all-out to try and stop you from activating a doomsday weapon or preventing you from takings its capitol, it'll still be sending disorganized armies to fight pointless skirmishes. It's a shame, but AI for 4x games is hard and it doesn't detract too much from the experience.

Oh, and don't shy away from the campaign. It's basically a combination of (1) tutorials for each race and (2) a set of custom quests on top of the otherwise standard generated maps you'll get in free play. It encourages you to try out features unique to each faction while still feeling much like a normal game. There's also nice backstories for lots of otherwise-unexplained things - not compelling, but they give character and background to what happens in free play.

89846387.review:
If you enjoyed the previous Age of Wonders games, you owe it to yourself to check out Planetfall. If you enjoyed Endless Legend, you should also check out Planetfall.

[b]The Good[/b]

* No more random spell unlocks like in AoW 3. The research tree is a better system.
* Mods add diversity to your armies and genuinely keep your weaker units relevant all the way into the late game.
* Splitting the map up into sectors makes for easier city placement and expansion. No longer do you have to debate whether to found a city next to some high-value resource that will [i]only[/i] have that resource in its domain.
* The NPC factions are interesting and the "courting independents" feature of the game is more developed and fun than it was in AoW 3.
* The AI is better than it was in AoW 3, especially on the strategic map. The AI will invade if it sees an opening, and it will bypass your fortified cities to go harass your weaker cities.
* Empire mode is a cool idea.
* You can save in the middle of tactical combat now. Thank you!!

[b]The Bad[/b]

* The campaign left so much to be desired, especially the DLC "campaigns" that are only two missions long. I was so disappointed that they didn't include handcrafted maps for the campaign but instead relied on the random map generator.

[b]The Other[/b]

* Be sure to prioritize energy! Coming from AoW 3, it took me a few games to get used to the fact that energy is both your gold and your "mana" in the sense that you spend energy on units and on operations.
* Although mods help greatly in keeping weaker units relevant throughout the game, they overcompensate in a way that leaves higher-tier units feeling underpowered. In AoW 3, Tier 3 and Tier 4 units were the undisputed kings of the battlefield with Tier 1-2 units being little more than fodder by the late game. In Planetfall, it takes a long time to get to your Tier 3-4 units because you'll be spending research on mods, and by the time you do get to your elite units, they don't feel like the game changers they used to be when going up against swarms of low-level units with endgame mods.

The good aspects of this game far outweigh the bad aspects. You should buy it on sale and enjoy!

Crunchy sci-fi turn based tactical battles inside a tasty 4X strategy shell - what's not to love?

I really like how the different factions in the game are created and presented.

Command the armored troopers, drones and vehicles of the Vanguard.
Or bio-engineered bow warrior Amazons and their animal friends, including a tyrannosaurs with laser eyes.
Or armies of 'indentured' (slaves in all but name) and the aristocratic overlords in the Syndicate.
Or the Assembly, a hive-mind of undead cyborgs.
Then there's the Dvar, exosuit-bound clans obsessed with survival, mining, and defense. 
Lastly the Kir'ko, who are like the Zerg, but they're good guy oppressed rebels rather than evil.

All of these factions have different art styles and abilities on the strategy map and in tactical battles. They don't just look different, but they play differently as well.

You can mix and match the above and are often encouraged to do so by game mechanics. In addition there are minor factions to befriend and recruit from (or fight),
including:
The Spacers: VR gamers that have turned into roving bands of mad max bandits after civilization collapsed.
Psi-Fish: Curious ethereal outsiders that don't understand our reality enough to refrain from eating people's brains.
Autonom: Robots gone rogue.
Paragon: Cyborg technology worshipers.
The Growth: Mobile plant and giant bee symbionts.

Due to all these choices, endgame battles between big armies end up looking and playing unique.

I'm not even going to get into all the units from the six secret techs, wildlife, or the additional factions added by the 3 DLC.

If you buy this I'm always willing to PBEM the strategy game with you (we should probably PvE if you're new at the game), and we can play the tactical battles in real time if you want. 
You can play a game with someone that has DLC that you don't have, so I can show you that stuff. 

Single player is also fun, especially the recently added empire mode.

However after a break from the game for a while I recently got back to trying it out after the latest DLC and the Galactic Campaign Mode were added. I just finished up a game playing as an Amazon Warrior (Princess) who won the game by releasing a doomsday device that infected the whole planet with an Alpha Strain Xenoplague infestation. Lets just say the world had a very green tint to it by the end of the game. 

Below is an overview of how that game went:

I tried to master the planet in quite a few different ways when I started, there was a timed quest to eliminate a single npc faction within 20 turns (I wasn't fast enough). So next I tried to focus on uniting all the 6 factions and going for a Unification victory, however there were 3 Dvar factions that decided they would all become friends and try and take out the rest of us. So it turned out to be a 3 vs 3 duel, however the Dvar factions had all gotten a technological head start on me due to me faffing around doing diplomacy things rather than researching bigger guns or more lethal biomass weapon mods.

Now normally there isn't really much hope of coming back from this situation in a lot of 4X games. However I looked through this list of possible win scenarios and spotted the Doomsday scenario. So I thought what the heck I'll try anything to get rid of these pesky scheming Dvar guys. It took a lot of guerrilla hit and run attacks then quickly hiding in forests but I kept them at bay long enough to start building up my research. Luckily my fellow allies were just about holding their own too so we kept control of the top half of the map just long enough to get the Alpha Strain option on the table. 

Alas once I'd set the doomsday chain of events in motion I then had to defend the Strain "Nodes" from being attacked for 10 turns. It was really nail biting watching the Dvar heading towards me in their tanks and flame throwing mechs. However I called on my allies to come and help defend and sure enough one of them sent over some troops which didn't quite swing the battle, but was enough to keep the Nodes safe long enough for the Alpha Strain to infect and dissolve those dastardly Dvar. I loved every minute of it. 

Of course this is just one example of what could happen and there are so many different ways to customise, that no two games will ever be the same. 

Also special mention to the character editor, wow... you can create just about any character you can imagine, and pick their skills and attributes. The customisation continues through the game when playing too so you really get a sense of advancing as the game plays out. Also the random world events (which came in the Invasions DLC) really help keep things spicy. Just remember there is about a 2-3 hour learning curve to fully get down with it,.

So if any of the above sounds like fun to you then go for it. It even has multiplayer if that's your thing.

Oh yeah one more thing it also has Tyrannosaurs in it..... Grrrrrrrrreat!

85798060.review:
There will be a TL;DR at the end.

Age Of Wonders: Planetfall is a… Unique experience. After playing just over 48 hours of this title, I’ve completed 2 conquest matches. And while I was reluctant to write a review about this game after only a couple of in-game bouts. I think that this alone speaks for itself. There are only 3 things that you should consider about this game – Paradox’s attempt to compete with Firaxis’s Civilization series, Triumph’s attempt to replicate Firaxis’s XCOM combat, and the overall pacing of the game’s mechanics.

Paradox stepped in to provide a new angle for this game over Age Of Wonders III – they seem to have brought a great amount of production value to the table and have applied a lot of lessons that they learned during their development of Stellaris. However, there are a couple of things that this game does differently from all previous titles. It’s a lot more streamlined and approachable than Civ or Stellaris – but it’s also a lot less balanced – and a lot less rewarding. On one hand, you don’t have to worry so much about micromanagement, but on the other, you have little to look forward to on the world map other than quitting the game to buy Paradox’s legendarily overpriced ‘essential’ DLCs. While not as half-baked as AOW3’s mechanics, it’s not nearly fleshed out enough to give towns their own unique identities through the gauntlets of direct upgrades that take huge chunks of the game to develop fully. While, thankfully, there aren’t strict penalties to spreading your empire out, or having big armies – making this a lot less restrictive, and there’s a lot more things to keep the game interesting, it’s an unfortunate truth that it adds little overall value to the game in general.

Triumph tried their hand at combat… again… and it seems to be a lot like last time. There are half a billion unique opponent types and troops to put into your armies. But balance is still something that the developers only heard of in passing, balance is an elusive prospect from early game to end game. Fighting enemies at end-game is a complete gamble… you can fight the same combat scenario dozen times and it will play out RADICALLY different during each one. Some units are more valuable than others – some abilities are better than others. And the AI is not much better than in AO3 either. In comparison to refined, well designed, tightly focused TBS games – it pales in comparison. And a lot of little oversights (Like moving one unit as the other one moves) cause this game to become a slog, with combat encounters that should be trivial taking several minutes to gruel through.

Which brings us to the final portion of the game: the pacing. While Civ V and VI can have some slow pacing at times – it’s because there’s a lot going on between each player and faction. And much like Civ, time can pass like no other while playing this game, but not because it’s specifically interesting, but because the mechanics make the long spaces between interesting actions as languid as they can be. After spending so much time on the game – I can absolutely say that it was not at all worth it.

TL;DR
5/10
Age Of Wonders: Planetfall is as Average as a game can get.
In spite of some very daring improvements over the previous title, the game itself is a rusted chain connecting anticlimax to anticlimax. All to labor in vain under the shadow of much more worthwhile predecessors, and the grueling truth of better future endeavors.

85782449.review:
Almost 200 hours in and I feel like I'm just scratching the surface. Each race gets its own mini campaign. These campaigns essentially are glorified tutorials, but they're nevertheless very entertaining. Each one teaches you a different facet of the game. I like the new streamlined sector system, which is a lot less fiddly compared to AoW3 (Age of Wonders 3). The tactical combat also got several tweaks; it's more cover based and units can miss their attacks. I do believe it's a bit deeper compared to AoW3, but just as engaging. The unit mod system is just icing on the cake. This system delivers some creative and seemingly OP combinations! :)

To top it up Planetfall boasts good graphics for a strategy game and the musical score of Michiel van den Bosch always is a pleasure to listen to. I recommend getting all the DLC pieces, as these seamlessly add more races, gameplay elements and variation. The last patch (2020) adds Galactic Empire gameplay mode, a sort of galactic stratego.  This mode brings some macro strategic elements to the table, as winning a planet (map) earns you bonuses to wield on the next planet. Newly created planets get progressively harder to conquer. I only played Galactic eRpire for a short while, but it seems very interesting. I'll certainly try this mode more in the future.

Planetfall is Triumph Studio's first foray into science fiction strategy, but I believe they achieved their goals with this release. It's a fun, balanced turn based strategy game, with a clear focus on tactical battles. At the core it's actually not that different from AoW3, but still different enough to not be confused as a reskin. In a sense Triuph Studio's newest release is an evolution, not a revolution. Will we see a Planetfall 2? I do hope so!

84807653.review:
TLDR;

Q: Is the game worth getting at full price? 
A: No, but if you can acquire the Premium Edition with all DLC at a dramatic discount, then do so.

Q: I enjoy 4X Games, is this tile a rich and dynamic 4X with lots of complex nuance?
A: No, but it provides a wide variety of ways to engage with the game in ways other 4X games lack, and I mean that in a very positive way.

Q: I enjoyed Age of Wonders III, how does it compare?
A: This feels similar but is different in a wide variety of ways. The game does feel like an Age of Wonders 4, which takes refines the experience and gives you reasons to keep coming back. Something AoW3 lacked.

Q: Do you enjoy the game and intend to play more of it?
A: Yes. At first the game feels like it is lacking features, and it can be surprisingly overwhelming with all of the stuff coming at you in the early turns. But as long as you pay attention, read, and experiment with features – you’ll begin to see the depth hidden beneath the surface. The more I played it, the more I took out of the game and enjoyed it. But it has flaws, like predictable AI and game flow not designed to go beyond 100 turns.

---

Some Notable Gripes

There is a lot of good in this game, and I’ll cover that soon enough. But let’s first point out some of the flaws so you’d know what you’d be getting in to. First of all the game doesn’t do a very good job explaining itself via the tutorial. Sure it has a tutorial, but it’s a ‘Baby’s First 4X’ game sort of stuff, literally covering the absolute basics of any 4X ever, as though it was the first of its kind.

All of the advanced nuance that is unique to this game is relegated to the portions you have to read, and that means there is a great deal of reading. By default, your city can only get a maximum of five sectors, meaning it can capture four more as the starting sector counts as one. You can only build one exploit structure per sector, so choose wisely.

But by building a Residential District as an exploit, you can gain one additional sector. You can build two Residential Districts max, expanding your total number of sectors of seven. This is a fundamental, basic, thing that all cities pretty much have to do to be extremely effective. Only 2.2% of total players who have ever owned and played the game have actually done this.

So yeah, the game has a lot of stuff, but YOU need to actually LEARN how to play it yourself. It’s not going to hold your hand and tell you want to do, which may be very frustrating for a lot of people. Understanding how to build properly, divert food resources, and manipulate the AI via a small handful of specific resources are critical to success. And this where the fun resides, but all of that is not obvious and you need to really fiddle with the game a while before things start to click.

 Another gripe is that the AI isn’t what you’d hope for in a 4X game. It thinks too hard, but achieves very little over all. Let me illustrate. I created a massive game with several AI, and I made one my ally. We shared vision, relay portals, intel, everything, etc. You can even give them orders to attack a specific target – but with caveats.

I had a huge, massive, 100+ sector empire and this AI had only a handful of cities. He was practically a vessel, but lord forbid asking the AI to be a vessel is impossible. You can ONLY convert an AI to a vessel when they are on death’s door, and you’re the one beating their face in with said door. There is no other way. Period. I’ve tried!

Anyway, you can give them orders to attack another AI. But doing so will not actually make the AI attack independently. The AI will only attack a target you call, IF you are also attacking that target too. You are always meant to be the the AI’s meat shield, not the other way around.

And the AI will never, ever ever put itself in a position where it is your meat shield. It will always retreat and make sure your armies do all the dirty work, then they mop up the stragglers and claim the cities you worked your ass off to claim. So AIs have limits. It will always have massive armies at your border, even if you’re its ally. Because someone apparently programed the AI to always be prepared for the eventuality to defend against YOU.

So you cannot send the AI to fight another AI, and then you sweep in behind and claim his stuff. No, the AI is ready for this as they have way way way more units than they actually need, just sitting there, on the map, never doing anything other than being ready to fend you off.

Games that exceed 100 turns get bogged down considerably because of this crap, and eventually AI turns take longer than you own, leaving you waiting and waiting for 10 to 15 minutes for the AI to get done computing, because it’s trying to defend itself from everyone, especially you, at all times, at every front, with way way way too many units.

This is why the score screen is always impossibly off. You can technically have more military might, progress, development, and everything better than the AI – but you’ll always be listed as last or next to last place. Because the AI doesn’t measure might in actual unit strength, it measures it in units produced. So the AI cranks out hundreds of crappy little units it doesn’t have to pay upkeep for, and stacks every city they own with a notable army of several groups.

And it doesn’t move these units as groups. It moves them all, one by one, unit by unit, on at a time… So for the love of god turn off walking animations or you’re going to be waiting for the AI for about 30 minutes in games that exceed 100 turns.

The Good Stuff

Games can be small quick, pop in and pop out. Empire Mode makes this rewarding as you can eventually put together your own strange collection of units from every faction, including the NPC ones. And the NPC factions are extremely important too, but they only compliment certain races. You need to learn with NPC factions compliment you best, work with them, and then just kill off the others so your opponents cannot profit from them.

Empire Mode is really where the game does shine and it’s worth it for that alone, but it’s a very long grind before you start squeezing some fun out of it too. So keep your games short, quick and dirty, and you’ll have a better time. I’ve tried long games, and eventually the AI became some damn cumbersome that it was clear they were more trouble than they were worth!

If you have a lot of AI, just make it a point to play nice-nice with um until you finally kill them all mercilessly one by one, as fast as you can as to not bog down the system last game. The more AI that are dead, the faster game goes! Don’t ever put down tons of AI or you’ll regret it. So if you want fast, fluid, but not as straight forward as it seems, sort of 4X game that has lasting rewards which can roll over into other games via the single player Empire Mode – then yeah, pick this game up.

But only buy this game at a DEEP DEEP discount. I paid less than $20 for the full package, all DLC, Premium edition, and I feel that was the perfect price. If I paid any more than that, I’d be pretty upset and feel a bit cheated.

[b]Overall:[/b]
It's a quite good strategy game. If you like the 4X style it's likely you will be happy. This game is an unpolished jewel and can easily give many hours of fun. With some further development for the next iteration, perhaps focusing on immersion, it could become great.

[b]The Gameplay:[/b]
- The AI is surprisingly good. 
- Diplomacy is good and engaging, there are enough options and the AI is surprisingly adequate.
- A smooth experience, short loading times, fairly few bugs.
- Plenty of possibilities for discovering synergies between units and upgrades. Some combinations are slightly overpowered.
- Lots of important and engaging strategic decisions to make.
- Base building is underwhelming, probably to make it easier on the AI.
- Development and tech offers plenty of options and decision making.
- Options for different play styles, diplomacy, war etc.
- The game lacks story/lore to make you invested and feel what this universe is like, why you are fighting and such. I would have liked bigger differences between races than there are. For example the Syndicate are traders but seemingly play the same way as other races.
- The campaigns story is somewhat cringeworthy due to the dialogue. I couldn't make it past a few turns.
- Lots of replayability, due to a variety of units and tech.
- For some strange reason, the database with information about the game is not structured alphabetically, making reading about the game annoying.

[b]The Visuals:[/b]
- Rough and underwhelming animations. Overall ok but often breaks immersion.
- Units that looks strong are weak and vice versa. Can be a bit unsatisfying.
- Some menus are strangely sloppy. For example, when recruiting units in a city, there's a clogged up menu with all units and all unit variations in the same place. It would be much better if unit variations are subcategories of units.
- The combat is tile based, all units use 1 tile which becomes weird when some units clearly are meant to be big but instead are small.

[b]The Sound:[/b]
- Sound FX is poor and unsatisfying. The sound is often out of sync with animations. A big tank firing really does sound like "pew-pew".
- The music does what it should, nothing special but it works.
- There is an announcer during the combat that is quite weird and breaks the immersion, saying things such as "unit lost".

Now, let's move onto what's bad... And that's mechanics, units and overall combat gameplay.

82036132.review:
[u] Overall [/u]
A solid 4x strategy game.  Think Civilization combined with the turn-based combat from X-Com.  This game is a must-buy for any fan of the previous Age of Wonders games.  It's also a good choice for anyone looking for a sci-fi themed strategy game that focuses heavily on the combat aspect of 4x games.

[u] Campaign [/u]
Decent.  Not as good a story as the campaign in Age of Wonders 3, but it still serves as a good introduction to the different races and secret technologies.

[u] Graphics [/u]
Looks very nice on high graphics settings.  Haven't had any compatability issues, and it is not very taxing compared to a lot of other modern games.  Good combat animations.

[u] Sound [/u]
Background music is decent; it does a good job at setting the mood, but I can't say any of the tracks stuck in my head afterwards.  Combat sound design is excellent and really adds weight to the animations: everything from gunfire to explosions to claw swipes.  The voice acting is decent as well, though certain lines are perhaps overused for in-game events.

[u] AI [/u]
The AI is pretty standard for 4x games.  Not amazing, but not horrible.  Still exploitable even on the hardest difficulty, like almost all AIs.

[u] Empire Building [/u]
Empire building is fairly basic in this game, like most Age of Wonders games.  It serves its purpose, and there are usually enough interesting choices to be made, but it's not the depth found in something like Civilization 4.  Diplomacy is fairly standard for modern 4x games as well.

[u] Multiplayer [/u]
There is a small but dedicated multiplayer community for this game.  It's not why I, personally, play the game, so I can't say much more than that.

[u] Developer Support [/u]
Triumph Studios is extremely good at making relevant and good updates to this game.  Even the free patches have a TON of small improvements, needed balance adjustments, and meaningful gameplay changes.  The expansions are reasonably costed for the amount of content included.  The devs are very good at listening to feedback from the players too.

81623122.review:
Recommended, with DLC and on sale. 

It's a 4x that plays a bit like Endless Legend and has clearly taken heavy inspiration from XCOM. This sounds like a match made in heaven, except that makes this title more like a jack of all trades, master of none. Note: This is my first AOW game.

The tactical battles have no significant impact beyond losing a few units on the map if you screw up (and you can retry as much as you want anyway). Often 'auto combat' has good enough results, meaning the stakes for going into manual combat are just not very enticing. The XCOM-factor is severely reduced in that matter.

The strategic side feels better. The world map has a fine amount of terrain/landmark/bonus resources for base planning, especially with Residential Sectors. You can't choose where to place your cities except the sector center, but that's okay I guess. There are plenty of covert and non-covert operations to take, as well as varied win conditions. But, domination is probably the VC you'll be getting the most often.

Research is the biggest letdown in my opinion. Society Research is too 'robotic'. Researching 'Production Development II' over 'Energy Development II' feels like very yucky filler content and leaves very little to flavor or imagination. However, if you'd remove/reorganize them so you wouldn't have to research over 10 different 'Development' researches, there's barely any tech tree left.
On the other extreme, Military Research has a separate multi-row tech tree for every single race, supported by two weapons trees and one secret tech tree. As you can found colonies of other races in the game, these tech trees are then added to your possible research, and of course this means your research tree gets so big you need a drop-down button to switch between the different parts.

The base content can feel underwhelming, despite the potential loads of customization that you can do (select a race, a secret technology, and traits). The DLC are however all excellent, and bring interesting things to the table.

80680090.review:
Let me start by saying i have a passion for turn based strategy games. Take a look at my play times for Civ6, Gladius, Endless Legend and X-Com and you'll see i'm no casual.

I had such high hopes for Planetfall. At first glance it seemed to check all the boxes. But as i kept playing i started to see the holes that the developers left and seem to refuse to fix. If you're not too fussy with the little things, then you'll probably enjoy the game. But as someone who worked as a game developer, I can't abide.

[u]The good[/u]
1. Probably the thing this game does better than any other strategy is the relationship between the tactical and world maps. You can group units into squads and teams into larger armies that fight together depending on how they're placed on the world map. The terrain is wildly different depending whether you're fighting in a city, the countryside, or special world tiles. And when you get a full 7 squad battle, it's really satisfying to see it played out in the tactical map.
2. Unit customization is amazing. With all the different upgrades for the units you can really fine tune how your army fights. Up against a lot of machines? Load up on electrical weapons. The enemy is hold up behind a defensive wall with turrets? Put some jetpacks and grenades on your dudes and Starship Trooper that jazz.
3. The landmasses and terrain are more organic and natural. The game is hex based but the world is split up into regions that vary in size and utility. It makes defending your territory feel more strategic.
4. The Galactic Empire is a great feature that is unique to Planetfall as far as i know. Each planet you play has unique features that allow you to unlock relics and units with other factions for future games. It makes each game feel important feels like you're working toward something.

[u]The bad[/u]
1. The races are symmetrical. Every race has the same version of each unit; scout, light infantry, skirmisher, support, flying, heavy, and ultimate form. They all do almost the same thing and cost the same across all races. Feels extremely lazy and adds a repetitive nature. Gladius does an excellent job of having unique races while still being balanced if you want to see an example.
2. Too. Many. Different. Status effects. Seriously, this is something they need to fix. If you're going to have so many status effects, then there needs to be a better way of finding out which ones are on your units. Currently, you have to exit the tactical screen and go to the unit's personal info screen. The status effects are thrown into a bucket of information which can sometimes be difficult to parse. On top of that, there are redundant status effects. For fire alone there is burning, immolated, and charred which honestly could just be the same status effect with increasing levels of damage and effects.
3. The DLC is bland and repetitive. When every race is symmetrical, then every new race you add is too similar to what's already there. Instead of adding a bunch of new interchangeable races, they should have worked on filling out the current ones so they feel more unique. 
4. It's the bad kind of turn based. Can you imagine playing a game of chess where each player gets to move all their pieces each turn? Final Fantasy Tactics showed us over 20 years ago how to do turn based right, and this game more than any could benefit from speed based individual unit turns. Remember those 7 squad battles? well that's 42 total units on the screen, and some of those units can summon other units. It's not strategy when 20 enemy units can all go one after another, and all target the same unit.

[u]The ugly[/u]
1. Every game has bugs, but this one has some doozies. The worst one that i've encountered so far is the game being unable to get through the computer's turn. Sometimes the computer takes a while because it has a bunch of battles to get through, and then sometimes it just hangs there indefinitely. There's no way of knowing the game has crashed until you wait a stupid amount of time. The only fix is to reload the previous turn. And if you've just fought a 7 squad battle which can take forever, that's a lot of your life to just incinerate. There are other game breaking bugs, but honestly that one is enough for me to never touch this game again. 
2. The UX was designed by Satan's nutsack. It's inconsistent, not intuitive, not clear. Honestly for me this might be the worst thing about the game. Give me an ugly game with great controls any day over this beautiful yet maddening mess.

80482056.review:
This game's cheaty RNG puts Xcom to shame.

It has so many ways to screw the player tactically, most of which you can't even take out of the equation. The graze mechanic is "supposedly" included to make missing less frustrating, but all it does is turn your 3 90% shots into duds. Information about game mechanics is absolute trash, both the wiki and the in-game help seem vastly incomplete with some pages or descriptions missing completely. The competence mechanic is totally skewed against the player, it's not uncommon to be ranked first in diplomacy and development and still be last in total because the AI spams units.

Speaking of which, for a "tactical game", there sure is a lot of emphasis on unit spam. Most units take less than a couple of turns to build, making spam (the enemy of tactical gameplay) too common, especially for the AI. It's pretty normal to see them running around with a whole pile of unit stacks and, because the AI cheats to keep up with the player, makes this extremely tedious to deal with. To put this in perspective, I've never lost a war, despite being totally outnumbered. This isn't fun, this isn't challenging. It's friggen tedious and mentally taxing.

I really liked it when I first started playing, but the more I've played, the more glaring the flaws are. There's simply too much bull and not enough information at your hands with a considerable lack of tools to deal with all the game's faults. It has a lot of promise, but is fundamentally flawed. A few tweaks to basic game mechanics would go a long way towards improving the game:

1. Unit upkeep/ cost: Increase this and make it even harsher for stacks that lack a leader/hero. This makes it so making a huge army actually requires infrastructure. Units should also take longer to build, losing units IN A STRATEGY GAME should be more punishing rather than a minor inconvenience.

2. Better/cleaner information: Right now, the information available to the player is extremely bare bones. To put this into perspective, the wiki's page that lists AI diplo weights (traits) doesn't even describe them, it's literally just a list, no subsections dedicated to them. There's absolutely no information on AI dislikes at all and you have to actually dig for this information or post in the forums. That's just bad form and it feels lazy.

3. Retweak the RNG: As previously stated, there's too much that's dependant on randomness. The Oathbound does a good job of including abilities that allow you to mitigate the amount of RNG, but EVERY faction needs this. A good player formulates strategies that rely as little as possible on randomness, but this game has too much of it and not enough ways to deal with it.

TLDR: Good potential, bad execution. Some cleanup required.

79360594.review:
Short review this game takes a 4x game like CIV, guts a lot of the overly complex aspects, adds an XCOM style manual combat with cover mechanics, creates a great "end the game" scenario for each faction that bypasses typical 4x's overly drawn out and tedious endgame and creates a more managable win condition....though typical win conditions exist.

With that said, its missing a LOT of the depth and complexity people might typically like in a 4x, you wont have hard building queue decisions, you wont be managing complicated troop load out, or be juggling 20+ building queue items with troop production.

More detailed info for 4x fans:

This game slips under the radar because of the strange things they did with 4x (imo) which pushes the 4x genre forward in many good ways, but misses that deep complexity itch that other 4x games such as anything from Fraxis or Amplitude.

Expansion: No tile stats.  Your starting city is dropped for you at game start, you annex nearby areas which allow you to build one category of district upgrades.  Your city grows you annex a nearby region, there might be an event item to give city bonuses or not, there might be a bad anomoly you can remove for money.  Thats it.  Expanding is very basic and little thought needs to go into it.  The annexing of areas will get you into war with AI if the area is bordering their land.  Its the trigger that has resulted in 75% of all AI war decs on me.  FIghting over annexed areas on border regions.  Isnt that how it should be?

Research/Tech:  You pick one race, all races have the same core research tree with items relevant to their race.  You select one secret technology, which adds a second tree.  Each race has a secret tech that jives 100% with them, however all secret tech does is provided extra units and skills...and each secret tech has a win condition item.  I play assembly, with secret tech that adds units that use the damage my race uses, provided mech/cyborg anti unit skills, and creates a win condition ballisk network, i build 3 expensive towers one per city, then research down the singularity event, prime the skill, once launched i win in 10 turns unless stopped.  Every secret tech has one like it.  This gives you an out vs wiping the floor for 200 turns exterminating everyone.  Its brilliant once you do it a few times.

Last tech in both social and millitary is called future tech.  Its a brilliant end game research that is infinately repeatable, once completed grants an empire bonus.  Think +5 energy per citizen, or +2 arc damage, ect.  Very useful and makes endgame research useful which is new for 4x

Gear/Units:  Basic.  Every game ive played each hero ends the game with the same weapons they sarted with, i get 3 (4 for some heros) slots for gear, small effects are added, nothing fancy or special or fun.  Seriously lacking department for the game.  For a game that cuts out most complexities they leave this part open to confusing menus on items, its hard to tell with most items any change in play.

Combat: XCOM with cover function.  Its a great addition i love it, but i still auto battle 95% of my battles and that sucks.  Their efforts to make combat engaging in a 4x failed as i still skip most battles.  the new mechanics are fun but serve to draw out even longer the typically long drawn out boring manual battles of all 4x.  

DLC/Money grubbing: Standard issue, though DLC seems to bring a lot of content along with the questionable new faction.  Like with most 4x, never not buy it on sale.

Star King DLC brings something new to the table. Galaxy Mode,  Account stats.  Create your hero, then "conquer worlds" it tracks the conquered planets, each planet has unlocks and items and units and account currency.  End of match you get a massive XP/Unlock tracking screen to see the amount of XP/Levels per in game faction (NPC and Human factions).  Each start of game you can spend currency earned doing game quests and achievements to add starting units, skills beyond what you would get in game under your current faction/secret tech selection ect.

Galaxy mode gives you this sort of rogue light account to the 4x, which stives you to play another game.  Its fantastic.  Without it id probably have stopped playing after one mega long match.  This needs to stay for every future 4x.

In game i get a random quest pop up for some other faction, giving me account currency and XP for that faction the unlock more of their gear ect....its a faction that has something i want, now i care about said quest.  Its fun playing and seeing all the various factions i aided or destroyed be converted into XP into them.

Overall: game is hard to recommend for die hard 4x players unless you want exposure to the galaxy more, cant stand how overly complicated 4x games have become, or want to enjoy a more complete manual combat.  If galaxy mode doesnt sink its teeth into you there wont be much here.  This game feels more like a turn based RTS than a true 4x.

Get it on sale, and lets hope the next 4x they make adds back the complexity and depth and retains galaxy mode and the end game "future tech" research item and the secret techs win conditions.  Three great mechanics that will add to the 4x genre.

While this game brings 3 brilliant new mechanics to 4x, it just wont sink its teeth into you like a good Faraxis or Amplitude game, even AOW3 is more complex.  While the combat mechanic additions are nice, it serves to do the opposite of making 4x combat battles something i crave.  Youll skip most so, the cover mechanics, just wont be appreciated as the main point of playing like they wanted.  Mostly youll be using future tech quick win conditions to grind XP for TONS of factions for fun stuff and collect planets which are just game wins.

79257976.review:
AoW Planetfall is a straight upgrade from Age of Wonders in every aspect, with lots of new features that really enrich the experience.

It's perhaps more difficult to get in to, as like AoW a lot of the units, abilities and skills are all a bit nebulous at first.  It's all defined if you look it up but you really are dropped in at the deep end.

Significant changes from Age of Wonders:
Tactical combat is better and slightly more complex than AoW.
End game isn't just spamming higher tier units, because of the mod system you can customize units to provide slightly different roles, it also means your end game armies will optimally be using a great variety of units as you can create really nice synergy, even with modded tier 1 units.
There is a game mode that links together games, where you are conquering planets.  This is way better than it sounds, as you will feel a connection to things you have done before, you will level up and be doing missions in games to improve your galactic progress, Commanders you have in your empire will turn up as heroes in your games.  I literally jumped straight in to another game after my last because of the feeling of progression and connection that carries over.  1 more turn is endless.
In Age of Wonders the class of your leader was the most significant with the race having a subtle effect, it is somewhat in reverse in Planetfall.  Race is the most important choice, with secret tech having a more subtle but not insignificant effect.
So far I've found less broken overpowered things than in Age of Wonders. Age of Wonders you could really do some silly things with indestructible heroes and even units, I haven't found ways to do things as silly as that, which is a great thing for longevity.

For anyone else who hasn't played AoW, Planetfall plays similarly to 4X games but with good tactical combat.  The emphasis is on the battles between armies, and there's no other game in the genre that does combat as well.

Overall a fantastic sequel to a great game, AoW Panetfall deserves a lot more attention than it gets.

TL;DR: If you found the Endless games beautiful and intriguing, but frustrating in terms of mechanics, gameplay, and player freedom? Play this instead. 

I picked this up through Humble Choice, and wasn't expecting to think much of it -- I'm much more to the Civ and Stellaris side of 4X gaming -- but, much to my surprise, I found a game which took all the potential of Endless Space II & Endless Legend and gave me something I could actually work with. See, while I enjoy cool battles and leveling up my units, I don't want that to be the only thing I'm doing -- and I *certainly* don't want that to be the *main* thing I'm doing. 

Planetfall lets me focus on planning and growing my civilization in peaceful/defensive ways, while exploring the various cool sites scattered around the map. It's much easier to nerf my opponents/make them peaceful than it has been in other games in this sort, and that suits my low-key playstyle just fine. When I want challenges, I go after the increasingly difficult npcs/'barbarian'-type units out there -- which can also be set not to attack, if that's your thing. 

Reviewers who have said that you can't play a peaceful game with Planetfall are only partially correct. This is by no means as mellow a game as you can get with the proper settings on, say, Civ V or VI. However, if you're the kind of person who occasionally needs to stomp assorted beings while slowly ascending to galactic superiority? 

You can do a lot worse than this. 

*thinks* I described it to one of my partners as Civ Meets Diablo, but I think it's actually a lot more like one of my beloved sim-farming games on a decidedly epic scale. Like, you're rebuilding Portia... world.

Add in the great music, the fun voice acting, and, again, the fact that the game is freakin' gorgeous -- call it 7.5/10. I'd give it an even higher grade, but a lot of the fun/customizability is coming from fan-mods and paid dlcs. I'm iffy on that model.

77209078.review:
This game is easily one of the best newer strategy games (i.e. 4X style game) currently available for single player in my opinion, period. I've had a lot of time to try several of these sorts of games that are considered the top games in the category lately. Civ, Total War games, Stellaris, Endless Legend, the list goes on, but I always come back to this one.

NOTE: Many of the reviews for this game were from when the game was released, since then they did a massive update that re-balanced the game and overhauled several mechanics. A lot of the comments in negative reviews were from a year+ ago using the old mechanics. This game is being actively improved / patched as of Oct 2020 from what I've seen and they're still releasing an expansion.

I'll get the cons out of the way first:

CONS: 
- The campaign storyline is pretty poorly written compared to the rest of the game and its lore excerpts. They definitely need an editor. I still really enjoyed the campaign though, and definitely think it's worth it to learn the game. I don't think Civ even had a campaign..

- Some minor bugs encountered during the campaign, but the game is constantly saving every turn so it wasn't a gigantic deal to reload

- On extra large maps with tons of opponents the game gets pretty heavy on the CPU around turn 70+. Turns take around 15-30s seconds for me at that point on a fairly strong i7 from 3 years ago. I didn't encounter this on non-huge maps or when using Simultaneous Turns mode to speed things up.

- The game can be a bit overwhelming if you're totally unfamiliar with Age of Wonders, so you'll probably be playing at least 2 maps before you get the hang of things. I shouldn't need to warn people but 4X games are time consuming, heh.

- The AI could still use improvement. They make some questionable military decisions at times and you can fleece them in diplomacy if you're clever enough. I didn't have problems adding more enemies/setting various options to up the difficulty though.

PROS:

- Campaign is like 200 hours+ of gameplay in the base game alone. It's... quite a bit longer than that if you are taking your time. You will be getting your money's worth if you stick to this game.

- Good UI scaling if you play on a TV or super high resolution

- Best combat system of any newer 4X I've played [b]by far[/b]. My God it's good. It's especially good if you like XCOM (it uses things like overwatch, cover, etc. for the tactics). Several points below outline why I think so.

- Even if you hate the combat or XCOM, this game lets you auto-combat on a per battle basis if you want, and essentially sidestep the tactical combat if you dislike it or want to skip trivial fights, so you can ALSO play it as a pure empire building game if you wanted to. 

- Tactical battles allow you to re-watch what happened turn-by-turn even if you auto-combat, and also give you the option of RETRYING a fight without reloading the game, which is great! You can even pull up battle replays from the very beginning of the match at any time (say if you forgot what loadouts your enemy units were using). You can also pull out of combat before it starts if you're attacking with no penalty, movement or otherwise.

- If you were a Heroes of Might and Magic 3 fan try this game and AOW3 out as well, they're the true spiritual successors to the legendary game itself IMO! Same strategic map / empire building / tactical combat balance.

- Easy and unfrustrating save system, this thing saves my games automatically going back dozens of turns (in addition to regular save / quick save options), loading games is a nearly instantaneous for me. Taking back huge mistakes is a matter of 5 seconds.

- Several races with their totally own style to choose from, several "classes" to choose from (called secret techs in this game, but same idea). Each combination plays / feels a lot different than the other ones, each mission felt like a new experience to me.

- In addition to the usual racial and class-based units you'd expect, this game has an amazing "mods" (unit/hero upgrade) system, allowing you to upgrade and customize the loadout of every single unit and hero in your army. This means the game's combat has hundreds if not thousands of combinations and strategies in it that other games don't because they don't allow such deep flexibility. Facing a faction of sentient plants? Burn them by adding fiery lasers to your robots. Enemy stunning your robots too much with electric attacks? Add some +electricity resistance defense mods to your units. You get the idea.

- Heroes can level up, get talents and switch out what weapons/gear they have. They can even talent into piloting and drive around in vehicles.

- Units can level up (although they aren't as extreme as heroes). So a "Veteran" unit after several battles would be stronger than a unit you just trained. The "prime" top tier rank usually grants the units an additional, more powerful bonus than the weaker ones from the other ranks. You get rewarded for being good at fighting and being smart with units.

- This game lets you research fast map movement speed and teleporters regardless of what race/class you are. A lot of games become a slog on super large maps without this.

- Pretty good sound track and the racial announcers during fights make it sound exciting. "Enemy OBLITERATED!"

- Tons of space / sci fi references if you're into that. The game doesn't take itself too seriously, but it has some seriously awesome lore and references of its own. The visual artwork is really solid too.

- Founding colonies and exploiting resources: the actual "empire building" and research aspect of this game is solid and not overly punishing or boring.

- Adventure on the map: visit exploration sites and curiosities on the map, fight monsters, gain treasure and items! Do quests for rewards too! (just like in heroes of might and magic). I felt like I was actually *doing interesting things* and being rewarded during the game instead of just passing turns for the empire building to complete.

- Multiple ways to victory! Win by whatever play style you want, including: just murdering everyone else, becoming a diplomacy expert and "peacefully" winning, using a doomsday weapon, controlling the overwhelming majority of map sectors, or if you're in the campaign often just doing the quest lines.

In summary:

This game is one of the best there is in the genre right now as of Oct 2020, putting a particular emphasis on action and tactical combat, although still a very rewarding game even if auto-combated for all battles. The game is almost criminally underrated on steam right now and if you're looking to try a new 4X I think this game is a must try.

There is also a severe lack of interesting locations or cool unique weapons/armor in the game. they made the entire "rpg" feel of the game EXTREMELY boring and monotone. unlike last game you can now equip regular units with gear - its a pretty basic inventory but they are just units so thats to be expected - the tradeoff? The heroes got the same treatment. The inventory is appalingly bland and boring compared to last installment.

And then the basebuilding and zone-expanding.. this game gives you about 20 rounds before the AI's have blocked you off entirely from expanding. the whole zone system is disturbingly boring to deal with, since unlike last game its more math than fluid fun, and coupled with that the AI just use its borders to lock you within your own little enclosure just drains so much out of the game... You cant even declare war on them without MAJOR repurcussions from literally everyone on the map unless you have a reason. a reason, mind you - that the game decides for you.

Speaking of the declaration of war, why did it have to be so extremely clunky? just another tiny change for god knows what reason - but it did subtract from my fun atleast.

And the spells. jesus christ, the spells. They were basic in the previous games, basic but fun - and I dont know how or why, but apparently - they needed to be even more basic. you have 2/2 spells per day left. oh, you used this shitty little spell, ah, subtract one point from your spell per day count. What was wrong with the mana system? this way there is no difference between a complete garbage spell and one spell you will use time and time again because its amazing. this was just a letdown altogether since mage was my favorite in the previous game.

And then lastly the tech-tree. Now, this obviously is a subjective view, just like the rest of this review - but personally, being able to see literally all the stuff and what leads to what was just.. you guessed it - boring. it becomes less of a, what do i need now - do i wanna take the risk of teching my spell in hopes that the one i need shows up, or should i go with the safe-bet of researching better units - and more of a, ok, this goes there and that goes there and i want that one so i just have to go this tech-road for 135 turns, cool - lets do that. 

I guess as I type this its becoming more and more apparent that this does not feel like a game to me, it feels like a math-problem. Everything is so open and precise it removes the "mystique" from the game. Every AI will block you inside, every game with your favorite combination will be the same, every zone you encounter will be lackluster, every game will always end up with min-maxing, going the most efficient route etc - if you have played one game as Race X and hidden tech X you have played them all.

This game is boring. and I truly wish it wasn't. Good thing Age of Wonders 3 still exist.

As a final PS: I did use some hyperbole here, there are some elements of mystique and randomness, but to me - you pretty much saw what the game had to offer after 10 hours, and the later 40 felt like a forced slog. ive uninstalled this game more times than ive started it up because the thought of playing it literally bores me, this however is the case for me, it might not be for you. If you prefer Civilization to Might&Magic you might enjoy this game, I however - did not.

76160204.review:
I have been a fan of the entire series since AoW 1, and have well over 700 hours invested in AoW 3. For me, this used to be the better version of Heroes of Might and Magic. There are things I really like in Planetfall, but the things against are too serious for me to enjoy it the way I enjoyed the previous games.

The good
If you played the previous games, at the beginning you will probably have an impression that the combat has been improved. Maps feature a lot of destructable elements that explode doing damage and adding status effects to units within one hex radius. These are not gimmicks, but meaningful combat factors that you may want to exploit to tilt the scales in your favor. Many ranged units have directional overwatch like in Gears: Tactics, which allows you to dig-in and fire at the enemy when he enters your range on his round. You have a free action to rotate your units so they do not end up flanked at the end of their movement. Each unit has action points that are spent on movement, attacks and abilities, giving you a better idea of the actions you have left. Every colony automatically starts with a garrison that you cannot move and is not visible on the map, you can improve the tier of the defending units by purchasing military infrastructure (like buildings), and you can also add units that you have moving on the map like in the previous AoWs. Improving military infrastructure also unlocks the production of turrets, which can also be upgraded. Defending such a fortress can be very entertaining. Heroes have skills, equipment and mods, and they can also drive vehicles. All units also have access to 3 mod slots, which can dramatically change their effectiveness. When preparing for battle, you are provided with some combined numbers on the strength of the attacking/defending army, making it easier to decide whether you want an automatic or tactical battle. The scenery for tactical battles is varied and pleasant to the eye. The soundtrack was made by Michiel Van Den Bos, the legend that made a lot of music for the first Unreal Tournament, and I had the track Wave of Hostility on repeat on my PC for an hour. Diplomacy has been significantly improved, even if you just play to kill every other enemy on the map. Diplomacy points are a resource that you gather over time and as a result of your actions and can spend e.g. to instantly purchase unique units and technology from neutral factions scattered on the map, you can ask them to vacate a strategically important location, and to prod them to perform certain activities. When you accelerate the production of units, you no longer have to wait 1 turn for the production to finish - it happens instantly. You can only do this once in a turn, but this often is a game changer anyway. The map features environmental hazards that add variety, affect all armies and can be removed if you have the appropriate resources. The tech tree is alright, separated into military and social upgrades that develop simultaneously. They unlock what you would expect to unlock, units, map and diplomatic abilities, improved resource gathering, mods, combat "magic", etc.

The bad
You may have noticed I haven't written anything positive about empire building. That's because I don't believe it has been changed for the better. The map is divided into sectors that yield specific resources depending on the type of terrain. They can also provide additional bonuses if you clear neutral factions guarding specific locations which may or may not be in a given sector. The sectors do not increase their sphere of influence as time goes by, and you can only annex adjacent sectors once your colonies gain enough population. You can build new colonies only in a single specific spot in every sector, and you cannot have colonies in adjacent sectors, they need to be at least one sector (annexed or not) between them. All in all you feel you have far less control over your state, to the point it almost seems you are autopiloting this aspect of the game. Forget about clustering cities, enthusiastically looking for the best spot to construct a new settlement to reap the best possible benefits. It's all very simplistic and unentertaining. The map looks bland, the colors are odd, it doesn't really encourage you to explore. The idle animations are alright, but many other are hideous. I mean, literally, go to YouTube and look at the jump attacks of units, or how jets crash into the ground, this stuff is straight from the second generation of consoles. The story is a joke. It starts strong, setting the right tone, like a sci-fi classic - an army returns home after cryo-sleep for 2 hundred years - seems exciting. Then, in the first mission, you run around in the search of a "pleasure bot" that the human leaders of the warring factions want to *uck, cause you want to earn their respect/blackmail them. I'm not kidding, this is the "quest". They lost me after this and my friend and I just stick to the multiplayer. Speaking of which, this is a classic Paradox game. Sometimes you get kicked out every second turn or so, sometimes the game cannot connect to the servers, sometimes it quits and says it had a desync. The only improvement to multiplayer is that the saves are stored online automatically and you can rejoin quickly. They know they can't make multiplayer properly so they literally made a system that makes it easier to reconnect. That's foresight, right there.

All that would be bearable, hell, even expected from a Paradox game, but the thing that completely destroys it is the XCOM-like RNG. In combat, all units now have % chance to hit, with the possibilities of full damage, graze, or miss. This is different than in the previous AoW, where you would always hit, maybe for 1 point of damage, but you would. Why is this an issue? Because you have situations when the enemy will shoot you for full damage from 6 hexes away, when he has two obstacles on the way to you, and you are standing behind cover in an elevated area in your fortress. At the same time, you will do less damage or completely miss a unit standing in the open with one hex between you. Just last game, a tier II gunship, shooting from above missed a tier I unit standing on the adjacent hex below. The randomness is atrocious, even more so because it seems so one-sided. I don't know what they did to the AI but on normal difficulty they will hurt you far more frequently than you will, and that's with low-tier units, very often to the point that you having cover is completely irrelevant for the AI. Some tier I units are op af. You get tier I critters that attack three times with a chain lightning-like beam that jumps around all adjacent units. As I said, at the beginning combat seems very captivating and exciting, but after 20 hours of playing you peel off the surface and see the rotten core. It's broken, it's frustrating and it's bad design. We will probably keep playing it a bit more, after all, I have enjoyed the series for 20 years, I will see if my opinion changes on this one, but I already stalled writing this review hoping for I don't know what. Right now, I'm of the opinion that there are better games than this, even by the same developer.

As someone who really enjoys strategy games, something about [i]Age of Wonders: Planetfall[/i] just fell short for me. 

Visually, the game is stunning. The maps are covered in detail, foliage, natural formations, and more that really bring the areas to life. [url=https://store.steampowered.com/developer/triumphstudios]Triumph Studio's[/url] Art Team deserves high praise as the characters, creatures, and units are all beautiful as well. The visuals, paired with a soothing soundtrack (albeit it can get repetitive after tens of hours), make playing and listening to the game a wonderful experience. So where does the game fall short?

To be honest it's hard for me to really pinpoint where [i]Age of Wonders: Planetfall[/i] missed the mark, but I'm leaning toward the combat. The different factions feel a little stereotypical and rely on many genre tropes. Each faction excels at a different aspect of the game's mechanics, and they tend to make sense and tie into the lore and history of the factions well enough. The combat is similar to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/200510/XCOM_Enemy_Unknown/]XCOM: Enemy Unknown[/url] but not nearly as polished. Even after 50 hours, I found myself struggling to understand the best way to move and position my units to maximize damage. One example is when units with an assault rifle could attack three times at 50% accuracy, but if moved to a flank position with 95% accuracy, all of a sudden that unit will only fire one time for a third of the damage. It was hidden mechanics like this that really made the combat frustrating, instead of fun (like [i]XCOM[/i]) and basically forced me to always auto-resolve combat with overwhelming force.

The diplomacy mechanics were well done. You have some additional options compared to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/594570/Total_War_WARHAMMER_II/]Total War: WARHAMMER II[/url] with the ability to trade territories, but the mechanics are not as nearly fleshed out as [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/779340/Total_War_THREE_KINGDOMS/]Total War: THREE KINGDOMS[/url]. 

Replayability is great if you enjoy the game. You can create custom sized maps with your choice of number of other AI players and friends. Performance was outstanding. Playing the game at the highest settings at 4K, I always stayed int he 50-60 fps range. 

Overall, I have to say I'm a little disappointed by [i]Age of Wonders: Planetfall[/i]. Not to say I didn't enjoy it, I just wish it had something more unique about it that made me want to play it over something else. It's not a bad game, and certainly not a bad strategy game, but there are many other available options that are far superior in my opinion such as [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/594570/Total_War_WARHAMMER_II/]Total War: WARHAMMER II[/url] or [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/779340/Total_War_THREE_KINGDOMS/]Total War: THREE KINGDOMS[/url].

Hey WallaWallas, thank you for your review and we're sorry to hear you didn't enjoy Age of Wonders: Planetfall. 

I would like to address your experience with Tactical Combat. During Tactical Combat units have 3 Action Points they can spend on movement and abilities. When you have a unit selected you'll see a grid of four colours (green, blue, purple and red) on the map, these colours indicate how many Action Points will be removed by moving into that section. While moving in the green area no AP is removed, 1 AP is removed when moving into the blue section, 2 AP when moving into the purple section and 3/All AP is removed when moving into the Red area. Additionally, Action Points can be removed through status effects and stagger. If you move into the Overwatch view of another unit and they have a ability that can stagger, you can end up losing an additional AP on top of the AP required to move.

In your example you're using a Repeating ability, meaning it will fire as many times as the unit has AP. If the unit fired only once either of the following scenario's might have occured:
[list]
[*] You moved the unit from it's starting position into the Purple section which requires 2 AP to achieve.
[*] You moved the unit from it's starting position into the Blue section which requires 1 AP to achieve, but moved into a enemies overwatch range and got hit with a stagger ability resulting in the removal of another AP.
[/list]

Hopefully this cleared up some of the issues you had with Tactical Combat and provided new insights.

With Regards,
Jordi

Dishing out the most damage isn't always the best strategy, as even low-threat enemies can focus-fire one or two of your soldiers before you wipe them all out. On the other hand, once you get the hang of things, you can take down enemies who far outrank you in terms of sheer military power.

Well, it's a game that I would have picked up on day 1 and by now have played 500+ hours. The's not the case only because lately my PC-bound play is down to kinda nothing.   And while that does not stop me from getting more games most of the inbound is big discounts and bundles.  Planetfall came with humble monthly, kicking it from the top of my 250+ WL. 

I'm an old AOW fan from their first games that brought me plenty of joy -- and be a very rare actual success of following MoM. And the whole line kept to the excellent standard.  If you are into this genre I suggest to get all those old games, they are still better than most what came after.  The design manages to collect the best parts of other games and make a good mix on both thematic and technical level. And even manage to add some unique elements.

PF also builds on top of many other games, and maybe not even have a unique this time around -- but this does not make it bad or lacking.  As the ingredient games (most notable probably SMAC and the new XCOM) had serious problems  gameplay-wise.  So the innovation was mostly wasted.  Not here.  
Let's see what you have:
 - a single-planet 4X as the core with economy based on sectors rather than small cells and colonies instead of cities
 - falling on the lighter side with city improvements and more on tech tree, also trying to go against much micromanagement
 - many different factions with their special approach, units and special techs
 - unit system with prototypes, hero leaders, unit mods, XP gain. army size limited to 6 but battle dragging in all surrounding hexes
 - tactical and strategic ops replacing the spells 
 - rich tactical battles on a big map with terrain, functional but destructible cover, and extreme variety of things at your fingertips. and finally thinking about players: you can repeat the battle from the exit screen if figured out better tactics, also auto-resolve can be watched and turned into manual after the fact. No need to waste saves/loads on that. 
 - world generated with locations, NPC races, barbarians
 - good diplomacy system and NPC quests 
 - beyond the sandbox there is campaign and multiplayer
 - the art and the score is beautiful

On the other side there are some crashes (the autosave rescues most of what you do) and potential balance issues -- the game is maybe a year old and got plenty of patches addressing issues, I expect more to come. 

I didn't play enough to tell about the thing most important to me: reasonably playing AI, but this far did not encounter a major blunder and didn't see comments about that, so I keep the hopes up.  For reasonable play on high challenge level I'll certainly need to learn a lot about the details, 

TLDR: looks like on of the best current offerings in the genre, if you read to this far, just go and obtain it.

A good 4X. I've only played the base campaigns; this review does not extend to the DLC gameplay or generic scenario maps. Before you start playing, you should know you can speed up map movement on both strategic and tactical layers from the game options - you'll want to very soon even into your first campaign,

Pros:
+ Playing well tactically can let you pull off victories that the army balance would say are impossible, and it feels really satisfying when you do. Accuracy and cover work in interesting ways, and it's sometimes worth it to take shots at 15% hit chance. Additionally, the support skill system is fun to use, though it doesn't feel very well balanced.
+ Strategically, exploring new worlds is enjoyable, as is growing your colonies and setting up defenses and transport nodes in anticipation of what your enemies will do.
+ Decent graphics, light but pleasant lore. Some of the voice acting doesn't fit at times, but it's almost comical when that happens, like a golden radio voice telling me about mass genocide in an upbeat tone.
+ Moment-to-moment gameplay almost always keeps you on your toes. I had a hard time putting down the game mid-map; there was always one more place to raid or army to fight.
+ Lots of ways to customize your units, allowing for different tactical strategies. Sometimes you'll end up preferring tier 1 bonuses that give a very niche effect even if the overall stats are lower compared to tier 4 alternatives, just because you're going for a certain playstyle. 
+ Also, the fact that your main heroes are campaign-persistent is nice. On the downside, that did make me end up grinding already-won maps so I could have a power start in the next.
+ Great, memorable soundtrack. Parts of it reminds me of Westwood game soundtracks, while the rest feels like an 80s sci-fi action movie. Really solid, unique feel.
+ Even though I didn't play MP, I like the idea that you can log off while waiting for turns and get notified when yours starts. Given how long turns can take, I wouldn't like to have to wait for possibly an hour, so I felt like this might be worth mentioning for those who do want to play online.
+ I like that you can defeat an enemy by taking out their main commander and their capital, as opposed to having to spend a lot of time conquering each individual settlement and defeating each army. Outmaneuvering them is rewarded.

It's not without some flaws, though:
- The turn timer gets really long past turn 50 or so, and not always for good reason. In one case, there were only a few dozen NPC armies left and two factions that did nothing but turtle. It probably boiled down to trying to find options when they were severely limited in what they could do, but it was frustrating.
- In the early game, losing any units at all is very punishing, which leads to a tendency to repeat battles a lot, which ends up being tedious.
- Tying into my previous point, the tactical AI doesn't understand attrition very well. It won't use choke points, nor keep melee units back to allow your ranged units to bait and punish. Additionally, if you have a lot of army support skills, it will spam them in favor of actually killing enemies. It does sometimes set up overwatch traps on defense maps, but only if it "feels" you can't hit them with anything. You can break it using a support skill and they won't retry.
- The strategic AI sometimes plays in very unnatural ways. It might just be bias, but it feels like when I'm attacked they show up with a doomstack at my border, but they'll be at war with an ally for ages and never move back and forth more than one settlement.
- There's lots of variety in tactical support skills and espionage operations, but it doesn't feel like most of them are meaningful or worth the cost compared to alternatives.
- You can find yourself in a real slog with progress in the last 1/3 of some campaigns. There is one specific Syndicate map with lots of water and teleporters that was a particular nightmare.

The tutorial could be a bit better about explaining some core concepts - such as: 
1. you should take your scout units from your first stacks and send them out to explore right from turn 1, 
2. almost every colony needs at least the first military defense upgrade to survive random marauders, unless you clear their spawners out, which you won't probably have the time for
3. you should almost always focus on NPC faction quests in the early game and save up influence to buy a stack from them as your 2nd/3rd army
4. having an air unit raider stack can be a very powerful strategy, as they can cross water and mountains very fast and let you do precision strikes
5. before finishing a campaign, kit out your main commander with the best stuff you can get that would work against tier 1 or 2 units, as you'll be using them to clear out the early and mid game for the next campaign
6. when picking new sectors, cosmite is usually the most important to get, followed by influence, followed by everything else. Also, you can talk to friendly NPC faction armies to get them off of occupied resource points - I didn't know this for quite some time.

All in all, I had a good time, and I would recommend the game to people who enjoy Civ-style games but would like more control over their units. I've played a lot of XCOM, and I wouldn't agree the tactical gameplay is all that similar, but it does feel good for the most part.

72115322.review:
Taking on the feel of Civilization, XCOM, and former Age of Wonders games, Planetfall distinguishes itself from its predecessors by improving some mechanics and leaving behind others that made the other games fun. Overall, this is a unique experience that can still be a lot of fun despite its imperfections.

Likes
o	Experience is divided amongst units at the end of battle. Big improvement since experience could be over-farmed in former AoE games.
o	Modding units allows for more unit customization.
o	Great themes. Each civilization is interesting with unique benefits.
o	Cities are much more customizable, allowing players to modify their economy to fit their sitation.
o	Tactical combat is strategic and gritty.

Dislikes
o	Experience is capped. In other AoW games, units would continue to get experience though with diminishing returns.
o	Unit levels don’t give interesting perks. Getting a unit to gold experience usually gave some sort of game changing ability or trait in other AoE games that allowed weaker units to scale into late game.
o	Unit movement on the global map is mostly the same for units. In other AoE games, there were benefits and drawbacks for mobile armies of calvary versus strong, slow armies. Now it mostly only matters what kind of terrain is traversed rather than a unit’s base value for movement.
o	Captured NPC factions you are at war with can be annexed and cannot be migrated. Diminishes the theme.

Bugs – Nothing game breaking but still mentionable.
o	Sometimes enemy units in tactical combat take about 60 seconds to move. This is rare, but sometimes an AI controlled unit seems to “sit and think” for a while before moving.
o	Models of units getting blasted in overwatch will not always appear on the correct square after ending the turn. (I.e. the unit will look like it’s on a different square. Attacking the “true” square still works; this is just a visual bug.)
