71691777.review:
A very shallow and simplified but colorful mashup of several popular games.

First off: There's nothing actually wrong with this game, however I'm requesting a refund from steam because it isn't what I was expecting or looking for.

The game is a combination of Civilizations lite, X-Com lite, and RPG lite elements. If you find Civilizations too complicated or X-Com too difficult and want to combine those games with some mild RPG elements in a very colorful and slick setting, you'll enjoy it. If you're looking for something deeper or more complex, look elsewhere.

4X Gameplay: Essentially Civ 6 with fewer build options, restricted city founding locations, fewer resources, etc. Your cities generate Energy, production (just like civ 6), research (just like civ 6), and food (just like civ 6) each turn. You can expand cities by annexing adjacent zones and building expansion buildings on them (just like districts in civ 6). There's a very small research tree (just like civ 6) which essentially unlocks units and unit upgrades. You get the idea. Each faction only has about 8 units in total.

Combat: I haven't played X-Com, but this is exactly like what I expect a dumbed-down X-Com is like. The maps are colorful but not that varied. They are small  and everything on them can basically be classified as A: Cover, B: LoS blocker, C: Something that explodes and damages adjacent hexes. Battles typically last no more than 3 turns, which is good because you'll be fighting a lot of battles against AI units roaming the map, and every battle is pretty much the same, so by the time you finish the tutorial, you've basically seen it all. Each unit in your army has a basic attack and 1 or 2 special abilities which are typically one use per battle. Some units can set overwatch, most can't. There's some basic tactical elements like cover and flanking, but don't expect too much.

RPG: After gaining experience from combat, you can level up your heroes with a variety of abilities that mostly boil down to +X% to accuracy/damage/etc. on your hero, or +X% to your army. There's some extremely shallow RPG elements involved with interacting with NPC factions, but it pretty much boils down to "declare war" or "do quest to defeat enemy stack X or collect some amount of resource Y in exchange for reputation".

In summary, this game is colorful, slick, and polished. There's a number of factions with a unique flair, but by the time you finish the tutorial campaign, you've seen about all there is to see in the game. If you find other games too complicated or you just want something very casual, this game will do good for you. However, to those used to Paradox's other 4X titles like Stellaris, this game will leave you feeling underwhelmed.

If you like deep 4x games: Get Civilization 6 or Stellaris instead.
If you like deep turn based tactical squad combat: Get Battletech or X-Com instead.
If you like deep turn based adventure RPGs: Not my lane, but I'm sure there's better games for that too.

71408473.review:
This is right on the borderline for me between positive and negative. Ultimately i'm not recommending it it because I doesn't really do anything better than it's competetors, and I can't think of a good reason to play this over TW or Civ. 

On the one hand, it's not an objectively bad game, there are good elements
- It looks great! There are some really cool units and the maps all look amazing.
- The UI is clean and attractive presents info well - not often the case in this type of game
- It has a load of content variety, different creatures, types of ammo, powers etc (though this doesn't necessarily translate well into gameplay variety)
- The systems do a great job of carrying you through the game and giving you that 'one more turn' drug. I did play it till 3 several days in a row.

But these things are outweighed by the bad
- The campaign gameplay is comparatively very linear. Unlike Civ, you don't feel like there are many different ways to play a game. The management systems are fairly sparse so it's hard to specialise, and go tall or wide, or shoot for a diplomatic victory. Maybe you can if you are really pro - but the fact the game didn't communicate this to me in nearly 20 hours of gameplay is not good. Unlike TW, it lacks the extreme differences across factions and start positions.
- The battle systems are also pretty linear. It's turn based, and there is a load of unit customisation, which games like X-com have shown can lead to massive variety. Unfortunately, due to the very basic design of the battlefields and the hugely long ranges, it's very hard to mix things up and feel smart. 
- This is more nebulous - but I just didn't feel engaged. My choices didn't feel that consequential, so I just drifted through my games. I was addictively taking turns but I felt pretty empty afterwards. No highs, lows or bloggable moments. 

TLDR - A pretty accomplished game with a lot of polish, that unfortunately fails to give you a reason to play it over a competitor.

As searing bolts of arc energy and screaming psyonic power filled the air, Sulemar Atredies, firstborn son of House Atredies, one of the Syndicate's greatest noble families, couldn't help but smile behind his veil as the warriors of his house advanced on the city's last line of defense, the last thing standing between him and mastery of Arrakis.

Vast numbers of Indentured footsoldiers clad in black body gloves and equipped with arc rifles and neural control devices advanced relentlessly through the streets, ignoring their own casualties as they poured fire into the Vanguard troops.  Overseers drove them on, adding psyonic blasts from their staffs to the Indentured's firepower and occasionally using their neural override protocol to force a unit to run farther or fight harder.  Slinking from cover to cover, hooded Assassins sniped at any enemy that dared poke their head over the wall.

Behind the infantry came the vehicles of House Atredies; sleek silver hovercraft with smooth lines and beautiful sails.  Though they resembled the pleasure craft used by many noble houses for travel across the planet's surface, they were very much built for war:  Heavy armor and shields protected them and their crews from enemy fire, and as they advanced, they blasted at the enemy with powerful psionic cannons that could break minds and bodies alike.

Sulemar watched as his Indentured brought down a large Vanguard Walker with their arc rifles.  It froze up as the arc energy overloaded its systems, then toppled over with an earth-shaking crash.  His men cheered and he nodded in satisfaction at the new power his infantry could bring to bear.  

His scientists really had done a wonderful job upgrading his troops’ weapons.  Not only had their power output increased, but every shot that hit its target would jump to several nearby enemy units, electrocuting them as well as the target.  With this power, his men were scything through the Vanguard's mechs and tanks, the blue arc energy frying their circuits.  It also appeared to work well enough against fleshy targets, he thought as he watched a squad of Vanguard troops get gunned down by the Indentured, their bodies spasming as the shock coursed through their power armor and nervous systems.

He felt a pang of pity as he watched the soldiers die and shook his head sadly.  It was a shame, really, that House Atredies and the 113th Vanguard Expeditionary Corps had come to blows.  They'd both been dispatched centuries ago to colonize Arrakis for the Star Union, only to emerge from cryostasis and discover that the Star Union had long ago collapsed for reasons unknown and they had no contact with any outside planets.  

Without the means for another interstellar voyage, they both made planetfall on Arrakis and set about establishing civilizations.  There were hardships, of course; reactivated Reaper nests that spawned homicidal robots, former Star Union nobility who'd degenerated into insane technocultists, pirates, monsters, and many more dangers.

There were also more familiar faces, ones he knew from the happier days of the Star Union; the biology-altering Amazons and their reptilian pets, the undead techno-abominations of the Assembly, and more.  There was even a species of extragalactic conquerors looking to scavenge the Star Union's remains like a vulture.  It had taken an alliance with the Vanguard and Amazons to finally drive them off the planet.

He remembered the victory celebration following that victory, held in the very streets his troops were now fighting over.  He’d met the leaders of the Vanguard and Amazons and, before the cheering crowds, swore friendship between their peoples.  

That was five years ago.  In that time, the Amazons had fallen to the Assembly’s techno-organic horde and he had wiped out the Assembly only to be attacked by the Vanguard.  Now the Vanguard’s armies were broken, and their capital was about to fall.  The Syndicate’s silken banners would fly over the entirety of Arrakis.  It really was a shame that things hadn’t turned out better between them, Sulemar thought as he watched his troops reach the fortified walls of the city’s last stronghold.  He only hoped the Vanguard’s people would accept Syndicate rule peacefully.

An explosion ripped through several clustered Indentured units and the leader of the 113th Expeditionary Corps, Vanguard General Galen Jerrus, emerged from the smoke in his power armor and ever-present brown trench coat, followed by his remaining heroes and the last Vanguard reserves.  Together they unleashed a storm of bullets and lasers that cut down the closest Syndicate troops and sent the rest scrambling for cover as a fierce firefight began at the stronghold's entrance. 

Sulemar smiled grimly and raised his trusty psionic sniper rifle.  At last, the treacherous dog had reavealed himself.  His monocle quickly gathered information on his target as he rested the crosshairs on Galen’s head.  The war for Arrakis would end today…

From what i've played so far, i'm really impressed.  If you like Civ (alpha centuri'ish), turn based combat and a decent reward system to upgrade units/Hero's - you will like this!

Races: Only played as vanguard so far but there are a fair few. Races are all unique (including the minor NPC Factions that you can recruit units/get unique items from if you win their favour).  You can customise your main general which isn't massively in depth, but enough to ensure that your faction doesn't look too much like others.

Colony Development:  Its fine - Not the best in this type of game, but not the weakest either.  Build food, research stations etc on that specific colony, invest in better barracks etc...standard stuff.  You can get a few unique buildings when capturing Annexing things like spaceports, armouries etc that can be developed further in order to give you more buffs/resources.

Combat and units: Turn based with cover systems and is pretty fun. You can auto resolve if you wish, but there are many times you will want to manually fight - such as if the odds are not exactly in your favour and you want to minimise loss, or if there is a good chance you will fail. You cannot create giant stacks of doom as each 'Army' can only have 6 units (from what i've seen so far anyway), but can reinforce each other if they are nearby.  Random Hero units will appear outside your main settlement from time to time that you can hire - these can be equipped with different weapons and vehicles/mounts that you can find, be rewarded with or buy in order to help support your troops and win fights. Normal troops can have 3 different items to customise them like flechette rounds or Stim Packs etc, which can be saved under a template of your choice. The longer units are alive, the more experienced and tougher they get - making you feel a little invested in there well being. Heroes can get better also via spending experience on perks/abilities and as mentioned, can be equipped with weapons etc. Want a particular unit to be a bit armoured but supportive - whack them in a tank and give them abilities and tools that can heal troops and provide buffs.  Want another to be a sneaker damage dealer, give them blade, void shift device (warp through cover) and something that makes them harder to hit.  Choices are down to your play style.

Map: Very appealing and remind me a little of Civilisations Alpha Centuri. You can capture/annex unique buildings/tiles that can help boost your faction, grant unique buffs, units or 'Operations'.  be careful as neighbouring factions may have more of a claim to those tiles and capturing them may p*ss them off enough to get enough support for a cassius belli (justify war without much if a penalty). There are roaming aliens, bandits etc defending ruins and many more.  An example is that I captured a sort of old pleasure city that had rogue 'pleasure' bots that were good at mind controlling units and hand to hand combat, which I could then recruit on that tile.

Diplomacy:  Only a little so far due to the Story but there are lots of ways to appease or piss factions off.  Once you are semi friendly, they will reach out from time to time stating that you haven't offered anything/spoke in a while.  The minor NPC factions will give you missions or ask for resources in order to keep them happy and 'progress' to the next stages of your relationship until you sort of merge them with you (in a way).  During each stage unlocks new trade options involving faction specific units and items bought with influence.  Influence is the main currency used when dealing in diplomacy and trade.  NPCs taking up a landmark that you want? Spend some influence to ask them to move without fighting etc.  Want them to help you in a war? Spend 40 influence to get them on side (once you are all Allied that is) - and so on.

Operations: Are various Strategic, tactical or doctrines you can use. They affect the main campaign map or a few can be called in during battle....these cost and cannot be spammed; some taking turns to prepare.

Story: Currently playing through Vanguard Story and there are many 'missions' and ways to complete the missions (and quests within) before moving onto the next campaign - which also transfers your main Commanders progress.  There was a moment where something happened and I feel I could have prevented it.  There are lots of other storys too.

Music:  Synthwavey at times and orchestral space opera at other.  Battle music is great and fits in well.  Definately does the job on the atmospheric side.  Ambient sounds are great too!

Multiplayer: Haven't tried but only really play these types of games with Friends. I imagine it would be just as fun.

I could write more and may have missed some stuff on these but its still early days with a lot more to be seen and experienced. its a great game and you should get this!  9/10

This game is a big departure from the AoW series, not simply in lore but in actual mechanics. While they look like they could be interesting in fact they often become a detriment.

Starting with cities and sectors. Where before your city grew in area of influence now you build a city on a sector and as it grows it allows you to annex up to 5 sectors that are adjacent to one that is part of the city. Looks interesting until you realise that you need to keep units around for the sole purpose of going around annexing as needed and then you have to build upgrades on annexed sectors on top of that also concurring with any other city building you need to do. Where the latter could be called a strategical decision, the former 2 are completly pointless and boring micromanagement. They serve no other purpose than busywork.

Following on cities and pointless busywork, cities need food to grow, to grow a city at a fast enough pace you'll need food dedicated sectors, but once you reach the cap of max sectors, extra growth speed is pointless even if more people is still nice to get extra bonus. This means that early on you want at least one food sector but then you have to demolish it later to trade for something better. Meaning, more pointless busywork.

Before it was hard to actually control your domain in AoW because doing perfect math to make sure your area of influence had absolutly no gaps so the enemy wasn't constantly trying to build a city in those gaps was a headache, now you have double the headache trying to plan where you need to put cities and count which exact pieces of land they take so that the enemy can't take it, so in this point we only changed how you get the headache instead of addressing the fact that you are gettign one. But now you have the added problem that enemies build in your claimed sectors and thus create a permanent relation debuff which only penalises the player for something the AI did it himself.

As for combat it's one step forward and two steps back. We now can give units permanent enchantments in the form of mods, that is good albeit the customisation level is stageringly bad. But now we are back on the hit chances that AoW2 had. While I can understand the idea that it leads to more tactical options, fact of the matter is that it just becomes more RNG.

Since I talked about the low customisation. This is a problem that came from AoW3. I've complained as did many that the game has a very low level os customisation. in AoW3 you picked a class which gave you 90% of your research tree and then you picked a little extra that left a bad taste in your mouth. In planetfall the problem maintains. You get your race and all of it's tech + social tech which is 90% of the tech tree and then you have the other 10% being the super tech you pick which not only is severely lacking is customisation, it often is just not even good anyway.

Lastly, not necessarely a problem of the developers but this certainly needs addressing. There isn't a proper wiki. If a player wants to try to try and play with a certain build, like say, going with a really high damaging army or go with an army that heavly favors debuffing enemies or maybe one that has really good dodging chances. There is no place where we can look all technology and all mods and all units easily so that we can decide on where to go and how to do it.

After playing this game for a little bit more there are a couple things that need to be added to this review.

Age of Wonders: Planetfall recalls the classic play mechanics of previous AoW titles, with a unique twist.  Expanding territory works through claiming or colonizing regions this time around, rather than through simply expanding as you hit certain population milestones in a city.  Diplomacy is better expanded, allowing you to coordinate with player and NPC allies, and influence the standing of other players on the board.  They are, for lack of a better term, enthralling.  Depending on how you set the game up, the world itself can also be a dangerous, difficult to navigate, even hostile place, with armies of indigenous creatures and populations threatening the safety of your cities.  Each of these things adds a layer of challenge that you can add to or remove from a game before clicking "start," letting you personalize a game to test you the way you want it to.  Solid mechanics and a wide array of various dynamics make this game a must have in any strategy gamer's library.  Combine this with AoW's unique layer of RPG mechanics and you'll find that you won't always have the same experiences.

69664887.review:
So, if you haven't played an AoW title before, you're probably wondering what this game is like? It's like Civ isn't it? Well, actually no, but it is like another Firaxis title which you've likely heard of: XCOM. This is a tactical combat wargame, like XCOM but on steroids. But it also has a strategic game as well which is more like Total War rather than Civ. We'll come back to that later.

First though, the Tactical Combat is undeniably the main event of the game. This is where you'll spend most of your time.

You can mod (customise) your units with equipment unlocked by tech or bought from a neutral faction.

Your units are squads rather than individual units for the most part. Some higher tier units are individual units.

You have customisable leaders which earn experience which gives them new skills. You choose which skills and the equipment to fit them out. They can fight on foot, from a vehicle or beast or even from an aircraft.

You have Operations which you can call in during a fight with a wide variety of effects, from healing to laser strikes, call in special units or cause panic to enemy units or even subvert them etc.

It's worth mentioning that the auto combat is actually pretty fair in this game so if you don't want to fight every piddly little action, you can reliably trust the auto combat to do the job. And if you don't like the result you get, you have the option to refight it yourself. How fair is that?

Then there's the strategic map where you build your colonies and develop them. This is more like a Total War campaign map rather than Civ. The colony building is nowhere near as deep as it is in Civ but it's on  a par with TW Warhammer, at least. There are neutral factions on the map which you can do quests for or exterminate depending on your play style. There are 'barbarian' spawn sites as well as 'treasure' to find, both guarded and free to gather.

Overall, it's a very satisfying experience if you like tactical battles. The AI is above average and can use all the abilities and skills their units possess. I expect I'll get a few more hours out of this before I tire of it.

I played AOW3 for over 900 hours so I was excitedly looking forward to Planetfall. Naturally, it makes sense to compare the two.

Good changes:
+ Economics were dramatically overhauled and now there are 5 resources instead of just gold and mana. A lot of ideas were borrowed and improved on from Endless Legends and it shows
+ Dividing the map into sectors that can be captured and improved was an awesome development for the series and it's very satisfying watching the sectors change color as you capture them like a game of risk
+ Diplomacy and NPC factions were buffed significantly and far more interesting
+ The new sci-fi races are much more interesting than the usual fantasy races of orcs, goblins, elves, etc; they feel well thought out although I don't feel they are very balanced

Bad changes:
- Unfortunately, I feel that tactical combat has been changed for the worse in most ways, which sucks because that is one of the main draws of the series. The biggest change is that almost every unit has ranged attacks and every unit seems "squisher", so units die much quicker. You can have a Tier V unit on the field and it will go down to focused fire from 3-4 Tier I-II units in two rounds. Late-game units felt so much more powerful and meaningful in AOW3. Units no longer have automatic zone of control, which means that melee enemies can run past all of your blockers and attack more vulnerable units
- Related to the point above, no more castle sieges. Perhaps its more fitting with the sci-fi theme but city defense and attack combat is much less interesting than AOW3 when a smart player could hold off 5-6 stacks of enemies with 2 stacks of defenders

Overall, the game is good and worth a purchase. But the changes to combat mean I find myself hitting auto-battle more often than I'd like, so I very much doubt I'm getting even 100 hours in this, much less 900 like with AOW3

Excellent and highly recommended but it's really quite different from previous entries in the series, even though it retains all the essential components of an age of wonders game.
It's a lot closer to civilisation with large scale x-com battles fought over an entire world than earlier games which felt more like controlling multiple D&D campaigns in a single region.

What really makes it stand out though is that instead of spending magic on buffs you now apply mods which can really change up how a unit works. 
Mods can add new abilities, improve or change damage types and alter how you use a unit. It's important to note that resources spent modding cannot be refunded so, you really need to carefully plan what mods you use, this resource is also required to purchase high tier units.
Additionally the resources for mods, in-battle spells and strategic spells are all separate so you're never forced to choose between one or the other as in previous games.

On top of the different races and class types, NPC factions also each offer their own units and mods too which allows for different playstyles and unit compositions depending on what damage types you want to focus on.

As someone who has been playing since shadow magic this one is a really nice change of pace without actually removing anything which makes the series what it is.

A few weeks ago I was locked out of another game due to server issues. By chance I saw that Planetfall was on sale (-50%). I never looked back and became instantly addicted. This game truly deserves all its positive reviews. Even the negative reviews do not report game breaking technical issues or bugs. Some reviewers just  preferred a previous game from the same developers (Age of wonders 1-3) Some have criticized the visual appearance of the game. (Looks fine to me, very nice artwork on the unit cards, research tree and encyclopaedia are a bit minimalist, decent tactical combat graphics) Some people just gave up on the game after less than 10 hours.

I can confidently recommend this game for people who like 4X games (Xpand Xplore Xploit Xterminate) such as Alpha centauri, Civilisation, Warlock, Master of Magic, Endless legend, Stellaris and others. It is a fine mix of strategic map management and tactical combat. Tactical combat has similarities to X-Com but without the brutal rng failures and timer (you do have dice rolls and skill checks but you also have a drop down box detailing combat events for all the hardcore game nerds) . Once you start understanding the wonderful complexities of different possible builds and strategies it begins to feel like an advanced form of chess where you want to plan your colony expansions several turns in advance and grab special structures that will give you special bonuses. 

Units can be enhanced with mods in so many different ways. Armies consist of 6 units (including a hero who can also be customized with melee or ranged weapons, offensive or defensive mods, perks to enhance the hero or the army) Your starting faction and planet can be customized (in so many ways it will make your head spin) or randomized. 

There is an amazing level of complexity that will appeal to most strategy players who like to figure out the best possible builds for their factions.

The game rewards exploration. There is true joy in discovering rare items after defeating powerful enemies in dangerous locations.

The game will appeal to players who like to expand all over the map without expansion penalties. (You still have to manage your economy and be prepared for invasions) There are many paths to victory. Diplomacy may look deceptively simple but it is actually quite a juggling act among all the major factions.  And it seems to work for me so far. You must also handle minor factions that can sell you techs and units to improve your armies and offer quests, bounties, rewards or make demands. 

AND there is a cool Science fiction story (about the fall of a galactic empire and the struggles of various factions in the ensuing turmoil)   that plays out during the campaign. I enjoy discovering the backstory for some heroes and factions. With branching story lines you may even want to play the campaign more than once if you don't spoil it by researching it on the web.

BEGINNER TIPS: Do the tutorial (first campaign mission) The game will suggest you  play the practise planet before you do the second campaign mission. Do this. Choose hero Helen Shaw for the practise planet. (You will learn more about Helen during the next campaign mission.) You will feel lost at this point. ("What do I do next?") Find the you tube video "Planetfall 10 beginner tips" by Frost Ees OP
Have fun. Experiment. Discover. 

I can easily see myself playing over 1000 hours  of this game.

64224034.review:
Short version:
Age of Wonders: Planetfall is a very complex game with a steep learning curve that scratches the itch of wanting to enjoy both Civilization and X-Com style games at once!

Not so short version:
Age of Wonders: Planetfall is a turn-based Sci-Fi 4X game that is a cross between the Civilization and X-Com series of games.  There's a colonization and expansion part that involves exploring a newly settled planet and establishing colonies then expanding them up by annexing and specializing adjacent sectors.   Each sector has the potential to provide bonuses to FOOD for population growth, ENERGY for unit and operational costs (tactical and strategic), PRODUCTION for colony and unit generation, and KNOWLEDGE for military and social research.   Annexed sectors can be improved through additional building construction and research policies.  Some sectors contain unique landmarks that provide a specific resource boost and may also contain features such as rivers or lava streams that can be tapped though research to provide a boost to food or energy as well.  Each colony can only annex a maximum of 4 sectors so you have to have an idea of what you want a colony to specialize in and annex sectors that will fulfill that specialization (FOOD, ENERGY, PRODUCTION, or KNOWLEDGE).   You can build and acquire additional colonizer units to expand your empire and the only real downside to playing wide vs tall is protecting your colonies from other players.  There are colony upgrades that provide militia units and defense towers that will fend off most aggressive NPC attacks.

The strategic (world) map contains random resource stash pickups, anomalies that can provide encounters resulting in unique units and gear, NPC faction settlements you can befriend, trade and ally with, or even attack and conquer.  Allied NPCs will often provide quests (missions) and make demands on you for assistance or resources.   Once your reputation is high enough you can buy their units, offensive and defensive mods, or even ask them to go to war with you.  

In your travels across the planet you'll also run across other players (human or AI) and can also ally and trade with them, perform covert operations on their colonies, or go to war with them.  The diplomatic dialog is similar to Civilization where you can negotiate to trade resources, set up defensive pacts, send gifts or make demands.  You can also make pronouncements that can increase or decrease your standing with them.  The declare war system is similar to Civilization as you'll take a reputation hit for attacking other players without just cause.  If they settle near your colony, or insult you, or if you use covert operations to fabricate false accusations about them, they will build up Casus Belli, which allows you to declare war without taking a negative penalty hit to your reputation.  Reputation is global.  What you do will have affect on how other player and non player NPC factions treat you.

You start out with one hero unit which is your faction commander, who can be improved over time as they gain experience.  You can also recruit additional hero units and there many abilities they can select from like increasing their health, or improving ranged/melee attack and defense or providing auras (buffs) to the units under their direct command.  Units are typically grouped in armies of 6 but can also travel the world map as individuals or in smaller groups to perform scouting or to pick up resources in random guarded/unguarded stashes.

You can built different combat units specific to the race your chose to play and each race has unique traits and damage types, called damage channels.  They include kinetic, thermal, biological, electrical,   and even psionic.  There are several different races to chose from such as Vanguard Starship Trooper type units, animal riding Amazon warriors in tune with creatures and forests, human/machine cyborg units called The Assembly, Kir'ko insectoids, a shady trade style guild called The Syndicate that utilizes rogue/assassin style mechanics, and some Dwarven type Dvar that specialize in planetary mining and terraforming.  I can't go into detail on each as there is so much information so do a search to read some in- depth guides or watch some videos.  There are also separate branches of secret research that every race can select that will provide additional specialized units and operations.  They include Promethean that deals in fire, Celestian that draws from a spiritual plane, Xenoplague that is all about biological weapons and plague, Psynumba which deals with psionics, Synthesis which revolves around machines, and Voidtech that bends space and time.  The combination of different races and secret technology allows for even more varied builds.  You can also pick up units from different NPC factions as you complete missions, or clear resource stashes.

Combat is played out on tactical maps that utilize cover, line of sight (LoS) and range.  Each side in the battle consisting of players, NPCs, or random marauders, can bring stacks of units in different armies, that will each take turns moving or using abilities.  There are ground and flying units that specialize in various ranged (rifles, pistols, grenades, rockets), close combat melee, and AoE attacks and you use including researched tactical operations to assist you in the fight.  Units can take cover, repair or heal each other, summon additional units, and even resurrect fallen allies.  There are a lot of different weapons, unit mods, and abilities that can vary depending on the race and secret research chosen at the start of the game or trading with NPC factions and discovered on the strategic map.  There are coastal and ocean sectors with available naval units but these areas doesn't seem to offer as much in the way of resources and may see some changes in additional DLC or patches.

As with other 4X games, there are different ways to win a game, from diplomacy, exploration, or absolute domination.   The game includes several campaigns you can play through and a random map generator to play skirmish style with AI or human players.   Advanced map generation allows you to adjust a huge variety of options to suit your play style.

AofW Planetfall is my all time favorite game (replacing AofW III which is now my 2nd all time favorite game).  

I like how the developers took a lot of the basic key elements of exploration, empire building and detailed tactical battles from AofW III and built a game in a new environment, with new races and a significantly advanced and enhanced gameplay.  The developers added an incredible amount of depth and creativity to the game.  Unfortunately more depth normally means a game that is much harder to play.  To minimize this the developers put considerable effort into making the actual gameplay easy and enjoyable.  For instance in the tactical battles there are many choices available when one unit is attacking one or multiple other units.  The game uses color and numerical indicators to show the range, potential damage and odds of a hit.  In addition, instead just a "hit" or "miss", a lesser "graze" damage is employed as well.  So even when going against a well entrenched, high defense unit send enough hurt its way and even with lower odds that unit will eventually meet its demise.  

It is true, when I first started playing the game it was a challenge to learn the tremendous depth and complexity the game offers but I actually enjoyed discovering the numerous different ways and choices that are available at all phases of the game.  These strategic and tactical choices are one of the key things that keeps me playing.  Like AofW III there is a great modding community with support from the developers to keep the game fresh.  The game has a customizable random map generator with up to 12 players in addition to multiple NPC factions with their own peculiarities.  Each of the available races have a different feel and though the races to me are pretty well balanced the play strategies vary in order to take advantage of the race differences.  The heroes can equip items and gain selectable abilities.  In addition in Planetfall each regular unit can receive items that are available if you have the right resources.  There are also interesting side quests that require a hero.

The above are just a few of the reasons why AofW Planetfall is now my all time favorite game.  So if you like turn-based strategy at its finest, to me AofW Planetfall is it.

I picked this up on sale for the $45 Premium Edition, and wound up spending just over two hours making it through setup, tutorial, and through the first mission or two of a campaign.  I kinda wanted to refund, but had crossed steams threshold, so I carried on a bit to see if it would grow on me.

What I wanted in a game was a new and interesting spiritual successor to Xcom.  This game offers a micro-game of tactical combat in that fashion, but it's a far cry from the immersion and intricacy of the Xcom series.  This game also offers a macro-game similar to a Civilization Hex-map 4x game...but with an order of magnitude more complexity in resources, settlement/city-building, and encounters.

I personally found this to be the worst of both worlds regarding Tactical Turn-based strategy and 4x.   The tactics were pretty blunt and un-synergistic in combat (I found myself thinking after a half dozen battles "I don't see how my control is any better or even any different than what auto-play would be doing"), while the 4x was overburdened by some dozen resources to manage and deep-but-narrow options at the strategic level (I found myself thinking of the skill tree "Okay, i have two options, and they're not mutually exclusive...so I guess I just click the next one in line").

Regarding backstory, I'm not usually one to care about dialogue and campaign, preferring to just get to the action and execution of things, but the story behind this seemed particularly cheesy B-sci-fi movie that they let the intern write up, and did not help my engagement with the game at all.

Things got worse as I progressed through campaign, having several heroes leading armies that I didn't really have time to put my heart into learning about, as it's been 5 hours and I kinda just want to not be playing this anymore.  Admittedly, I could just be a cruddy strategic commander, so mileage may vary.


All that being said, I *can* tell that a lot of effort and heart went into creating this game,and I don't think it's anything like a terrible game in and of itself.  It's got good visuals and a seemingly sound engine underneath the hood.

I would sincerely believe someone that does love and enjoy playing this game.  It just definitely does not scratch any of the itches I had, and I'd ultimately rather just boot up either Civ or Xcom that do each of these things better.

Disclaimer: This review is mostly relevant if A) You've played AoW3, and B) You play this game in single player.

If you haven't played AoW3, I suggest you start there, as it's a better introduction to the series, in my opinion, having simpler and more straightforward game mechanics. I would go so far as to say that I do not recommend this game to anyone who hadn't played AoW3, or to anyone who'd played it and didn't like it.

[strike]For those of you who have played and liked AoW3, I [i]would[/i] recommend AoW:P. It's similar enough that you should be able to get comfortable with it fairly quickly, yet different enough to give you a new experience.[/strike]

For more details, let me give you a quick rundown of the main differences between AoW3 and AoW:P:

Cities vs. Colonies:
In AoW3 you had cities that could collect resources from resource-generating nodes within their domain, with the domain gradually expanding outward as the city's population grew. The idea back then was to found a city with as many resource nodes within a 3 hex radius to maximize the city's economic bonuses.
In AoW:P, the map in divided into a sort patchwork grid of sectors. Instead of picking any hex on the map to found your colony, you instead found it on one of these sectors. As the colony grows, instead of having a domain around it which grows outward, you get to claim one of the adjacent sectors to the colony to exploit, up to a maximum of 4, and up to a distance of 2 sectors (i.e. up to the sectors next to the sectors next to the colony). The resources and bonuses you get from the exploited sectors depend on two things: 1. Resource nodes in the sector. 2. The type of exploitation you build on the sector, combined with the sector's terrain features. You can choose between 4 exploitation types, with a max of 2 of each type per colony: agriculture, production, energy (gold), and research. You can then upgrade the sector's exploitation by one level for each exploitation tier of that type you research (up to max of 2) and for each terrain feature compatible with the exploitation type you chose (e.g. "Fertile Plains" and "Forest" terrain features are compatible with the agriculture exploitation type) up to a maximum of level 5. The strategy here is to found your colonies near sectors with lots of exploitable terrain features that will allow you to maximally upgrade as few exploitation types as possible, as every upgrade to an exploitation type takes time to build, so you don't want to have to build too many. The idea here is to have every colony specialize in 2, or, at most, 3 exploitation types.
As you can tell by the difference in text length it takes to explain the two systems, AoW:P's colony system is not as intuitive or simple as AoW3's domain system, but you'll get the hang of it eventually.

Races and classes / factions and secret techs:
If there is anything in AoW:P that I can point to as being a significant improvement over AoW3, it's the factions, AoW:P's version of AoW3's races. Unlike in AoW3, where every race was nearly identical to the rest, with nearly the same unit structure (skirmisher, infantry, ranger, cavalry, mage, etc.) varying only in nominal stat/ability differences, AoW:P's factions are radically different from one another. While they all follow nearly the same unit tier and class system, the difference in functionality between each unit makes it so there is very little overlap between units across factions.
AoW3's classes are replaced in AoW:P with "secret techs", which function pretty much the same way, giving you a few secret tech units, operations (magic), and mods.

Mods:
Speaking of mods, AoW:P allows you to equip not only your heroes, but your units too. The effects of these mods can range from a few passive stat boosts/augments to major changes (e.g. more damage, more armor, increased evasion, changed damage type, HP regeneration, new abilities, increased attack range, giving attacks AOE, giving attacks new status effects, etc.). With the right combination of mods, even a tier 1 unit can become a force to be reckoned with. The trick is that, aside from energy, AoW:P's basic "money" resource, they also cost "Cosmite", AoW:P's secondary resource, which is much harder to come by, and is used to build your more powerful tier 3 and 4 units, so you can't go hog-wild and mod all your units up the wazoo, no matter how high your energy income is.

Neutral factions:
AoW:P introduces another new feature: neutral factions. These are non-player factions that control a few sectors and numerous resource nodes on the map, that you can trade with using "Influence", another new resource, to get unique units, mods, and doctrines (operations that give you passive bonuses), or to politely ask them to vacate a resource node they're protecting. They will also occasionally give you mini quests that, if completed, improve your relationship with them and grant you a cache of resources (and sometimes a piece of equipment and/or a faction unit). The better your relationship with the faction, the cheaper it becomes to buy from them, and the more powerful units and items become available for purchase.
Alternatively, you can decide you don't want to be friendly with a neutral faction, and go to war with them instead. This will allow you to claim their sectors and nodes by force, and give you a resource bonus for killing their units.

AI:
Now, if there is something I can point to in AoW:P as its weakness, it would be the AI. The AI in AoW:P is absolutely incompetent. Even on the highest difficulty level, in which the AI gets massive resource bonuses (i.e. cheats), I don't find winning especially difficult.
Its strategic decision-making is highly questionable. It's needlessly belligerent towards its neighbors, randomly declares war on half the other players, then gets scared and hunkers down, and later asks for peace even when it's not advantageous for it to do so. I've been consistently able to win by means of the "Doomsday" victory condition, in which you need to build 3 super-weapon buildings, initiate the doomsday operation, and protect them for 10 turns. While doing this will make all AI's not aligned with you to declare war on you, it won't make them stop fighting among themselves long enough to stop you.
In combat, its behavior is absolutely moronic.
In AoW3, because a large part of the units were melee, and even most ranged units had penalties for attacking from max range, most battles were about closing in and trying to surround and outflank the enemy, which the AI was OK at.
In AoW:P, most units are ranged, and aside from more accuracy, there's generally little point in moving your units in for a close-quarters brawl. The AI seems to have a hard time wrapping its "head" around this concept, and will often charge in to use its units more potent abilities, letting you set up lethal kill-boxes on favorable terrain and catch them in a cross-fire. This is especially bad in colony attacks, where the AI's units will run head-long into your colony's defensive towers. Beside that, the AI doesn't try to create a unified "front" with its units to maximize damage output, and never groups up its army stacks in open field battle, letting you pick off its units one group at a time. Furthermore, in battles the AI is guaranteed to win (e.g. 4-to-1 force advantage in the open), it makes no effort to preserve its units, taking unnecessary damage and losses. Because of the AI's tactical weakness, I've been able to crush its armies even in battles where I was in a significant force disadvantage.

Edit (05/12/2020):
I've stopped playing the game since March of this year because of severe issues with the AI. The devs have made no progress in noticeably improving it since that time. Given this, I can not recommend this game.

Just play AoW3 instead.

63520224.review:
Age of Wonders III, the previous entry before Planetfall, now resides permanently in my pantheon of favorites, somewhere between Master of Orion II and King’s Bounty The Legend. Now Planetfall has come on the scene, promising deeper, more rewarding gameplay and a richer story, untethered to the clichés of the fantasy genre. Although it’s pleased enough Steam users to garner mostly positive reviews, I don’t think Planetfall is worth the current asking price of US$50, so it’s a Not Recommended from me. I currently have over 400 hours played and about half the achievements, including the coveted “Wololo,” which is held by only 0.6% of players.

The formula of light 4X coupled with turn-based tactical battles worked like a charm in AOW3. Planetfall tinkers with this formula, placing greater emphasis on city building and associated management tasks. Gameplay feels much closer to modern incarnations of the Civilization franchise than to the familiar Heroes of Might and Magic / Civ hybrid from earlier AOW games. The attractive spell books have been replaced with massive tech trees that require constant vertical scrolling, and mostly-unbearable spoken quotes before each tech advancement. AOW3’s map zoomed out to show a picturesque storybook map. Planetfall’s is a dog’s dinner of inkblot-shaped “sectors” festooned with resource icons (just grab any sector with Cosmite, since you’ll be starved for Cosmite from turn one until you quit playing). The complexity of the sector system can be confusing for new players, and Triumph’s policy of constant tinkering means even seasoned players of the game won’t always know how sectors work after the latest patch. As of this writing, an upcoming update promises to divide the map icons up into three different versions, navigated by tabs.

And I miss the Book of Wonders. Searching the Imperial Archives just feels like Google.

You’ll start off your city with structures like the central science lab and recreational dome, but soon enough you find yourself constructing abstract concepts like “Energy Sectors Upgrade” and “Agriculture Exploitation.” You’re spammed with insignificant notifications like “X has insulted my kingdom!” New metrics like Popular Support, Reputation, Alert Level and Casus Belli are thrown into the mix with familiar metrics like Race Relations, Morale, etc., resulting in a fog of statistical gibberish.

Like the silly feature that lets you move each citizen of your city into different occupations, some of Planetfall’s micromanagement can be automated and ignored, but doing so will lead to suboptimal results and might potentially lose the game for you.

This franchise really deserves a game with a coherent UI, but Planetfall’s is catastrophic. Picking new attributes when a hero levels up in AOW3 was an absolute mess of tiny scrolling text, but Planetfall’s method is identical, only the text is larger and they used a futuristic font.

What about that storyline? Well, you’re in the future, where some pan-galactic apocalypse has reduced everything to rubble, so everyone stands around inside ruined buildings on different planets, waiting for you to show up so they can start shooting.

There’s apparently only one gender in the future. Let’s refer to them as “space maureens.” They have broad shoulders, muscular limbs and lean, masculine faces. Some are voiced by female actors, perhaps for diversity’s sake. 

I’m not one for graphics, but these character animations just don’t make it look like a US$50 game. Defeated units tip over like a domino. The copious amounts of voice acting sound under-rehearsed and stilted. The one exception to this is the actor who narrates the tech advancements for the Syndicate, who sounds like Jon Irenicus. The musical score is generally excellent, my favorite track is the battle music that sounds like an Abba pop song.

Now, on to the best part of all the Age of Wonders games, the combat. Planetfall brings some needed improvements (like displaying which enemies can be hit before you advance your ranged units), but it also streamlines and discards some really enjoyable elements from the previous game (like cutting the number of items your heroes can carry from 8 to a maximum of 6).

In an attempt to wean players away from spamming endless tier 3 units, Planetfall gives us some tier 1 units that can be improved throughout the game with progressively more powerful mods. Not sure what they’ll do to stop us from spamming tier 1’s now, but no doubt there’s something around the corner.

Hero vehicles are an interesting idea, but they require too much advance planning and don’t really feel like a big step up. And why does the hero portrait change to the vehicle itself?

You can’t charm enemy heroes any more, a feature that I loved in the previous game. In one of my Planetfall games, a mind-controlled enemy hero reverted back to the enemy’s side after the battle!

Fighting to a stalemate was always a long and tedious affair – necessary when one of your scouts get ambushed – but now the process is more boring since it takes 6 rounds of battle instead of 5.

The damn camera won’t stay still! Every time I move a unit, it shifts a little bit. I’m constantly zooming and rotating to get a good view of the battle.

It’s difficult to know where the edge of some combat maps are, until you’ve bumped up against them.

A prerecorded “damnit!” clip from Jack Gelder plays to inform you of your reaction to the death of your unit. Actually, I think these clips are included because it’s so difficult to tell if a unit is dead or alive sometimes.

Flying units are a great addition, I love how they integrate their abilities with ground troops, but it’s agonizing to move them around. Everyone at Triumph should take a week off, shut off their internet and figure out how flying units can be moved. It’s the only way, guys.

How is the campaign? I’m not sure how they did it, but they took all these cataclysmic events and made them really boring. Somehow, the story of the Vanguard waking up from centuries of sleep to discover that their galactic empire has collapsed, was a yawn. The Kirkos’ quest for their original homeworld is the only campaign that hit any dramatic chords. The Revelations campaign rehashes a lot of ideas from the main campaign – the planet is covered with network nodes and you must find them all while the Autonom shoot lasers at you. 

https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/767224654521522556/8F8121149C8AFC506DF840648309B7A4D1EB6CF4/

In summary, Planetfall’s good, but not as good as AOW3. If you like Civ style micromanagement, Planetfall’s been patched to let you skip the battles and automate exploration, so you can dive right in. If you want to play Age of Wonders, maybe wait on this purchase and see how the game develops in future expansions.

Hopefully, I’ll be able to one day return to this review with a more positive recommendation. We'll see how the expansions go.

This is a good first attempt.  I'm looking forward to the sequel.

I've not come across any bugs.  The races and tech trees are interesting.  The combat is fun.  However, they made some design decisions that I find extremely frustrating.  They've also failed to provide clear, concise, and easily accessible information about your cities.

I've spent most of my time playing the campaign.  It feels like a minimum viable product.  For reference I'm comparing this game to X-com 1 and 2, the Total War games, Battletech, and Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.  

My biggest problem is with the tech tree and player choice.  If you capture a city that belongs to another race you get access to some of that race's technology.  You're able to research it yourself.  However, you only get access to some of it.  If their race uses different damage channels than you, you will not be able to research the appropriate tech, meaning that even though you can research and build their units, they will always be weak.  The result is that you cannot effectively field mixed armies.

There are also buildings that are in the society tree that you will never be able to build.  The first one that comes to mind is the Vanguard training building that gives 3xp per turn to any unit in the city.

They seem to have restricted the tech you get access to maintain the distinctiveness of each race.  I found this to be extremely annoying.  The factions in Alpha Centari all had their own unique quirks separate from the tech tree.  Here, everything seems to be dependent on it.

It seems to me it would be very easy for them to fix this, but because it appears to be a conscious design decision I doubt that they will.

In the campaign you do not carry your researched tech from world to world, and you often abandon one secret tech for another.  It makes sense to add a new secret tech between missions.  However, that's not what happens.

I also found the way cities are done to be overly restricted.  Each city can have 4 sectors (6 or 8 with mods), however you can only have 2 of any individual kind of sector, including ocean sectors.   The result is that ocean bases are not viable and you are not able to maximize the output of your cities.  It seemed like the game was cockblocking everything I wanted to do.

Compare that to Alpha Centari, where I felt free to do whatever I wanted, including hitting cities with nerve gas or black hole bombs that would blow massive holes in continents.

The tactical battles also need to be improved.  The first thing I would do is give the player the ability to deploy their units, just like you can in the Total War games.  I'd also increase the number of units you can have in one stack.  Six is extremely restrictive and limits your ability to engage in combined arms operations.

If they wanted to get really crazy they could abandon the flat map and use a sphere like in Planetary Annihilation and Phoenix Point.  Planetary Annihilation also has many maps with multiple worlds in the same system, with combat happening across the whole system.  Implementing that kind of a system in this game would set it apart from anything else in the space.

In summary, I'm excited for a sequel that gives unrestricted access to the tech tree (some gated behind, capturing enemy cities, reverse engineering destroyed units, map quests), improved tactical battles (choose your own deployment and more units), spherical world maps, and multiworld systems.  If they fix it, so the game stops cockblocking players it will be fun and I'll change my this to recommend.  But again, these seem to be conscious design decisions.  It seems unlikely to happen. 

It would also be nice if they implemented a skirmish mode, where you could pick a map and units.  Then just have a tactical battle without having to play the campaign.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
[i]Age of Wonders: Planetfall[/i] is a turn-based 4X game, made by [i]Triumph Studios[/i], set in a sci-fi setting. I expected a good strategic experience, but all I got was a dull story, bland gameplay, inferior AI, generic art design, and technical problems. 

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list][*]The game offers quite a lot of units for each race, letting you do various army compositions. They are also very distinctive in their design and have a few gameplay differences. 
[*]You can customize units and heroes with modifications increasing their overall statistics and adding other special abilities.
[*]The option to play battles manually adds much more fun to this genre.
[*]You can customize your commanders' appearance.[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list][*]The story campaign is nothing but a skirmish mode with specific missions and awful storytelling.
[*]In my experience, the AI acts stupidly and erroneously, especially on the world’s map. It is better in the battles, but nothing extraordinary. 
[*]I could not immerse myself in this sci-fi universe because the design of races and units is generic, uninteresting, and grotesque. The same applies to story, lore, and dialogues. 
[*]There are a few questionable design decisions that deteriorate the gameplay experience on the world’s map. 
[*]I had a problem with launching the game on Steam at first, which I had to repair by myself as the developers' advice was useless. Although it works now, every function that Steam offers (achievements, trading cards, Steam cloud) do not work for me. 
[*]I experienced a lot of frame drops, both on the world’s map and during the combat. It is irritating even for a turn-based game. 
[*]Not the developer's fault, but I do not see a point in having the Paradox Launcher.[/list] 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay divides into two major parts: the world’s map and battles. Your main goal is the same as in every other 4X game: eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate. 

[b]The world’s map[/b] 

You choose from six different races with unique designs, units, and gameplay elements. As it is custom, maps are procedurally generated, even in the campaign. You start the game with a small army and a city, where you construct buildings and upgrades for your sector. Sectors divide the whole map. They always have a specific place where you can build a base or a city. 

Sectors also provide resources, such as energy, cosmite, food, knowledge, and production.

This whole system feels simplified because you do not build anything on the tiles as in the [i]Civilization[/i] series. You have no freedom in choosing a spot for a city. After a while, it is just a boring routine which you have to do. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1978713226
You interact with other civilizations which usually lead to a war that you want anyway because battles are the biggest strength of this game. The diplomacy system is almost the same as in the [i]Civilization[/i] series, and the AI has abnormally weird reasons to hate you. They often come up with “excellent” tactical plans when you are at war, such as: attacking your city with a small group of units or dividing their forces so you can get them one by one.

There are also smaller AI factions that do not expand. They have an addiction that forces them to send you the very same quest requests over and over again. To stop their spamming, you need to destroy them. It is a test of patience as they attack you themselves after you reject them many times.

The campaign offers two missions for each race, and there is no reason to play it. It is just a limited skirmish with dull dialogues that pauses your game every single time. The writing is substandard even for strategy games. The skirmish mode is much more enjoyable as there is an absence of dialogues and you can customize the game with various settings.

[b]Battles[/b]

The battles are turn-based, as in the [i]XCOM[/i] series. Each army has six unit slots which you fill however you want. Units have ranged or melee attacks, and also special abilities which are different for every faction. For example, Vanguard faction soldiers throw grenades, their robots use smokes for cover or heal allied units. The Psi-Fish faction I fought a lot uses hypnotic powers that take off the control of your units. 

The units have up to three modifications slots. Modifications increase the stats of the units and add special abilities. For the mentioned Vanguard soldiers, you can increase their overall range and accuracy and ignoring the cover bonuses. 

Units are distinguished into types and tiers. The unit type adds resistance and sensitivity to a certain damage type. There are unit types like biological, mineral, etc. There are four tiers. The higher tier units are stronger but costlier. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1978713639
You lead an army with a hero who is fully customizable. You can change their weapons and as they level up, you choose perks and other special abilities. Unfortunately, the perks are mostly about a higher percentage of health, accuracy, defense, etc. The metioned modifications can be used on heroes, as well.

There are special faction abilities you need to research first. They allow you to use barrages, lasers, heals, and other useful things on the battlefield. The battlefields’ cover is destructible, and there are often explosives you can use to your advantage. 

I found the battles to be the most enjoyable part, as the AI is adequate and the diverse units, abilities, and modifications make it more interesting, and variable. 

[h1]Graphics, design, and soundtrack[/h1]
I find the graphics underwhelming, even on the highest settings, for a 2019 game. The same unfortunately applies to the soundtrack. I honestly remember slightly just one composition. 

On the other hand, graphics for me are secondary to design. Unfortunately, the designs of races, units, and the world overall are way too generic and uninteresting. There are some exceptions, but overall it is just a big mess. That is subjective, sure, but if the game fails to immerse me into the sci-fi universe, then there is something wrong with it. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1978714015
[h1]Game’s performance[/h1]
The game was tested on [b]i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, 8GB RAM, and an SSD[/b]. I had several frame drops, both on the world’s map and in the battles. I locked the game on 60 frames and the drops in the worst cases went to 20-30 frames. These drops were random, and I have not found the source of them. I have not had such inconsistent framerates with other big releases this year.

I also could not launch the game at first through Steam. I found out that I did not have the executable files required for starting the game. I unsuccessfully tried every advice from developers. I found a solution by downloading the game via the Paradox Launcher and playing it there. But as I had to write a review, I had to find a way to play it on Steam. I will leave a guide in the comments.

With that comes the aligned problem, that the game does not register Steam achievements, trading cards, or cloud.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[i]Age of Wonders: Planetfall[/i] is not the worst strategy game out there. It offers quite a lot of content and replayability. However, I cannot recommend it for all its faults and problems I had. Even if I was to look past the technical issues I experienced, I still could not think of a single reason why I would recommend this game over any other series, such as [i]Civilization, Total War, XCOM[/i], and others. I would wait for a huge sale to buy this game, as I think the price of 50€ is not adequate.

I loved Age of Wonders III and can tell it'll be more of the same but with a sci-fi angle.  I do prefer the battles much more in Planetfall however; mostly because of the cover system.  It's almost like an X-Com type of battle system with half cover and full cover.

Fun science fantasy 4X game that creates a vivid setting Thankfully it doesn't cling too tightly to pre-existing tropes from franchises like 40k. Instead of orcs there are psionic bugmen that had their Queens genetically lobotomized by sack-bleeders (humans.) Instead of elves there's a faction of all female genetically modified eco-terrorists. Space dwarves are Russian steampunk interstellar mining consortiums. The Vanguard are archetypal human military forces, while the Syndicate feel as if they took a lot of inspiration from the XCOM franchise itself as they are psionic merchant guilds of blue man group that enslave their subordinates.

Other than your race you also choose a Secret Tech which is essentially a character class. Instead of Warrior, Mage, Necromancer, etc. you choose from things like: Promethean, ancient technology that exists solely to PURGE IT IN FLAME. Xenoplague, a biological weapon that grows as you kill units afflicted with a parasitic infection. Synthesis, which allows you to utilize "Daemon" AI programs. The final two are Celestial and Psynumbra which are the Light and Dark side of psionics respectively. (There's also the Heritor Secret Tech from the Revelations DLC but I haven't played that just yet.)

Speaking of XCOM, Planetfall has about as much in common with those games as it does with Civilization. The strategic map is more or less parallel to the XCOM Geoscape and the game creates small tactical maps for your units to fight in when combat is initiated.

Engaging gameplay, fun setting, good worldbuilding, and a long campaign with choices that affect later missions. Check it out if any of that sounds appealing.

60106063.review:
[b]Important Note[/b]: you should be aware that Paradox as a publisher doesn't deserve your support, given the way they completely wrecked Magicka 1 with bad patches and a legally questionable change in multiplayer DLC policy, after the Arrowhead developers left. They have abandoned the game now, and haven't even bothered to provide rollback betas, forcing players to go through a grueling manual process to play the older versions without the crashes.

--

This said, I love the developer Triumph Games, so I'm going to evaluate the game on its own merit.

Great strategy game. If you've never played the Age of Wonders series, they are 4X games with a focus on strategic and tactical combat, aided by spells (or in this game, operations) that you can cast directly on the tactical or strategic map within your zone of influence. Tactical combat is deep (and got deeper since AOW3 with the addition of flanking and other mechanics) and excellent, and there's a big focus on leveling up and equipping your units.

Every game in the series is also notable for being great to play in coop multiplayer (random maps, not the campaign) because turns are simultaneous, which works perfect when you're working together and want to wait for each other as little as possible. Manual battles can slow things down unless you enforce autocombat at all times, but this title introduces an optional allotment of "battle cards" which makes manual combat a limited-availability item you want to use wisely. 

I was initially skeptical about Triumph making a Sci-Fi title, but they did an amazing job at making each faction feel fleshed out, with interesting lore that is well integrated into the campaign. Some races are downright terrifying, but at the same time everything is treated with a light humorous tone which I really appreciate. The Campaign is well-narrated with interesting characters you grow to like, and there are mutually exclusive choices to make, that can even affect future missions. One very nice touch when you get a quest is that the game tells you whether you can accomplish it by sending scouts, or if you actually need to bring an army - it saves you from awkward moments and wasted time.

The graphics really deserve a mention. Both the world map and the various tactical maps are absolutely gorgeous, and represent a big improvement over the previous installment - this is the best an Age of Wonders game has ever looked in terms of assets quality, though I still have a soft spot for the treasure map-like pixel art dreamscapes of AOW I/II/Shadow Magic. Animations are not up to the same level of quality, but by 4X game standards, they're pretty good.

Of particular note are the minor factions, that don't act like a player but rather give you quests and make demands to gain favor with them. Not only do they have a lot of flavour and personality, they also have rivalries with other minor factions and will try to make you pick sides. They're like a way more fun version of city-states in Civ V/VI. Gain enough favor and you can purchase their units and unique items, or even annex their sectors, by spending precious influence points.

Another element that's a bit Civ-like is the tech trees: gone are the randomized research options from all past games. Even unlocking faction units is now done through the tech tree, as opposed to simply building a sequence of buildings in a city. This makes it easier to pursue a specific strategy, but as someone who tends to suffer from analysis paralysis, I found the randomized research options in past titles liberating due to the limited amount of choices.

The economy is well-conceived and well-balanced, you'll never feel like you have too much of the various resources, forcing you to make choices every step of the way.

A rather large difference compared to past titles is that the map is pre-divided into randomly named sectors which you can annex to your cities as they grow, or build forward military outposts on. I think it's a good mechanic gameplay-wise, and just like the auto-expanding city domains in AOW3, it removes the need to "walk" on every resource-producing structure to capture it like you had to do in older AOW or HOMM games. However it detracts quite a bit from the "organic" and "treasure map" aspect of past titles, and I dare to say that some of the "Wonder" in Age of Wonders is gone. The fact that you most often colonize rather than rely on capturing neutral cities of various races doesn't feel as fun, either - I find building settlers boring in Civ and it's even more boring here, contrasted with the overall focus on military power.

Maps are still very big and missions rather long, though definitely not as much as the monster campaign missions in AOWII. There's no underworld or parallel dimension, at least so far - makes it easier to see everything at a glance, but reduces the feeling of adventure a bit.

Some flavor was perhaps lost compared to titles like AOW due to terraforming being a lot less common, and so far the absence of spel... sorry, operations, that place obstacles (poison plants, ...) on the map. It made you feel pretty powerful.

A bigger loss is certainly that scouting the map and picking up various resources is now rather boring (they did introduce auto-explore post-launch). Except the very rare occasional random event, you have three types of stashes to pick up with always the same flavour text. You also don't really get little nooks and crannies that feel very hand-designed and fun to explore, like the small underground or very thematic areas of past games. That's the cost of playing on a larger scale and on procedurally generated instead of hand-made maps I suppose - what we gain in replayability, we lose in character and detail. There's still the thrill of discovering which factions are on the map in campaign missions, thankfully, but I don't find myself looking forward to what cool areas of the map I'll be able to find, like I used to do in AOWII and Shadow Magic.

Nitpicks:
- The zoom when you get a quest is very annoying. Missions are often timed but this view prevents you from seeing what units you have nearby to evaluate if you can complete the quest, and you can't close the screen and come back to it - only way to close it is by accepting or refusing.
- The campaign tends to shove very important decisions in your face which you have to make on the spot - no way to save or look at the map beforehand.
- When you have a lot of colonies and mostly winning, picking what to build tends to become samey and tedious. Some optional auto-management of colonies would be appreciated.
- Unless I missed some subtle color-coding or other non-obvious hint, tactical combat doesn't do a great job at helping you evaluate which enemies you'll be able to reach with secondary abilities if you move to a given hex. Having to count hexes manually is pretty annoying.
- If I understand correctly, there are no hand-made skirmish maps? If so this is a big loss compared to past games, having random maps is great for long-term replayability, but sometimes you just want to play on something nicely hand-designed. Hopefully the community were given the means to plug this gap.

Overall though, this is a fascinating, deep and addictive game, which will take you dozens of hours just to explore all aspects of the economic and military systems, and way more to master them and find your favorite strategies. And beyond that you have simultaneous multiplayer, for great games in coop with very little downtime.

========EDIT==========

After spending more time with the game, here's an actual review:

First of all, I really don't like it when people compare this game to 4X games. I guess technically it is, but it's closer in style to Fantasy General, HoMM, or in fact the previous Age of Wonders games. It's a tactical wargame first and foremost, with a strategic side added on top. That's not a bad thing, just don't expect Civilization: Beyond Earth or Alpha Centauri.

The game takes place in a Fantasy/Sci-Fi setting, somewhat reminiscent of the Warhammer 40K universe, just much, MUCH less grimdark. After the fall of the Star Union, a Universe-spanning empire of humans, the remnants are left to be picked up by several warring factions, ranging from expeditionary forces of the old Union, through Merchant Houses from Dune, Space Dwarves, Borg wannabes to insectoid aliens. The setting is filled with familiar tropes, which helps to quickly get familiar with the different factions.

The core gameplay focuses on tactical battles (this time I have to express my displeasure for comparisons to X-com. The battles are turn-based, and some units have ranged overwatch. That's it for X-com similarities). The fights are brutal, are focused around exploiting unit weaknesses and synergies. The base game has 5 damage types and three (technically four, but one is not listed on the character sheet - Triumph, please show the dodge chance a unit has, ok?) types of defenses which a player must learn to recognize and know how to use to be successful. Each unit has a special ability (most actually have two), there are heroes who function as army leaders or really powerful units. You also have tactical operations to use in battle, which function like spells from previous entries, and strategic operations to hinder your enemies or benefit your armies and cities on the world map. And TBH, that's a very brief summary of the intricacies of the war mechanic of this game and I'm sure I've missed a key feature or two.

A key new addition to the series, and one of my favorite features, is unit modding. Each unit and hero has three slots for special mods gained through research, from allied NPC factions or (in the case of heroes) found through exploring. They can be as simple as a stat boost, to change how a unit's ability works or giving the unit a new ability entirely. It's a lot of fun trying out different combinations, or experimenting with combinations you haven't tried yet.

There is also research, city management, diplomacy, questing, and ruin explorations but while important, it is very simple actually, and quite standard for most strategy games nowadays. Generally speaking, if you enjoy playing as a warmonger in other strategy games, then this game is for you as warmongering is the default. And although there is a 'Pacifist' and Scientific victory condition, you will get into a lot of battles simply through exploring and questing. 

Finally the Audio-Visual design. The music is very subdued, even during fights, but enjoyable none the less. The battle sounds are serviceable, but no unit VO except for simple grunts. The voice acting in the cutscenes, the quotes after you finish a research project, or your advisors are hit and miss: some are fine (I especially enjoy the Insectoid Kir'ko) but some are dreadful (the Vanguard humans have it the worst I think). Graphics are clear and colorful, but some animations are prone to bugging out or are poorly synced with the sounds. Not the prettiest game, but at least you can turn on very fast animations, so you'll miss most of the bugs and the battles are faced paced.

All in all a great game. Highly recommended. Plus, the developers are clearly passionate about it and are constantly supporting it with DLC and patches, that do more than just fix simple glitches.
