59214861.review:
Long time Age of Wonders player, from AoW1 back in the early 2000s to now with Planetfall.

I'm doing a current playthrough with Vanguard. I never thought they would be my faction of choice, I usually gravitate to more melee focused tanky factions. However, theres something about creating fire lanes and overlapping arcs of fire that takes me back to when I was in the army. The full novelty of this is using those same modern day tactics, then adapting them to combat strange alien life forms who have unusual abilities.

The ability to "mod" units fixes a problem that older AoW games had, being that low tier units would be wiped out easily by higher tier units. With mods, even a lowly infantry unit can turn into something greater with the right loadout. Of course, your enemy can do the same thing, creating an arms race where you adapt your loadouts based on what enemies you fight.

I found the new map and sector system a bit jarring at first, very different to the old style of strategic gameplay, however after a few hours I feel like it suits the new setting well. I will say the map's geography don't seem to "flow" as naturally as they did in AoW3 (which has one of the best random map generators I've ever seen IMO). It definitely looks nice though.

I enjoy the new Landmark system as well, gives you specific areas to aim for when expanding. Some of the designs look really nice too.

Tactical combat is amazing as always. This time around a lot more emphasis on cover, creating fire lanes, arcs of fire, tactical movement and ranged combat. Melee still exists but it isn't the focus like it was with previous games. Operations give combat a nice edge to it too, the air strikes and such remind me of the old pc game "World in Conflict" where you would launch strikes on locations to tip the balance of skirmishes around the map.

Overall excellent game, I'll definitely be racking up the hours with this. A must for any Age of Wonders fan.

A worthy successor to the fantasy Age of Wonders games. The new mechanics take a bit to get used to if you're a series veteran but are easy to pick up for newcomers and the races and technologies are a nice "best of" of sci-fi tropes.

Visually, the game is pretty damn good for a turn-based strategy game, with reasonably detailed unit models and gorgeous environments. Sound-wise...it's Triumph, so the music being amazing was pretty much a given, and while some recurring voice messages can be a bit grating ("Happiness event in colony" x500 :P) that's a fairly minor issue and can be remedied with some settings changes. 

If the game has a weak spot it's the narrative of the story campaigns, which frequently leave the player in the dark with very limited and often contradictory exposition, expecting them to make decisions based on information their characters have but which was never communicated to the actual [i]player[/i]. The actual campaign maps are fun to play through...it's just the writing that is less than stellar.

The real meat of the game, though, is in its random scenarios, and there's a ton of ways to customize the perfect planet to settle/exploit/turn into a burned-out husk for fun and profit. Definitely very replayable.

In short, one of the finest TBS games out there right now. Beware the dreaded "One more turn!" effect.

Excellent 4X turn-based strategy, one of my all-time favorites. All aspects of gameplay: from expansion and strategic decision to combat is very well polished.

When it comes to variety, Planetfall has six main factions, which you are allowed to customize further through specializing in one of several secret technologies.

Planetfall also gives you ability to choose your leader’s gender and appearance. Character customization is, admittedly, very basic by RPG standards, but it is still more than nearly every other strategy game offers.

Planetfall also has light RPG elements: your leader and heroes you hire level-up and you can pick abilities for them. Here is where I feel Planetfall falls a little short comparing to other strategy/RPG hybrids. The list of abilities is fairly limited, and best abilities are very obvious, so you will likely develop all your heroes very similarly, with slight variation based on their faction. Some extra variety will still come in form of heroes’ equipment, though, as well as need for some heroes to fill a different role, such as sniper.

I fully recommend this game to everyone who likes 4X strategies or want to give this genre a try.

58333696.review:
TL;DR It’s [i]Endless Legend[/i] with a worse strategic layer and a better tactical layer. Same as the rest of the Age of Wonders series, except with a Sci-fi theme (which I love).

Let's get to why this game is good. The battles are a lot more engaging than Endless Legend. It’s XCOM but with a large variety of aliens and factions. IE, there are aliens that resist heat, which allows you to walk over lava. There are fliers, rocks, abominations, mind controllers, pirates etc. The cover system and the flanking system both add a lot of decisions by themselves, but add overwatch, a variety of effects and you got yourself a really engaging couple of hours. The combat also allows you to SEE these factions in a way that a strategic layer just can’t provide. It’s just awesome to watch these abilities in action like a giant colossus throwing a giant meteor on your units, having to wear biohazard suits for a poisonous swamp, battling insects attacking a frontier outpost etc. It also does a decent job of tying the battles to the larger empire using “tactical operations” that make your battles seem larger than the small scale affair they are. I like being able to call down orbital laser strikes and valkyries in the middle of the battle. I just wish there was more map variety. Some of the unique maps are pretty cool tho. 

However, if you are a fan of strategy games like me, the strategic layer will leave you sorely disappointed. Like most 4X games, the beginning is shrouded in mystery, the unknown. In this game, your decisions seem relatively simple. As the mystery disappears, you should be left with with an intricate and complicated system, but I just found it to be just as simple as the beginning. It took me a while to get into the game just because how disappointed I was at the empire building aspect of it. For example, [i]Endless Legend[/i] will force you to research technologies to find new and and advanced materials, and then build mines to generate the various metals, which allows for higher tier weapons require ever higher tier materials. Here you only have one special one. EL also requires you to build buildings that changes things in the map and how your cities look, just researching the technology doesn’t do much. But here, all you need to do is grab a sector and clear a couple of baddies and that’s really it. The city building was meager affair, and I felt a simple plan of expand aggressively and grab cosmite would get me 90% of the way there.  Disappointing for an empire building strategy game.

The strategic maps are also random and not very interesting. They do the job of keeping your guys moving and trying to organize your sectors, but there is no sense of world building for me. No plate tectonics, no continents, etc.  I don’t get a lot of pleasure looking at it. I think the idea is that you barely look at the strategic layer and just get to the meat of the game: the battles. I just wish there was more.

It would be awesome if they align the strategic AI with the units themselves. IE, there is a minor faction that basically mind control your dudes. Lower units remove the ability to use weapons, higher tiers can straight up control them and lay eggs on them. It would be really interesting if they start doing that to your citizens, not just in combat, depending on how the diplomacy goes. But I think that's still far in the future. Overall, the diplomacy is a fairly simple affair with a simple influence point system to compliment and trade with factions.. It does have racial relations and various other gimmicks, but it’s pretty straightforward and doesn’t do anything more than other strategy games.

It’s an interesting game with a lot of cool things to offer. It’s definitely worth a look. If it also had a strong strategic layer, I would be much more excited. And if it could do proper large scale combat… man, it would be the best strategy game yet.

Planetfall definitely has all the good vibes from Age of Wonders III. It's difficult not to compare the two given their similarities, but in a few words - Planetfall's art may be a bit muddier and less cohesive than AoW3's, due to the mishmash sci-fi setting, but in gameplay terms Planetfall feels like an overall improvement, with more interesting NPC factions, cleaner and more manageable empire management, and just as much great tactical combat.

Overall, Planetfall is one of my favourite recent 4X games. The colourful setting is great fun to play around in, and the "one more turn" feeling is very strong with this game. The tactical combat is fun to engage in when you want to, and the auto-resolve is pretty reasonable if you want to skip tactics and focus on rampant imperialism instead. The narrative and setting are interesting, borrowing heavily from space opera and planetary romance tropes rather than the usual dry and boring hard sci-fi settings so many space games get saddled with. Customizing your faction through the twin axes of Faction and Secret Tech (both of which provide units, mods, etc) remains a solid mechanic that adds a lot of variety.

There's really only one thing I'd complain about, aside from the slightly less distinctive art style, and that's the fact that you can't fully absorb NPC factions. Even when you've maxed out your reputation with them and absorbed their territory, you still need to go get their units from them by spending influence points. I miss the way AoW3 did things, where they just became a city in your empire on-par with the others.

But aside from that? I'm having a blast!

Review at Patch: (Revelations Expansion)
Hours Clocked: 36.0

It's been 20 years since the first Age of Wonders came out, and I remember that day fondly. Sitting down and having an absolute blast with that game for hours on end. I can say the latest addition to the series has rekindled those fond memories, even if the setting has changed.

The game itself is your basic 4X game, eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate. You'll start with a single city, a hero, and a contingent of troops. If you are familiar with the genre, it is a pretty straightforward affair of what you would expect from a game in this genre. Gain resources and territory, then smash your enemies.

If this is your first 4X game, this is not a bad place to start. Each turn you'll gain resources that you can use to build improvements in your cities or produce more soldiers. Your armies will get to move and attack so many times per turn, so you will have to plan out your moves to achieve your goals. You'll also be able to conduct diplomacy and research technology.

Each city has it's own production queue, so you can focus a city on being say a massive science center, while another is churning out armies to do your bidding, while another is filling your coffers with credits to keep the whole thing moving smoothly. As your cities grow, you'll be able to annex surrounding areas, which then can be exploited to fit your city's needs. Want more food? Annex the plains that are rich with farms, etc. This not only makes city placement important for maximizing bonuses, but it also means that you can ensure you can focus on what you want.

The star of the series is the tactical battles themselves when push comes to shove. Those armies then drop onto a Tactical Map where each turn will let you move your individual units, use special abilities and the like. This plays out similar to games like XCOM, and you'll find yourself taking cover or shooting gas barrels to your advantage. With the variety of factions and technology, you'll see everything from cybernetically enhanced dinosaurs to mind controlling ghosts.

Overall recommendation is that I recommend Age of Wonders: Planetfall.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Everything you'd expect from the Age of Wonders Franchise.
    [*]Unit customization allows you to capitalize on your strengths, or your enemy's weaknesses.
    [*]Tactics actually work better than just smashing units with the highest ATK and DEF at one another.
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Minor Faction Quests get repetitive.

(Summary at the bottom if you don't want to read a book.)

Have been an AOW fan since the very beginning, and have played extensively through the years and expansions and DLC, etc.  Thousands of hours total, and Van Den Bos's music features prominently in my focus-work/writing playlists.  My wife and I are big fans.

(Note: To be clear as far as this review goes, my experiences with PF and all past AOW games are either campaign/skirmish or multiplayer allied with humans vs AI, usually 2 humans, sometimes 3 or 4.)

This review isn't for people who are concerned with the viability of late game synergies between crazy combinations of races/techs/mods or the balance nightmare that is sure to be.  I am writing this for people who, like us, were kind of on the fence about whether or not we would like this game.  This review assumes you have played one or more of the AOW franchise, or at the very least have a solid understanding of TBS games with tactical TBS combat.

I held off on this purchase because I was kind of lukewarm on the whole move to Sci-Fi thing... I love Sci-Fi, and I knew that Triumph would do a great job no matter what, but I just wasn't personally super excited about the new genre and when PF launched I wasn't in the TBS mood.  The sale, as well as the weather cooling off, and most importantly my wife pushing it (She's not a big Sci-Fi fan) saw us pick it up this weekend, and we put about 10 hours into it.

1.  The Graphics - AOW has always done a fantastic job here, not just from a raw eye-candy standpoint, but in using every tool at their disposal to really set a theme, mood, and feeling.  Planetfall is no exception.  The AOW3 engine has been upgraded significantly (or at least been cranked up to match modern computer specs) and the effects and animations are very nice.  The various races and extreme variety in locations have been expertly crafted to convey a living, breathing world filled with ancient secrets and dangers.  The static backgrounds and portraits all benefit from the new engine abilities, with lighting effects and greater clarity.  This in particular seems like a big improvement over AOW3's character stances/facial expressions/etc.

2.  The Sound - It's easy to miss this in the sea of everything else that is going on for an incredibly busy turn-based experience, but the sounds are very good.  There has always been a really impressive visceral impact in AOW games when the metal meets the meat, so to speak, and PF carries this forward into the higher-tech realm.

3.  The Music - As I mentioned before, I am a fan of the music of this entire series to the degree that I purchased the soundtracks separately.  How the music would be affected by the genre shift was really a concern, and while I was really hoping to see "Love and Death" transcend the space-time barrier along with some of the other core mechanics, I must say that the music is 100% Age of Wonders.  Van Den Bos has done a fantastic job here, you can hear a familiar underscore but the music nails the theme in a new way.  For me, in long-burn TBS games the music is vital to the experience, and for Planetfall it is certainly a high-point.


Summary of basic gameplay/changes:

1.  The core is still AOW.  
     -Combat is still AOW.  If you made the jump from AOW/SM/AOW2 to AOW3's complexity in combat, the jump from 
      AOW3 to PF is about the same.  Cover matters, most units have either a charge/leap or a ranged attack, and then all 
      the various status effects/resistances that make of the layers of the tactical onion.

     -The Overland Core (4X game if you want) is still AOW.  Play the tutorial, you know most of it already, but the colony 
     sectors/specializations are new and important, as are forward bases and militia (Militia is a fantastic change, btw, all 
     colonies/sectors/bases have an upgrade-able defense force that allows you to focus less on garrisons)

2.  The races will take some time to learn.  For Fantasy-fans, this will be one of the tougher jumps, not just because it is sci-fi, but because there are a lot of units/races that defy the standard Sci-Fi norms, or mix several together.  This is a good thing but can take some getting used ti.

3.  Mods are vital, both for your own troops as well as from a "Know Your Enemy" standpoint.  My wife got into a turn-based battle that was marked "Low Risk"... she wiped her veteran 6 stack against a modded group of 4 on a spawner.  There is a learning curve here.

4.  The handling of MP saves is awesome, but won't allow you to save scum.  You can drop in/out of a multiplayer game with ease, but there is no going back to a previous save.

All in all, this is a fine game.  AOW has a large following that has been with it for twenty years.  I expected the Goldilocks "THIS GAME ISN'T X ENOUGH" brigade to savage it with the reviews, but that has not been the case.  This is an amazing feat in this day and age, and it is due to the expertise and love with which this game was crafted.

Worth full price.

57831912.review:
This is a warning as much as a review... basically, I'd recommend this game the same way I'd recommend a coke-habit. It's DANGEROUSLY addictive, fully embodying that 'just one more turn' element that the best 4X-games have. Maybe it's just because I've never really gotten into the Age of Wonders games before, while I've been playing Civilization for so long (ever since the very first Civ-game, back on my first PC, 8-bit units and all) that I've gotten desensitized to its appeal?

Then again, there's a lot to pull you in, here, regardless. The way the campaign is laid out is particularly clever, and particularly effective at keeping you engaged. Instead of having to sit through a lengthy campaign with a specific faction, the narrative 'jumps' from faction to faction, with each 'mission' you complete unlocking new ones - and new factions to sample. And the early missions, in particularly, are short and sweet - ending before they have a chance to get stale, and leaving you hungry for more. You may have been sitting there, thinking that you're JUST going to clear this mission and then go to bed... but once you did it, oooh, look! Now you've unlocked the first mission starring the Amazon faction! And while there are two missions for each faction (three for the Vanguard, if you count the brief tutorial), each brings new things to the table. Different Secret Technology, different NPC-factions to fight or absorb, different synergies to explore...

Indeed, the way the research-trees are set up is quite ingenious all by itself, providing excellent replayability. The idea of having  'military' and 'civilian' research-trees running in parallel, saving you from having to pick between growing your armies or your infrastructure, is ingenious - and the way those trees are mixed up is even better. Your 'Military' tree, for starters, has a 'racial' segment at the top that depends on what faction you're playing, letting you research all their units and key gear... and if you absorb another race into your empire, be it through diplomacy or conquest, you get access to their racial tree as well, not only letting you field their units but also equip their gear, potentially creating very intriguing combos. Then there are two 'weapon' trees, or rather LINES, which are also racially dependent - but with a lot of overlap, with each race being able to research the two kinds of weapons they primarily use. And finally, there's the 'Secret Tech' segment, which is the most interesting - picked alongside your faction in character creation, it adds a unique twist and lots of potential synergy to your lineup. Some Race/Tech combinations are obvious, others may prove surprisingly potent despite being a poor fit on the surface. Want your Syndicate to be a bit friendlier? Pick the Celestian Secret Tech, and take your slave-driven crime-empire in a more benevolent direction!
On the civilian side, it's mostly always the same, with 'Economic' and 'Operational' tech being identical regardless of who you're playing, and providing you with all the basic tools you need for base-building and espionage. Only the top line gets mixed up, containing stuff unique to both your race AND chosen Secret Tech.

And then there's the NPC-factions! Most maps will have several, all will have one, and by doing missions for them you can gradually integrate them into your colony, getting access to THEIR unique units and gear... again creating surprising synergies. The cybernetic Assembly might benefit greatly from allying with the self-aware machines of the Autonomy, granting their own units access to the machine's potent internal networks for army-wide buffs... but the Vanguard could also find some use in fitting the Assembly's potent weapon-mods to their Laser Tanks.

Basically, every mission, every scenario, is a new experience as you combine race, tech, factions and very different environments - from resource-rich but food-poor ice-planets to vast ruined cities that offer swift technological advancement to idyllic garden-planets with lots of food but little else - and the end result is that suddenly it's Monday, and you're not sure what happened to the last couple of days. You have, perhaps, dim memories of grabbing a bag of chips from the cupboard because your stomach was growling and you wanted something you could eat while you play, but surely you must've stopped for a square meal and a nap at SOME point, right?

So remember, kids, don't do drugs, and don't play AoW: Planetfall unless you have someone around who can pull you out of it and force you to eat, sleep and bathe at regular intervals.

57810233.review:
This game very nearly got a "no" from me and I held off reviewing it for quite a while, because I was trying to decide if I wanted to recommend it or not.

Let me give you the short version, first: I am enjoying this game; mostly. But, there are so many problems with it that I know that a lot of people who buy it are going to come away from it disappointed. It is buggy, it has [i]countless[/i] misleading ability/item descriptions that tell you that things should work one way when in fact they work a completely different way, it has awkward animations that always feel stiff and cheap (unfortunately, a trademark of the Age of Wonders franchise), and worst of all... it was developed by a company that is now owned by Paradox, a studio that is [i]infamous[/i] for pushing excessive, overpriced DLCs for half finished games while they completely ignore bugs and broken content for [i]months[/i] or even [i]years[/i] after release. Yet, here I am, with a three digit play time, buying those DLCs the day they come out, so... clearly I can't say that it isn't fun. If you want to know more, read on.

I have been playing Age of Wonders since I was fifteen, and I'm thirty five, now. I have never seen an entry in the series that I haven't liked, and I bought this game as soon as I got the chance. Age 2 advanced the series from Age 1 by [i]a lot[/i], and Age 3 was the best the series has ever been. But this one... it feels a lot like a re-skin of the last one; maybe more like a well made sci-fi mod, than a sequel. If you are old-hat and hoping for another revolutionary leap in the franchise, you won't see it here. Much, if not most, of the content is recycled from Age 3 and while there are many changes, nothing that has been added is actually [i]new[/i]. Maybe some things are new [i] to this series[/i], but they're all things you've seen in other 4X titles, before. You'll recognize things from Endless Legend, especially, and some stuff from Civilization, too, and even a bit from Europa Universalis, to boot, but nothing here is original. Even the sci-fi 4X premise, itself, has already been done to death in the last five years, so you'd better already be a fan of this stuff if you're coming to [u]this[/u] table. 

That being said, I do feel like this game does all of those things much better than they've ever been done before, and presents itself as a very ambitious (if not [i]unpolished[/i]) member of that well-known sci-fi 4X club. If you like the genre then you'll find that this one has quite a lot of content and is fun enough to keep you clicking the 'End Turn' button several thousand times (and pushing on through all of the bugs). The graphics are nice, though not fantastic, and the different races are all interesting and richly developed. They not only have a lot for you to unlock and play with, but they have plenty of lore and identity, too. The Secret techs are cool, the NPC factions are cool, and the unit mod system gives you lots of options for personalizing your units as you build your empire. Playing it all over again, with a new race and tech combo, leads to a very different experience than you had the last time, and that's super important in a game like this.

The turn based combat is fantastic, and is among the best I have ever seen in a 4X title. Psychic soldiers who infect the enemy's mind with evil spirits, causing them to explode and release ghosts onto the battlefield, dinosaur-riding amazons shooting laser arrows, bugs that eat you and poop out giant maggots, deathbots that fire plasma cannons that light the battlefield on fire; it's all great. But then, Age has always had great combat. It might stand out when you compare it to everything else you've seen on Steam, but it isn't much better than what we got in the last game, and to be perfectly frank, I much preferred the high-fantasy aesthetic to the sci-fi aesthetic. Dragons, spells, undead; that was more my jam, than aliens and laserguns. I miss the wizards, a lot. 

Plus, the combat experience, while great overall, is persistently hindered by ability/item descriptions that mislead you as to how they work. You'll go and use an ability that says it causes your unit to turn rabid, and attack the nearest [i][b]enemy[/b][/i] with bonus damage, only to find out they'll attack anyone nearby and you wind up killing your own dude. You'll activate a power because it says your Xeno creatures are immune to it, and it'll turn out theyre not. You'll target a machine with an attack that says it works on machines, only to find out it doesn't affect [i]that[/i] machine, for some reason. You'll try to equip a mod that turns all of your psychic attacks into poisonous fire, but for whatever reason the game will tell you that the unit in question has no psychic attacks, even if he has three...

The game [i]could[/i] be awesome, but it's broken in so many ways and it just feels more like an awkward spinoff than a proper sequel. And, because it's owned by Paradox, now, the devs are hard at work on their upcoming DLCs instead of fixing anything, and I am left to wonder if that means its problems will ever see real attention paid to them. Many of these issues have existed since launch, and their updates contain a nominal offering of remedies, at best. 

So... overall... this game is fun, but the acquisition by Paradox has seriously tarnished it and holds it back. If you're really into 4X games, you'll like it, especially if you're into the sci-fi aesthetic. If you've played all of the Age games, before now, you'll think it's "ok", and have some fun. But... if you're new to the franchise, and you want to try it out, just go and get Age of Wonders 3. It was leaps and bounds ahead of this thing in quality, had more content, and was a lot more stable. It remains the paragon of the series, while this will probably fall off the radar in another year or two.

As the game is now, I do not recommend it.

I played the entire series extensively, over 4.000 hours over all titles of the series, for me personally, they changed things that were good about the game, and kept things that were bad about it.

City Siege
The first thing that is really noticeable and changes the dynamic of sieges entirely, they removed gates from city walls, those were replaced by militias and defensive towers, however these militias don't have mods, and you can't aim the towers, so any other troop that attacks the city will be stronger.

The amount of terrain attackers have to move was also reduced, and there are no longer heavy ranged units ( like ballistas from previous games ) available universally, on top of that, there are a ton of barricades on every single city fight for the attackers (???) not only buildings, but lower barricades themselves that have no purpose other than provide cover for the attackers, these covers for the attackers have the exact same defensive capabilities as the ones available for the defenders, so basically makeshift barricades have the same defensive value as solid concrete defenses from walls, so attackers are on equal grounds, not on the disadvantage from terrain you would expect when facing a army that would be waiting and ready for a siege.

Defensive units also do not gain a bonus for high ground anymore, so any player that properly understand show to use terrain for their advantage will have a advantage, and since ranged attacks had their ranged lowered, 

Cities
The cities themselves changed a lot on some aspects, buildings do not need money to be build anymore, only units, and you need to have dedicated units around your cities to keep claiming terrain to expand your cities.
The effectiveness of the kind of expansion, Industry, Energy (gold), research or food, depends on the terrain of the expansion, but there are mixed variations of terrain, and how effective the expansion is depends on both kinds of terrains, this adds a interesting dynamic to the city management, but why a space faring civilization of galaxy wide capabilities is unable to terraform terrain to the kind you need is beyond me, so you are restricted by what the game offers and based on luck of generated terrain, your opponents can get several 'good' terrains for their play style while you get 'bad' ones, but unlike previous titles that also had this issue, but this would only be a 'problem' early on, now these affect the city production much more, so a city that manages to have two good production expansions can pop units much faster than any other city, or a city with two good energy expansions can provide a ton of extra energy, I've seen differences of almost 400% between one city output and the other, again, this is only a problem o the end-game, but enough of a problem to be game breaking.

Monument raid
There are some sort of structures that provide much higher production once exploited by a city expansion than normal terrains, adding extra population slots and considerably more production of something, like industry or research, but those are either defended by marauders, or you need to deal with a minor faction through either diplomacy or conquest.
However, unlike cities, these monuments can only be attacked by a army of 6 units, because... well, there is no explanation on why...., it just is, giving the feel that, instead of having to put effort on making the computer play better, they instead limited the amount of units a player can use, as a form of clutch, and this specific aspect I find very frustrating

Operations
They equivalent of magic from previous iterations is called operations, there are three kinds, to use in combat, to use in the world map as a instant operation, or to use as a empire wide bonus, but now you no longer have to worry with the range of operations, they can be 'cast' anywhere, 

Like previous iterations, there are still borderline useless operations that I have never, ever used because other options are simple better, or simply because what they do is meaningless, like native threat detector, or Call of the Hive, or Sway Ideology, the point isn't that what some of those operations do isn't in some way useful, it's that either their cost, or the amount of research needed to unlock them is so high, that by the time you have them, due to the limited amount of operations you can perform, you don't use those, ever, because there are considerably better alternatives, or better usage for their cost in energy or influence.

But then again, that has always been a problem on the franchise, I feel like it's like having a soldier who owns the best dagger in the world, but he never uses it because he rides a dragon into battle, so having the option to use the dagger is pointless.

Heroes
Heroes have, once again, been nerfed, and I feel that most of their skills are too similar, depending on the level cap of the map you can level your heroes to be support of the army, or slight more effective in combat, but not enough to be able to fight on their own a T4 unit, or even most T3 units, this again changes the dynamic of the game, but I personally did not like this change, I miss both they being stronger and also having more customization options, on the other hand, they don't have a upkeep cost anymore, but I didn't find this buff to be necessary, and to be honest, don't understand the reasoning for they not having a upkeep.

Troops
There is a new mechanic introduced called staggering, to reduce the amount of action points a unit has based on how strong a skill impacts them, there is a counter for that, being stagger resistance or immunity.

I enjoy this a lot, felt like a awesome change, adding several different usages and also things to consider when thinking on the moves of your units.

However, I also feel that just one significant additional mechanic alone is not enough, it's great, it's welcome, and also, it is not enough, specially for a futuristic world.

A.I., Combat and Terrain
Game A.I. has improved a bit, it is still one of the best for games of the genre, but still feels like it has room for improvement, sometimes they don't use terrain properly, and there is a hidden issue on that, regarding the terrain.

There are terrain stuff, like rocks or debris, that can be used for cover EVERYWHERE, I mentioned this during my point regarding city siege, like, when you fight on a road, there are always a ton of car and truck debris, sometimes it feels like you're fighting on the super bowl parking lot

And that happens everywhere, fight on a city? no worries, attackers not only have buildings for cover, they have entire LAYERS of buildings for cover! 

The feeling I have is that they wanted to make the cover mechanic more widespread, but that is absurdly exaggerated on this iteration of the franchise, also, some of those covers don't make sense, like a hover bike or tank hiding behind a tree, some units seem to not be classified correctly for their scale, or the system itself needs rework.

And so far I have not mentioned a single bug in the game, I myself had to deal with several, like units stuck in their movement animation endlessly, making their turn in combat last forever, or operations not working properly, like the cryogenic sleep awakening operation giving less population to a city than the operation lists, or having to wait a turn once the city reaches maximum number of colonist to configure it to send food to other colonies otherwise one of your colonists dies, and those are the ones I remember at the top of my head while writing this review, and those are kinda minor bugs, I experienced several complete freezes that forced me to restart the game entirely.

The game, as it is now, is kinda nice, but needs work, has a ton of space for improvement, and before I can recommend it, it needs at least a major work effort to fix the current bugs the game has.

56570177.review:
Age of Wonders: Planetfall is probably best described as a blend of the Civilization, Total War, and XCOM series.

The game includes a good tutorial and gives you an idea of how the rest of it is going to play. While it should be accessible to anyone interested in a strategy game, Age of Wonders has a rather unique way of playing.

As far as the campaign goes, each race (of which there are 6) has two relatively long missions, with hero progress and choices carrying over to the next mission. The decisions you make have an effect on some later missions, particularly the last mission, but there is no wrong way to win. The story is honestly a bit bland.

Like many 4X games, battle is absolutely necessary and cannot be avoided. It frees up occupied tiles, awards resources and hero items, and grants your troops experience. You field army stacks of no more than 6 units, typically led by a hero. These stacks can reinforce each other in battle. At the beginning, you explore from your starting position, coming into conflict with neutral forces that occupy your expansion paths. Eventually you encounter other players and may engage them in diplomacy or war.

There are only 3 major resources in the game: food, energy, and "cosmite". The latter two are used to create and maintain combat units, with "cosmite" being required to build more advanced troops or augment existing troops to perform better in combat. This means lower tier units can still serve a role (and indeed may be necessary) in late-game compositions.

Research and city-building has parallels to Civilization but is more narrow. It is focused on producing stronger combat units or providing better support. Expanding revolves around building colonizers, not unlike Civilization's settlers, which can found new cities. Unlike other similar games, players in Planetfall must "annex" territories next to settled cities to grow their borders.

In terms of factions, there are 6 player factions and 5 "NPC" factions. In Planetfall, "NPC" factions are distinct from other neutral units and are a bit like city-states in Civilization, which provide quests and unique units. Each player faction can be further customized with a set of perks/flaws and a so-called "secret technology", which unlock different units and operations.

Balance-wise, I think Planetfall manages to make every race and secret technology not feel underpowered, although I definitely think some are a little stronger than others. There is good variety on unit compositions, but many units are also similar to each other and you quickly realize what type of combos you like.

The game has its share of bugs and quality-of-life issues. There are annoyances to be had with end of turn notifications relating to unit movement, particularly if you reload a save where you intentionally skipped a unit's turn.

Overall, I think Age of Wonders: Planetfall is a fun game with its own sets of challenges. Its unique playstyle is not for everyone, but if you enjoy Civilization, Total War, and XCOM, it is worth giving this game a shot. If you also just enjoy 4X games with a focus on combat, this may be a good fit.

A lot of people seem to misunderstand the game, so I figured I'd clarify it. This is a wargame, not a civlike. It contains civlike mechanics, but if you attempt to play the game passively, building up your empire and economy, you're going to find yourself quickly falling behind, running out of resources, and losing. This is a game about building big armies you use to invade and take land and resources, then turn those resources into more armies, more land, and more resources. City building is far more simple and straightforward than Civ, and can easily feel like there's nothing to do if you're not building armies because city upgrades come far slower than your building of units.

Units can have long, detailed statblocks with a long list of benefits, and can then be customized to do all manner of things. A basic soldier wielding an electrical rifle in the early game can quickly become a unit who wields a chain lightning stun rifle that ignores cover. A soldier with a plasma launcher can equip themselves with a medical kit and the means to heal and empower themselves from the flames they create and form a rolling barrage of fire that incinerates anything that dares to approach them. These are not expensive lategame units, these are basic cannon fodder. Late game can include things such as teleporting tanks, hovercrafts that can call down orbital bombardments, multiple flavors of mecha, and drone swarms.

This is a game about building armies and waging war. If you're like me and your average 4x game descends into a blood bath that would make Khorne proud, this is among if not the best 4x games on the market. If you want to play sim city, look elsewhere, as this game does not cater to that sort of play.

Having played a lot of AoW3, I was looking forward to Planetfall. When it came out, my feelings were mixed at first. The game felt a bit too overcomplicated, but that changed in the upcoming hours.

[b]Pros:[/b]
New and interesting strategic layer, fits the scifi settings. Similarity to Endless Legends is a bit too obvious, but welcome - as far as strategic layers go, EL is imho the uncontested king, so why not learn from the very best?

Combat is just as fun as it was before, adding possibility of grazing is an excellent idea. Battles are fun, interesting and complex. The developers admit big inspiration by XCOM, which is great. Once again - why not learn from the best?

Proper research tree that sets just the right pacing. Whenever you research something, it feels like you benefit from it right away and it stays for a while. This is pretty nice compared to e.g. main Civilization titles, where research speed often eclipsed production speed, i.e. you never could build everything you wanted or even half the things you wanted (Beyond Earth did this better).

Production times are also reasonably paced, i.e. you can field an army quite quickly, but you need resources to support its maintenance. This also means losing a few units when creeping isn't a game over for you (unlike in HOMAM).

The developers keep working on the game. I recommend checking out their developer diaries, it makes for an interesting read.

Factions are well graphically designed and have interesting backstories, I've spent a lot of time by just reading the descriptions.

The game runs perfectly smoothly even on a laptop optimized for programming (low-end graphics card) - one of the few AA titles I can actually run on my machine.

[b]Cons:[/b]
The game takes some time to grow onto you - it might feel too clustered and too overcomplicated at first. You need to invest some time to get to like it and enjoy it, which might in today's age of DOTA and Fortnite be an issue for some people.

Even though they look very different, the factions essentially play the same with just minor differences. It feels very close to Age of Empires 2, where the civs differed by a unique unit, few advantages and lack of some specific units - here e.g. the Amazons don't have a sniper unit, but instead they get a knight-like unit. Ultimately the playstyle is the same for all factions. With scifi settings it feels like the factions could be far more diverse - see Starcraft or Endless Space for amazing examples of this.

[i]Minor spoiler alert[/i]
The campaign is very weak. I know this particular issue has been troubling AoW3 as well, but here it kinda hits in the face. The campaign consists of thirteen missions (not including tutorial) - two missions for each faction and one final mission to wrap it up. The story is told in a very lackluster way, even though it could have some potential, but that's not the biggest problem. It's the individual missions - they all feel and play exactly the same. Ok, sometimes you have an island map, sometimes the map is filled with teleporters, sometimes you play on a map that is 90% volcanic, but that's not really enough. The only two missions that felt really diverse were when the climate of the whole map kept regularly switching and when you started the map with all covert operations already researched. And even there you were tasked with just building up your empire and armies and conquering either some opponents or some key structures. Heck, even the first Warcraft all those 30 years ago had better mission design.

[b]Verdict:[/b]
It is obvious that the negative points are by far outweighted by the plus ones. Planetfall takes the best of Age of Wonders, XCOM and Endless Legends and creates a mix that is the best turn-based strategy we've seen in the last few years. Heartily recommended!

55518539.review:
I think this is the best iteration of the Age of Wonders franchise I have played, and I would recommend it to both veterans and  new-comers to this style of game. This recommendation, however, comes with a VERY important caveat - when you are making a scenario play the game on the 'fastest' setting, and reduce the amount of dwellings to the minimal value.

These recommendations are meant to address my two biggest beefs with the game in that it starts to feel held up by diplomacy mechanics and researching new technologies and building more structures. 

If you read this far, I want to give some more details about the things this game does well and poorly

The good:
 - The atmosphere in terms of music, lore, and environment, and characters makes the Sci-Fi universe of the game and motives of the various races extremely compelling.
 - The tech-tree revisions between the fantasy AoW and Planetfall (random spells in a spell book versus progressive tech trees split into purely economic and purely military growth, respectively) make tech progression much more satisfying. Furthermore, changing out specializations (with little internal synergy or impactful gameplay) to be less numerous but much more in depth in the form of Secret Technologies make your choice more important.
 - The mod systems (up to 3 mods per unit) allows you upgrade your units in unique ways and create more interesting unit compositions than in previous titles. Another benefit of Secret Technologies is that you get access to more mods - increasing the depth of unit build once again.

In summary, reduced complexity in some areas and increased complexity in others makes the game easier to grasp more quickly. More importantly, it is a game that is more difficult to achieve mastery in because of this same set of changes.

While the problems in the game are less numerous than the advantages, they may be deal breakers for some and is the reason for my earlier recommendations (Increased game speed and minimal dwellings). 

The bad:
 - The game plays very slowly and the sector system, while it definitely has its advantages, means you have to wait for colonists and food growth to grow your bases. This is largely solved by the increased game speed, but doesn't address the next issue...
- Diplomacy moves extremely slowly, and dwellings are extremely demanding yet also rewarding to invest into. With the standard amount of dwellings this grinds the game to a halt since the threat of engaging them is too dangerous in the early game. This issue is solved well by reducing the amount of dwellings, since that increases competition for exclusive access to them - encouraging you to compete and, eventually, go to war with your enemies. 

There are numerous other small changes that are big deals to me as well (militia garrisons, fewer OP unit buffing structures, and better melee/ranged diversity to name a few), I hope you give AoW: Planetfall a try.

In a hurry? Then here's my TL;DR: Game is awesome, BUY.

What makes it awesome though? To cover this, I've divided this review into 4 parts that I find important in a 4X: Gameplay systems, replayability, art and expression.

[h1]Gameplay systems[/h1]
The most significant part of a 4X and the one that keeps you going for one more turn until the wee hours of the morning. AoW: Planetfall consists of 2 parts: A Civilizations-like strategic layer and an XCom-like tactical layer.

[b]Strategic[/b]
On the strategic layer you build your colonies, perform diplomacy, do quests, research, create and mod armies and kit out your heroes. It is a bit of a cross between Civilization and Endless Legend, although it of course bears the closest resemblence to AoW3.
The thing that defines this part most is choices, choices, choices. From army composition to reasearch to which faction to ally with to expansion to balancing the resources; You are always making difficult choices based on the situation at hand. These choices also always bring rewards in one form or another, giving the player that sweet shot of dopamine.

[b]Tactical[/b]
The one thing AoW always does better than its contemporaries in the 4X genre is combat and Planetfall is no exception. The shift of focus from melee to ranged brings XCOM-style cover systems into the mix and it is a great match for the flanking mechanics that AoW3 already brought to the table. The thing that makes tactical combat stand out to me is the incredible array of options and units that you can have at your disposal; From standard troopers with their assault rifles and grenades to giant plants that serve as biochemical artillery and mechanical monstrosities that can simply wade through walls and bash people on the head with a giant hammer. There is a lot of variety in the game's roster and this spices the game's battles up and makes you giddy to try and use that new unit or mod that you've researched or received as a quest reward.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
4X games tend to take a long time to finish per playthrough and if a game is finally finished, there needs to be an insentive to do it all over again. To pour another 20 hours into a match from start to finish. Planetfall covers this nicely by offering an extensive random scenario generator and allowing the player to combine any of the 6 races with the 6 different secret technologies. These two factors more than enough variety to keep you going for hours on end.

[h1]Art[/h1]
Generally what lures me into a game is its art style: Do I like the characters? The colours? The world setting? If I spend hundreds of hours in a universe, it needs to be an interesting one. In my opinion the unitverse of Planetfall IS an enteresting place to be. The 6 factions breathe character while leaving enough space to fill in the gaps yourself and play the race as you want to play it. The neutral factions are created with the same love and attention as the playable factions and all units in the game, from the lowly scout drone to the mighty Arborian Queen, express themselves through their form, their abilities, their sounds and their animations. A special shout-out goes to the music, which strikes a nice balance between futuristic and classic AoW and I found myself whistling along to it quite quickly.

[h1]Expression[/h1]
I want to be able to express myself in a 4X: Play the way I want to, while leading MY faction to shape the setting the way I see fit. It is supposed to be the story of me. Planetfall has plenty of customization options; Not just in the selection of race and secret technology, but also in the customization of your commander, the setting up of the world, research selection, different victory goals to follow, a morality and public support system and the way the AI and neutral factions respond to your actions. The game always makes me feel that it flows a certain way due to my decisions and that gives me the agency I want from a game like this.

[h1]Additional comments[/h1]
A few more things I like to add:
[list]
[*]AI is hard to get right in a 4X and I think it is decent, both in strategic as well as tactical modes. I feel the game gives me enough of a challenge to keep me on my toes and if I feel like I'm getting too good, I simply set up a team game or give more bonuses to the AI.
[*]Triumph Studios listens intently to its audience and delivers frequent, big patches.
[*]Multiplayer can switch seemlessly between regular turn-based mode and a play-by-email system, in which people can play their turns, even if not everyone is online. This really helps with 4X games.
[*]Triumph has released extensive modding tools, meaning the workshop is filling up nicely with a whole bunch of mods.
[*]UI is really good at showing all the information to the player in crisp manner. I've actually shown it at work to inspire UX specialists :)
[/list]

If you have any questions, feel free to comment!

TLDR: I cannot recommend this game enough!

UPDATED REVIEW 

One year in, 3 expansions and numerous free patches later, AOW:Planetfall is now amongst the best 4x games I ever played. It stands head and shoulders above AOW3 to the extend where aside from the setting there is nothing that would want me to go back to AOW3. 

While Planetfall was already a fantastic game at launch (c.f. original review below) it did have some issues, in particular a somewhat simplistic, though at the same time confusing, empire building gameloop. However every single issue with the game has been patched over the last year. Empire building is fantastic now, with the option to play wide or tall, with the option to concentrate on miliary/mobility (there are teleport station that hugely improve the movement armies in the late game) or economic development. They added a number of faction-specific buildings and perks that differentiate the way you approach the game depending on who you play as. If you haven't played this since launch or were turned off by some of the issues, give it another go, it is quite different now.

The latest free patch introduced an endless  'campaign mode' which is just insanely good and fun to play. What it basically is is a way to get a sense of progression between individual random games. Your heroes grow in level between games, but you also start building a repository of stuff that you can bring along to your games. This could be units that are not typically accessible to your faction or special operations, or mods (more on mods later). This allows you to shore up weaknesses in your faction or create crazy new combinations that really make you feel more powerful game after game (want to bring a tier IV from another faction along? you got it!). Your heroes also rejoin you game after game (albeit without their loadout) which makes you become more attached to them than the random heroes that pop up. This game mode is so much fun that I don't think I would ever go back to single random maps. 

We also have anomalous sites, mini-expeditions dotted all over the map that can result in some rather unique weapons, mods, skills, operations and gives you a lot to do in the mid-game outside of constant warfare. Some of those rewards are just insane, e.g. an operation that allows you to create 2(!) clones of any unit during battle, and are just really really fun to further customize your game. The latest expansion has also add a 'grail hunt' which is like one mega-expedition that gives you a massive reward, but will require a fair bit of resource dedication and detract from what you should be doing.

Finally let me talk about mods again. This for me is, hands down, the best aspect of the game. Every single unit can be upgraded with dozens of mods. Some of them are simple, just adding a bit more damage, or defense, but others can completely change the way a unit operates on the battlefield. The genius of this is that it keeps your low(er) level units relevant into the late game. You know how in AOW3 you basically had T4 stacks by mid to late game. This is not the case in AOW:Planetfall. You can give a lowly T1 melee unit a mod that turns it into a AOE ranged unit, allows it to jump around the battlefield, gain ressurgence, etc. All of this leads to highly customized armies and each game results in very different compositions depending on what you research/find and what the enemy brings to the field. Even after almost 400 hours played I still find combinations that interact in new ways and make my otherwise obsolete units really shine. This is particularly true with the new campaign mode where the number of options has just exploded.

Overall AOW:Planetfall is a gem now, easily in my top 10 all times games, and on my 'desert island' list for sure.

ORIGINAL REVIEW

Planetfall is an awesome game. Packed with features, tons of strategy and tactics, meaningful decisions, well thought out tech trees, huge replayability and very stable.

I bought AOW3 when it came out and could see its appeal and really enjoyed the battles but for some reason could never really get into it. The strategic layer was lacking and it felt that only the Class really matter whereas all Races were kind of the same. AOW:Planetfall is very different, every Race is vastly different, and the depth that comes from combining Factions, Secret Techs, minor factions is amazing. The strategic layer is also hugely improved, I really like the sectors and the way skirmishes at the border can flip them around. The landmarks further add to the strategic depth, making colony placement much more significant. I just wish there was a way to see at once all the bonuses that apply, but that can easily be remedied by a patch, or a mod.

Finally the Mod system is pure genius. The amount of customization options is mind boggling. With the right mods my tier I units can stay relevant until the end, something that never was the case in AOW3. Heros can switch Mods (and Weapons!) on the fly, meaning you can turn an almost impossible battle round with the right counters.

Future expansions will only make this even better.

I cannot recommend this game enough!

As a long time fan of the Age of Wonders series, Planetfall did not disappoint.

Planetfall is a 4X game, with a particular emphasis on exterminate. If you are strategy gamer that prefers economic micro management and resource management, this is not the game for you.

For players who do like combat, this is the best combat strategy game on the market. The game has 6 economically similar races, but vastly different combat capabilities. These races combined with the 6 secret technologies and the 5 minor NPC factions enable each game to feel different. Even some of the less obvious combinations can have very powerful effects.

These different combinations get enhanced by the mod system in game. Each unit can have up 3 mods based on their unit type. One design choice I appreciate for the mods is they generally avoid just increasing damage or defense. The mods always do another effect that is more interesting than that, some of which can change a units role. One example is a fire round for guns, that changes ammo into a light explosion effect, causing AoE damage. The mod system can make some late game units and combinations feel broken, which is always fun in a mostly singleplayer game.

The units and mods all come together into the tactical combat. The normal gameplay occurs on a high level strategic view, but when two or more armies meet you can initiate a tactical combat. Each unit in the game has 2 or more abilities, and can have ever more with mods. Based on you and your opponents units and capabilities, it can allow for some intense combats and close victories.

The campaign consists of 13 missions, 2 per race with one final mission where you can pick who you want. As you play the campaign, you are given different choices in the mission which will affect the final mission, adding some decent replayability. While generally fun to play, some of the later missions can really drag along due to their requirement to eliminate many players on a large map. 

The main gameplay mode is a random map generator. This RMG allows for a good amount of customization, along with offering some presets to get you started.  It is possible to do Free For Alls or pre-set teams based on your preference. In this mode there are 3 different ways to win, though I find the technology one to be a little easier than the other ones on larger maps.

One big complaint I have about the multiplayer is that there is no way to play without going through the Paradox servers. I do not like how this bodes for the future of the game in regards to multiplayer.

Planetfall even in its vanilla release has a great amount of content. Both Triumph and Paradox have a history of supporting their titles, so this should be the beginning of a long and fruitful update process. Triumph has already released 2 patches within one month. Age of Wonders 3 looks very different from its release version and I have high hopes that Planetfall will continue this trend.

54871249.review:
In short - this is Age of Wonders 3, but with robots and tanks. If you liked that game, you'll like Planetfall. Now, differences.

Character creation is changed - you still pick your race and "profession" (this time called "secret tech"), but system of masteries is gone. You  get to choose some minor perks, which are much less significant.

Instead there's much more focus on your race. Where in AoW3 you were mostly playing a chosen profession, only considering race for their stat boosts, here both races and techs are fully flashed out, allowing you to either focus on one or the other, or combine both for internal, often race-unique synergies.

There's also mod system. Every unit can be further upgraded by 3 mods, provided by race and tech research trees. Those mods can be anything from damage type changes, to new abilities, to conditional quirks specializing your units in some unique fields. The whole system feels great, and offers a lot of customization for min-maxing and tailoring your armies.

City expansion is also changed - where in AoW3 your city just expanded on its own, here you get to chose up to 4 nearby provinces - sectors - to annex into the city. Each sector, due to combination of factors, will offer different yields of different resources, making you specialize your cities and plan your expansion more carefully.

Overall, the game feels really great. Highly recommend it.

I wish Steam would implement a Neutral rating, but weighing pro’s and cons, it’s a negative for now.

After a while you realise that every map plays the same. From the city upgrades to the tech-tree, after a few games you seen it all and it gets stale very fast. The diplomacy is bare bones and communication from the AI uninspiring and repetitive. The customisation options are lacklustre too, especially the Dvar have almost no options. (Guess more customisation options will come through DLC, the Paradox way!)
 The game doesn't feel like a new game, rather a reskin of Age of Wonders 3 which is blatantly obvious from the leader customisation screen and unit screens. The minimap is one unclear mess, especially when you play with a black colour and, regarding colour, they didn't learn anything from AoW3, as there are still too few colours which you can use to customise your empire. I cannot believe how this could get into the release, as there were Beta Testers so they had to spot these obvious faults. 

The "enormous" map is rather small, not utilising the 64bit environment the game runs in, and it feels like they copied the maps right from AoW3 (which was 32bit). Maybe it is larger, but if it is, it sure doesn't feel it.

The NPC factions get annoying very fast. Their demands are too frequent and their quests are very repetitive; Either kill a certain amount of units or research some stuff. And that every few turns. 

The races are a hit and miss, same as the units, and this was also the case in AoW3. You can see they used the same artists and copied most animations of units, albeit with a different skin. Luckily Tibbles is on the case to hopefully remedy the female characters through Modding. But how the Beta Testers missed that one too, is another mystery.

Of course there aren’t only negatives, they are in the majority than the positives, however.

The Map (excluding mini-map) looks beautiful. The shallow water (sometimes with reefs) and environment look top notch. They fixed one of the terrible annoyances of AoW3 too; Tier IV unit spam. You can now add mods to units, which makes Tier 1 units viable even mid- to late game. This was sorely lacking in AoW3 so kudo's for that! It’s a shame that you probably won’t get to see everything as the game ends rather quick, even on an enormous map. I had a conquest victory in turn 123 on an “enormous” map on normal difficulty. I never achieved a victory in Civ V (which this game borrowed heavily from) on the biggest map in 123 turns.  And this shows how small so-called enormous maps are. The Tech tree is expansive, but maybe too expansive for the duration of a game.

The manual battles look good but can get a bit unclear at times, especially when there are lot’s of units in mêlée. Flying units can be a pain to target sometimes without having to fiddle with the camera, but the battles are enjoyable to fight. The “spellcasting” in battles is through tech you researched which can grant buffs to your units and damage to enemies and so on. They really were intuitive with that system. People compare the battles with XCOM, but other than the cover system, there really isn’t much comparison. The mechanics are copied from AoW3 so if you were familiar with that, you feel right at home.

They fixed the missing sound-effects from release after two patches so that is good. I still wonder sometimes if they would've released the game on the same date if they were still independent as it felt like a bit rushed. The Swedish Overlords breathing down their necks.
 Of course every Paradox game needs a few patches to function, been so since the Hearts of Iron days, so the game has certainly potential to grow. And that’s where it lies; The game will probably really begin to shine when the planned DLC’s are released, which will hopefully add missing races and more customisation options. Hopefully Triumph has some say in this and will not give in into those antics.

Final verdict; A game with a lot of potential but released too soon to justify the price. You will get some enjoyment out of it, especially if you like customising your ruler (albeit with limited options) and the first few games can be enjoyable, but you will come to realise it gets stale very fast. I waited with this review when I got some hours invested into it as I feel you can only then review a game properly, instead of the people who only played for under an hour and immediately put a negative (or positive) rating on it.
Will update the review after some patches and DLC and hopefully it will change for the good as great 4X games are hard to come by.

I was holding back on my review until I thought I've played enough to understand how the game works, the different mechanics, played different factions and different specialisations. The game has a lot to offer, a lot of new stuff compared to AOW3, some similarities to other games too.

The Good:
Unit, faction and specialisation variety. There's 6 Factions and 6 specialisations all with their own units plus NPC factions with their own units and they all can be modded with 3 different mods. Insane amount of different stuff to try and use. A lot of flexibility and options.

Triumph got rid of the physical and elemental resist system of AOW3. Instead now you have 2 different protection (Armor and Shield) against all damage and resistance against status effects like bleed, blind, stun..etc. Combine that with the ability to mod units and you get a system in which a levelled up tier 1 unit can stand it's ground against a basic Tier 3 or even tier 4 unit so AOW3 tier 4 spam is not necessarily a winning strategy in Planetfall, which is great.

Modding units gives you a lot of flexibility to design your units, make them glass cannons or "tanks" to soak up damage,you can give them AOE effects or change their Kinetic damage to Arc to be more effective against machines, you can give them extra health or health regen.. it's up to you. You can get mods and units from dwellings (independent NPC factions) too so the possibilities are almost endless.

The tactical combat has been reworked too. The most significant change is the cover system and the chance based hitting in which you can actually miss opposed to AOW3's system where you always hit, even if it was only for 1HP. Some people like it, some don't all in all with all the changes to combat combined, I prefer Planetfall's system to AOW3's

The Sector system is an another big change which I love. I remember how many times I started with a Sorcerer in AOW3 and wanted mana nodes but all I got was gold and production and when I started as a Warlord wanted gold and mana but found 8 mana to 1 gold and 1 production. Whit the sector system this is gone. If you need food you specialise your sector on food and expand to sectors where there's food. If you need Energy (money) than you just specialise on energy and level up your energy sectors. It's a lot more flexible system than AOW3 population and border based one. Basically sectors are your traditional "mines" but you can decide what sort of resource you want them to produce.

The other great thing is colony defences. You can build defensive buildings in your colony which provides you with militia units to defend your colony AND your sectors TOO which means your economy is protected and "turtle" strategy is a lot more viable option than ever before.

Operations are great. Do you remember how annoying the constant Empire "upgrade" spell spam and disjunction spam was in AOW3? There was a mod to disable disjunction so you and the AI won't be able to remove spells from each other (wasn't a great solution either) It's all gone. Now you can still try to use some operations (spells) on each other but all faction has operation defences too with which you can lower the chance of success of any enemy operations.

These are the main changes that makes the game better than AOW3 and it seems Triumph has listened to all the community feedback they've been given to AOW3 and sort the biggest problems out in Planetfall so kudos to you Triumph Studios!!


The Ok:
Graphics and Music and animations are ok but nothing spectacular. 
Diplomacy is ok at best but let's face it AOW was never about the diplomacy but the units, faction diversity and tactical combat.

The Bad
Some of the voice over are horrendous (looking at you Dvar)
There's some bugs where the game just stops working,the battle doesn't end, some desync issues in Multiplayer (not too common) Some interface issues,information missing here and there...
Nothing major and I don't want to list them all here one by one but there's certainly stuff to work on.

....And The BEST: That freakin' "Eat Dust" ability :D That just made me laugh. Some great sense of humour right there :)

As you probably guessed by now I'd absolutely recommend the game,even at full price but it certainly isn't for everyone. 
Not a diplomacy based game, not a Civ-like empire building either, although the economy is important to support what the game is GREAT about which is tactical combat. 
If you're into unit customisation, unit diversity, finding and using faction, unit and mod synergies to find a combination that suits your play style the best and use all that to conquer the world than this is the best game for you to pick up and play. You better be ready to read a lot! :)

Age of Wonders: Planetfall

I’m new to the world of Age of Wonders so some of this will come as no surprise to the series fans, but for me it’s new and it’s great!

If like myself you are a fan of Civilization, Total War, XCOM and sci-fi in general then you will definitely love Age of Wonders: Planetfall!
The campaign map runs very similar to Civilization but with a sector system for expansion rather than slowly expanding out which makes diplomacy and working out your borders far better.
You develop your colonies as normal but your armies are similar to Total War, where you build and choose up to 6 units to go in each army, with up to 6 armies able to fight in any one battle.
Speaking of battles, this runs very much like XCOM, turn based with a cover system and lots of cool unit abilities. You can even call in airstrikes and satellite lasers if you’ve unlocked the tech!

The game’s setting and design is fantastic. I’m usually not a fan of the slightly crazier designs of sci-fi and fantasy, but in this game it feels right and works really well. Each faction is distinct in both visual and gameplay style.
I’ve enjoyed trying out all the factions, from your typical human spacefarers (the Vanguard), the espionage and stealth tactics of the Syndicate and the Amazons, a fun blend of Atlantians from Aquaman and the Navi of Avatar.  There’s even space Dwarves in the shape of the Dvar and space Zombies (Necrons/Borg)!

The single player campaign is well put together with a great story for each faction.  It reminds me a lot of the campaigns of classic games such as Starcraft and Command & Conquer.

Multiplayer is really strong as well, with an unusual but excellent way of running player turns. Like games such as Civilization you can opt for alternating or simultaneous turns on the campaign map, but you can pop on even without the “host” being online to take your turn, log off and it’s ready for the next player to do their actions.  This is great for carrying on a game, especially if your friends aren’t always available to play.

There are a few negative points but these are very minor. The developer has released a solid game and though I’m sure they will update it to improve quality of life, the game is complete and runs smoothly (at least for me).
If you love strategy games, love sci-fi and are looking for something new but familiar, then I highly recommend Age of Wonders: Planetfall.
