Age of Wonders: Planetfall:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Standing on your spaceship command deck, the sight is spectacular! There lies in front of your eyes one of the planets from the old Star Union Empire, led by the Empress Carmania, the leader of your ancestors. What were the reasons for the fall of this Empire, and are there any survivors who could help you understand.  It’s time to find out, as you’re about to land on the first planet of Age of Wonders: Planetfall!

Age of Wonders: Planetfall is a 4x strategy game with a turn-based combat system, developed by Triumph Studios and Published by Paradox Interactive on the 7th of August 2019. The game is available on PC (steam), Xbox One and PS4 platforms.

I must say up front that I haven’t played any of the previous games in the series and therefore, I’m not able to make any comparisons with the previous titles.

The game consists of 14 missions, including a tutorial. Whether or not you are familiar with this genre of game, I strongly suggest playing the tutorial, which is a small mission and will take you around 45 minutes to an hour to complete, and will give you a good understanding of all aspects of the game.

When you are done with the tutorial, it will be time for you to choose between one of the three planets available to explore. You can choose your difficulty from Beginner, Advanced and Expert, as well as whether or not you want to have your hero resurrected after losing a battle. 

The game has two phases; the first one is basically to grow your Empire, and the second is the turn-based combat phase. At the start of each game, your spaceship will land on the specific planet and create your base colony. You first goal is to acquire more lands surrounding your colony by sending a unit to a sector and building forward bases and claiming these territories. As your main colony grows, you’ll have the ability to annexe these specific territories to that colony and choose what type of industry it will support: Energy, Production, Food or Research. The energy is basically the currency in this game and therefore, you must make sure you have enough of it in your treasury to buy new units and strikes during the combat phases. In terms of research, you have two trees; one for the Military, and the other for the Society. Both have 9 stages of research, with each stage having 4 researches to acquire. 
 
As you move forward, you’ll be able to purchase new units and structures, as well as operations. But you must have plenty of energy and Cosmite (essential material) at your disposal for your military units and gears to produce new buildings after discovering new society research.

You’ll be able to move your units and start exploring the planet, eventually meeting other races (as well as your own) who will give you quests that will help you discover the story of the planet. But be aware that the first time they meet you, your relationship will be fragile as they will most likely doubt your intentions. You can start with a diplomatic approach using the diplomacy tab, or just become a war mongrel, attack them and take over their territories. I must say that the Diplomacy options are very good and easy to use. 

Which takes me to military units. You can merge up to six units, including a hero, to create an army. You have to make sure you have enough energy to create a unit, while equally ensuring that you have enough energy to keep your units alive. What I really like about the units is that you can customise them as you find new technologies. Yes, you’ll get new units with specific technology, and you’ll also be able to upgrade these units by adding additional technologies through the unit mod slots, of which there are three per unit. For example, your space marine starts with a machine gun, but by adding electrified ammunition and rail accelerators, your unit will now fire some sort of deadly electric laser. And there is plenty of variety, which is fabulous! Regarding your heroes, you can also purchase and change they primary and secondary weapons. All units will gather experience as they survive on the battlefield, but your heroes will gain experience points which you can use to purchase special skills for them.
The second phase is the turn-based combat and all you have to do is to move either one unit, or an army comprising six units, onto the tile where an enemy unit is located. If you have other friendly units next to the defendant or enemy figurine, they will automatically join the fight with you and vice versa.  During each turn, all units have 3 action points which they can use to move around, use weapons and activate abilities too. If you eliminate all enemies, you’ll be the winner! You’ll be fighting in different environments, including in deserts and on water, which is a lot of fun. Operations are also available in turn-based combat as long as you have enough energy points, but use them wisely as you can only use a few per battle.

Also, as you move from planet to planet, you’ll be playing different races (6 in total, plus the Paragon faction) which gives you a bit of novelty as you have to learn about each of the races, units and research. One point I forgot to mention is that all maps (planets) are randomly generated, which gives you plenty of replay-ability. There is also a multiplayer mode.
Splendid graphics and smooth soundtrack. The game runs very well and you’ll be stuck to your screen for hours on end. The only annoying thing I encountered was the constant reminder that I have still units with movement left in them, either in battle or on the main map; this kept happening even after ticking the box to not be reminded. There are plenty of options and your can rebind keys if you wish to do so (thank God for that)!

Positives:
~~~~~~~~

+	Great Graphics
+	Single and multiplayer mode
+	Customise your heroes and units
+	7 races with their own units
+	Good and easy technology trees
+	Great gamepedia
+	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	Annoying reminder before ending a turn if you haven’t moved all your units.

Dive headfirst into Planetfall, an exceptional strategy game! A must-have for all fans of the genre.

9/10  

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

This is a narrow recommendation in its current state. I expect that with patches and expansions it will get much better. 

A few pros:

1) Engaging combat system
2) The different factions/technologies play pretty different from one another, so there is value in playing a different way
3) The game doesn't drag out too long like in previous AoW games

Cons:

1) The map is really cluttered and hard to read compared to AoW3 and other games in the genre
2) Diplomacy options are weak. The AIs feel really aggressive. I've never managed to ally with a single other faction. Everybody just denounces and declares war for seemingly no reason. 
3) I find a lot of the animations to be a bit slow. They recently put in an option to always have fast movement on for combat, but this is not the case on the strategic map. 

Your mileage may vary:

1) After experimenting with all of the secret technologies, Xenoplague is the only one that I found really fun
2) I'm not a huge fan of the sci-fi theme. I think I prefer the fantasy theme
3) I don't trust Auto Combat to not lose my units, even in easy fights. If I have a 2 to 1 strength advantage, I will never lose a unit in manual combat. Auto Combat sometimes kills a unit. So playing through manual combats is a bit of a grind. Min-maxers will feel this pressure, while more casual players might not mind. 
4) I don't like the "sector" mechanic. I very much prefer building on a hex, and having influence expand from there. This game uses a mechanic similar to the Endless Legend system, where you claim a whole batch of hexes at once

All that said, I feel I've gotten my money's worth, and it has a lot of room to grow from here.

If you you don't know the AoW series better look it up on youtube and form your own opinion before you come back and read comments here, because the game is really complex and stillof the best turn based strategy games there. Did you like Endless legends but were bored with the combat and the hours of prepping for the perfect economy choices? Well then this game is for you.

If are a Age of Wonders veteran then this is what you need to know: Planetfall improved AoW in every aspect the prequels were lacking: 

1) Economy now actually takes planning and careful decisions have to be made to  max your income, due the sector system which allows you to build different buildings concering food, production, research or energy (the currency) depending in which climate the sector stands.

2) Tier 1 unit now stay usefull till the endgame thanks to the mod system (every unit has 3 mod slots you can fill with over 100 different mods, ranging from extra range, damage, changing of damage for ex. from kinetic to fire, giving them extra abilities...)

3) the experimenting with the mods alone will take you days and is well made

4)They split casting points into "stratetic" and "tactical" points. Strategic points can only be used for "spells"/operations on the stratetic map and operational for actual battles. This actually motivated me to use stratetic spells and not just save my casting points for the "actual battle". 

5) Also a lot of damaging abilities are not just flat numbers anymore but %, which means they scale into the endgame. 

6)Damage types have been distributed far wider and better than in AoW3. Remember Poison? In theory awesome, too bad that almost every undead creature was immune, the whole goblins and dwarves highly resisted and so on... Imagine Goblin Rogue fighting wraiths, yeahh.... high physical and poison immunity. 

So immunities as far as I can tell are gone. Every race has 2 damage types per se. "Physical"/kintec is now not the main damage type any more but just one of many. Certain races like the Syndicate don't even use physical but arc and psionic. 


So every change I can see improves the overall gaming experience and will keep you at bay for months. 

If you liked theprevious AoW and are ok with the Sci-fi setting, then you will LOVE this game.

Original review below:
------------------------

Better than AoW3, but not quite as good as it could have been, or could yet be. 

To start, the game doesn't feel completely "finished," like it was pushed out with a few things forgotten or not ready, mostly in the sound effects department. A number of weapon sounds and unit voices are missing, just a handful of ranged attacks, a larger number of melee attacks, most things have sounds so the few that don't tend to stick out and can be a tad jarring. Some of the melee animations I also want to believe are placeholders, because I can't see how they could be that bad with any effort put into them whatsoever. This ends up being a very minor issue because I found myself avoiding tactical combat as much as possible. Adding those sound effects in is probably going to be very low priority for a while since the devs are still dealing with a number of crash issues and broken mechanics. I feel it's worth mentioning those issues now even if they may be fixed in the future, as we are over week past release now.

Mechanically the combat system is pretty solid, overwatch and cover mechanics make it engaging, there's a variety of skills to use with various interesting synergies, if this was an Xcom style game that would all be great. It's not an Xcom style game though, it's a 4x, and combat takes entirely too long to deal with manually for any progress to be made at all in your overall campaigns. There are times when I fired the game up, fought a single tough battle, and that one battle took so long it exhausted me and I saved and quit after winning. You will be fighting hundreds of such battles per game. The other issue with combat, the bigger issue, is the AI is awful at using all these new mechanics and synergies, to the point where taking manual control of a battle feels like cheating and pressing an "I win" button even if you are grossly outnumbered. There are "late game" dungeon objectives on the map you have to defeat to unlock the strongest resource nodes (which can be extremely powerful nodes), they are filled with a mix of the higher tier units and only allow a single squad to enter (usually you can cluster your squads on the map and bring multiple into the same battle), they are like meant as a challenge even for a strong squad. I have beat these objectives using teams of basic scout units. Scouts as you can imagine are the weakest units in the game, meant for exploring not combat, that is how bad the AI is in manual combat. So I autobattle almost everything, and that said the autobattle feels relatively solid compared to other games since it is actually simulating the entire battle with all your units and skills, you can even watch a replay of it to understand what happened.

The usual 4x progression mechanics like research and city growth/management, Planetfall does MUCH better than AoW3. There are dedicated military and social research trees, and you have to actually get the tech to build the better buildings in your cities instead of just having them all unlocked instantly. Planetfall really does feel like a true full-depth 4x while AoW3 was a "light 4x." A lot of the military trees are faction specific or "class" specific, making each game you play feel fairly unique in that area. The social tree on the other hand, there are only like 2 faction techs and 2 class techs on the entire social tree, everything else is generic and shared with every faction, which is a bit disappointing. For the most part every game you play you will progress your cities and empire the same way, with the same buildings and upgrades. There is at least progression there though this time.

The unit mod system is I think the biggest highlight of the game. There are a large variety of mods you can unlock based on your faction and class choice, and a few you can get from NPC questing stuff, you can mix and combine these mods to create some really interesting strategies. I would say it's one of the better unit design systems out there in the genre.

Exploration is a tad weak, scouting around the map gets you a few very small resource pickups and very little else of use. The sector system locks most of the map to a fairly rigid balance making most of the world bland, IE a sector is either a forest sector or it's not, it doesn't matter how many trees are there it's the same, so there is very little interesting worldgen. There is no autoexplore, and if one was added it would be almost entirely useless because the map is full of wandering enemies that are only just strong enough to hunt down and kill your scouts while accomplishing nothing else. You can usually avoid these enemies while manually scouting by sticking to the coasts and going into the water to avoid the land enemies and popping back on shore to avoid the ocean ones, an autoexplore would just instantly get your scouts killed but a lot of people are asking for it.

Those are the systems I can think of offhand I feel worth highlighting. Overall it's a decent 4x and I'm looking forward to seeing how the game evolves with future content additions.

In comparison to Age of Wonders 3, Planetfall has a positive aspect to it. The immediate tactical combat is satisfying, with varied options for how to handle a fight. Unfortunately problems are to be found everywhere else in the game and can best be summarized as variations of being bland. Planetfall goes out of its way (unintentionally) to be as bland as possible. 

A lot of it stems from the art direction for Planetfall being subpar at best. This leads to a host of problems that sour the entire experience. The primary examples are:

1. Graphics blending together. Terrain on the world map lacks immediately obvious unique identifying traits which makes differentiating sectors more aggravating than it should be. Having no strong colours in the game's palette contributes to this. These problems also exist in tactical combat where it is harder to tell things apart than it should be.

2. Cluttered UI. Not only does the UI take up a lot of space, it also provides little information in exchange for that space. 

3. No aesthetic appeal. The races and their units aren't visually appealing and varied designs are distinctly absent. There's no "oomph" to high-tier units either that makes them satisfying to acquire. Designing your own commander is also affected by the lack of appeal. Planetfall removes every avenue for making conventionally attractive characters that you would want to identify with as a player. There is also no point to having graphical character customization when you are given as few choices as you are here.

Gameplay wise it is difficult to make comments on what is and isn't balanced based on only 30 hours of gameplay. What can be said is that the empire management side is unsatisfying. Replacing domain radius with sectors isn't necessarily bad, but the options for what to do with them are incredibly limited. The resource points on the world map provide a lot less diffrentiation than the previous game's equivalents. City advancement is also strictly linear and wholly dependent on your research; this leads to forcing certain strategies.

As a final note the music follows suit with the rest of the game. There is only one memorable track in Planetfall compared to the numerous standout tracks in AoW 3. This is a real shame.

TL;DR: Wanted to find out if gameplay is good or not, woefully lacking presentation makes it impossible to get there.

Age of Wonders Planetfall is a good game, but to me it is a disappointment.  It really just seems like a mod/reskin of Age of Wonders 3 to be a sci-fi setting. * more in game detail.  I want to see info amd lore on quests, not just a one line of text.  I want to see details on structures with animated graphics of what the building looks like, not just an icon size picture with one line of text

54607463.review:
Hello! Quick prefix before getting into the fun content! I don’t often do reviews but I make exceptions for when I have a good story to tell; I suck with being technical with reviewing games after all so I can only really do games justice with an ever so slightly dramaticized tale of something I have actually done in game! I made a review very similar to this one for AOW3 in fact and I believe I got an even better story out of this game than that, so take that as you will. With no further ado, let’s have some story time!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
The Amazons were in quite a predicament; after their boisterous leader, Regata, had a few too many drinks at her commonplace-parties she decided it would be a fun idea to insult the neighbouring Redeemers which resulted in them declaring war. Of course, they were just aching for an excuse to declare war anyway, Regata was not only a bloodthirsty warlord but a smart one at that, what was the issue with pushing things along while her armies were by their border? The issue was that the techno-zombies weren’t as mindless as they looked. The full army of the redeemers was held in tight formation and with enough synthesized firepower to put a frontal assault on their army a very risky endeavour, thus Regata planned to sit in her fully armed and armoured city and goad them into attacking her where she had the home field advantage. 

Unfortunately, the redeemers continued to prove their tactical competence by hiking up the mountains to completely circumvent the militarized border city and instead beeline directly towards the vulnerable capital. This would be quite a problem indeed; the capital had an army defending it but not one that could hold their large army off, if Regata wanted to try and rush to its defence then she would be back in time to fight within it’s smouldering ruin, not to mention leaving the other city undefended if the redeemers wanted to play another trick and turn around to hit the newly undefended border city. However, Regata in her war-like cunning saw a solution to this: Both her frontline armies and the capital guard would converge upon the redeemers in the mountains in a desperate and bloody assault! It would be the only way to take them on without a martyr. Thus, the massive battle began; the Amazons encircled the redeemers in a pincer-like formation and begun the assault. The Redeemers were split into three forces:

•	The force on the left was lead by a brutal Redeemer Captain wielding a devastating shotgun that fired ionized crystals, both shredding and zapping his opponents.
•	The force in the centre was lead by cold and calculating Redeemer Captain wielding a mind-tearing psyonic sniper rifle.
•	The force on the right, guarded by a river and only accessible from the centre, was lead by the Redeemer commander himself. He rode a bulky terror-inducing chopper, mounted with a powerful repulse based weapon and an arc blaster, both able to tear apart a full unit in one or two volleys single handily. 


The first objective of the bulk of the Amazonian forces was to reach the centre, much easier said than done as many of the routes were thick with rock and overgrowth in the wild terrain. Yet many of the hunters used this to their advantage as a useful cover to shield them from the sniper fire of both the central captain and his entourage of snipers. A hole was made in their defences of flesh and metal by the Amazonian purifiers, hailing firebombs onto the clustered Redeemer defenders. Due to Regata’s wise decision in equipping her hunters with thermal-based targeting on their weapons, the fire aided wonderfully in helping the hunters mow down half the immolated defenders of the central pass at once. With the window of opportunity opened, the raptor cavalry charged in and quickly dealt with the sniping captain, needless to say he never got another shot off.

Regata’s personal force was separated off from the rest to ensure that the redeemers on the left would not flank the rest of her forces heading through the centre and towards the commander; while she stealthily skulked her way around the side of a rocky hill, her hunters made their way up the hill to rain a hail of arrows upon the remaining captain’s forces. Unfortunately, those forces were a lot more powerful than expected and returned fire with brutal repeating arc guns, mowing down a majority of Regata’s personal guard upon the hill and forcing the remnants to retreat back down. Yet the hunters did indeed wipe out the bulk of his forces as they made their way up the hill, leaving the captain with a single weary unit of scavengers.

Regata had enough of watching her loyal soldiers die; with a burst of flame she leapt up onto the hill, directly down upon the scavengers, burning them alive through the power of cinematic entrance alone. Normal people would need to take a moment to recollect themselves after such a move, but due to Regata’s extensive training and aptitude in ruthless killing, the death of the measly scavengers kept her going with the same fire that burned all around her. She charged forward to battle the captain alone, laser glaive versus crystalline shotgun.

Even with such a brutal weapon, the cyborg didn’t have much of a chance; the powerful swings of the warlord’s weapon continued to knock him off balance as the thermal damage seared across his body. In a rage fuelled act of defiance he aimed not at her, but at the last surviving unit of her forces. In a flash of cyan lightning they too joined their sisters in the dirt. Regata took exception to that display, running her glaive so deep into the captain she could have pinned him to the floor. Not that he was any position to need pinning; he was dead the moment the thermal blade pierced his chest, the rest was just for Regata’s personal satisfaction.

The second captain’s death signalled the battle turning in the Amazon’s favour, Regata could see from the windswept hill her forces converging on the Commander’s personal forces; hunter, raptor and purifier alike. In a fiery display of arrows, lasers and plasma his forces were quickly put down, leaving the Commander to defiantly fight for his life. In the last few moments his deadly chopper put down unit after unit of hunters before he was cornered by the cavalry, piercing his infernal machine with their glaives until it exploded from underneath him. Before the cavalry could land the killing blow he activated his personal escape teleported and fled the scene. Regata, even if she may not have deserved it, had won this brutal battle. 

Casualty reports were much better than expected to boot, while both forces started out evenly matched, Regata only lost about a third of her forces while the Redeemers lost the entirety. Of course, this dramatic battle was exactly the kind of fun she was looking for, but she obviously wasn’t done. The redeemer cities were now undefended after all, might as well twist the humiliating dagger until it festers.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

10/10, Would have dramatic one on one duel with shotgun wielding borg on a hill again.

God but I wanted to love AoW: Planetfall. High off of the amazing awesomeness of AoW3 which remains, sadly, the high water mark of the series, most things about the presentation of Planetfall are excellent. The graphics and art design would feel right at home in Endless Legend, and the music is as usual by Michiel van den Bos who is an absolute soundtrack LEGEND.

The core mechanics aren't fundamentally bad either, though they're a step back from AoW3. Primarily they [i]are[/i] AoW3's mechanics in the combat section, except they decided to reintroduce missing, which adds a stupid random element to the combat. AoW3 did it better by just having cover and range straight reduce ability effects/damage by a percentage. It also just feels less satisfying than AoW3's combat, in part I think because of all the ranged units. Having mostly melee units in AoW3 made combat feel very much like solving a complex puzzle, and sometimes you could tease out AMAZING victories or K:D ratios just from very clever placement and spell use, but PF seems to allow for less of that.

The strategic map is more or less looted straight from Endless Legend, which isn't fundamentally bad, but suffers from the same issues that EL did, which is that a map of any real size just becomes more of a hassle than fun to work with. Everything about the UI just seems to fight the player by hiding info, often in un-necessary submenus(why do cities need a submenu that you will access at max a total of 4 times in a given city's lifetime? And the strategic play just feels like it's... a bit slower than it has to be. Armies move slow enough to be annoying, construction is slow enough to be annoying, turns tick over slowly enough to be annoying. When I'm already whapping "autofight" rather than playing it out twenty turns into the first mission just to speed things up, you know you've got a problem.

The game is very similar to Endless legend having the same city layout (fixed areas), similar resources and an own hex based combat minigame with the units of your armies while you fight. TL:DR  Age of Wonders: Planetfall is a great fresh take on an already well established series.  It offers a depth of gameplay and tactical satisfaction rarely found in other titles.  The game's steep learning curve may be off putting to some, but if you put in the time to learn the systems and be okay with failure while learning the depth the game offers is well worth the work to learn.

This is an absolute must play for fans of 4x titles such as Civilization or for tactical fans from the XCOM crowd.  



The game is a perfect blend of grand strategy and tactical battles. It can have a bit of a steep learning curve for the uninitiated but the complexity allows the game to be deep enough to hold your interest over the long term.  THe game will require you to be invested in learning its systems to really feel like you know whats going on.  If you want a quick, easy to pick up strategy game, this might not be for you.

Graphically the game is gorgeous.  The units look amazing and the XCOM style battles are my favorite part of the game. 

The sheer amount of combinations you can create to be used in tactical combat is staggering.  Between Your race, which secret tech you choose (basically the equivalent of your school of magic in previous age of wonders titles) the equipment and talents your heros employ or the mods you equip to your units, as well as the combination of units you put in your armies leaves a nearly endless array of strategies to try out. Not to mention combo's of support units damage moves (ranged vs melee) buffs, debuffs, and control abilites to play with.   The 3 action system which allows heavy hiting attacks or abilites to stagger their oppents which removes one action from the defending unit on their next turn makes for a great tactical battle that is far more than the usual rock, paper, scissors systems many strategy games give us.

Without fail it seems every 4x game's detractors complain that "Diplomacy is bad"  I see this as a recurring complaint in the negative reviews but I often wonder what people who always seem to complain about "Bad Diplomacy" are expecting.  The game gives you the ability perform covert operations as well as detect them.  Should you detect such actions you can choose to privately warn the empire at fault or publicly denounce them.  This same warning/denouncing feature is available for each instance of offence the empire has committed against you, from covert operations, to being friendly with your enemies, or disrespecting your claims.  You can also compliment the AI for things they do if you're looking for better relations.  It has the typical trading and deals systems you would expect.  

You can earn Casus Belli against an empire so that declaring war on them is considered justified by your neighbors so that they wont view you as a war monger.  The game even allows you to trade away your Casus Belli with the empire as an act of good faith where you no longer have a justified cause for war in exchange for something else.

I honestly dont know what all these "Diplomacy is terrible" rants are all on about because the diplomacy feels pretty robust. Has some nice improvements over Age of Wonders 3 but also a few questionable design changes.

Planetfall goes for a more rock, paper, scissors approach to combat mechanics unlike in AoW3 where its a linear tiered progression and you spam the highest tier units. Unit diversity and also counters are more prominent here as even low tiered units can be powerful due to their support skills or counters and with higher exp ranks. 

Especially with addition of mods, you can customize individual units with additional stats or skills that can provide low tier units with more utility, fullfill roles and counters unavailable to your race. The correct combinations between unit abilities and mods can make or break a battle encounter. Synergy is of utmost importance. You can turn the weakest tier 1 unit into an unstoppable cheap slave force or convert a useless sniper into a mobile teleporting healer. Unit mods are a welcomed addition, i hope it gets expanded on in the future.

All in all, tactical combat follows X-com style rather than traditional turn based. Dynamic and needs some planning with more focus on unit skills, combos, overwatch and such. AoW3 used to have toned down RNG, basically your RNG is in dmg range and saving throws but in Planetfall, its back to the classic RNG heavy mechanics where you also have to roll for chance to hit. Good and bad, i'm on the fence for this one. Furthermore they've added another layer in the form of terrain, more focus on cover system and terrain hazards, taking cover behind volatile crystals or fuel barrels is not really a good idea. Also little changes like to elevation, certain units(like tanks) on a slope or at the base of a cliff cannot directly hit units above it.

Top tier units like tier 4 are no longer spammable unlike in AoW3, due to costs of said units and its mods and especially upkeep tied to certain scarce resource. In general, smaller armies too as resource production is lower than in AoW3, you wont be able to field too many army stacks. Game encourages retaining units by ranking them up and investing in mods.

Heroes have also been buffed a lot, they are now better at their roles(support, offense etc), usually stronger than even modded units or elites and can be a game changer. Overall they are more useful and play a crucial role.

Really dig the new theme and lore, devs nailed it jumping to the sci-fi setting. Russian dwarf is epic. Cant wait for new races and classes.

Don't like the new sectors system, trying to copy the classic strategic map system like Civ. Unnecessarily complicated but at the same time feels dumbed down. Also feels too restrictive. Needs to be more fleshed out. I prefer area of Influence system in AoW3, more freedom to build your empire and also ability to build roads and outposts(to project influence to grab special resources) have been removed too.

Game UI lacks info. AoW3 did an awesome job, info is easily accessible and everything is transparent.

AoW3 has a much more rich and dense content for their races and classes, including the research and spells, units, skills and the likes. Planetfall kinda falls behind, their tech tree is smaller and compact, kinda repetitive though it does not have the RNG like in AoW3. Also goes the same for the minor factions, neutrals, critters and their units, could use a bigger pool. It can be argued that mods mechanic makes up for it but i really hope for more. Then theres stuff like the removal of the mercenary for hire system etc.

Due to new sector system and removal of underworld layer, game map is much more smaller than in AoW3 even on enormous size setting. Consequently lesser stuff to explore, i find myself lacking dungeons to clear on Planetfall compared to AoW3 even with equivalent settings. 

I liked the underworld layer in AoW3, more playstyle options and adds another strategic layer. Wasted opportunity, devs could have created a Void/Immaterium layer(like in WH40k), moreover the "Void" realm is kinda talked about a lot in Planetfall lore. Would be so cool to have a Void layer with their own unique inhabitants & features...

Early and mid game is really slow. Again due to new sector system in strategic map and short tech trees that have overly inflated research times. And the reduced map size that leaves you with limited exploration opportunities.

I can see balance will be a forever ongoing issue, especially when it comes to multiplayer. Mostly due to the mods mechanics. Can already see huge disparity with certain builds seemingly overpowered. Then again most are due to late game mods and in competitive play, unlikely to go beyond mid game.

Gfx & art is spectacular but they overdid it. Hurts my eyes, colors are too loud and theres too many details. Detailed is good, but too many stuff going on kills it. Like in the tactical and strategic map, you got too many assets and colors strewn across, makes locating units, landmarks, buildings a challenge, very distracting. 

Campaign is lackluster and short lived. Needs more missions and better story telling. To be honest AoW3 did not fare well either in this regard. Planetfall has potential in terms of lore, devs need to exploit this!

Planetfall compared to AoW3, 2 steps forward, then 2 steps back. Cons negates all the pros. A bit disappointed but have hope in future expansions.

54568252.review:
You should read this review because I almost asked for a refund, and now I'm loving Planetfall. 

I'm a sucker for campy sci-fi stories and wanted to hear a bit of the backstory to the Star Union's demise, so I jumped right into the campaign.  Oh, my, gosh, those first few missions were gouge-my-eyes-out boring.  Ooooo, marines with space lasers that shoot other marines with space lasers, weeeeee...  The missions absolutely did not put Planetfall's best foot forward, and this was exacerbated by the fact that they took way too long.  I seriously considered returning the game, I was having so little fun.  It was only my love of Age of Wonders 3 that kept me going, along with my recollection of how much I enjoyed the free-play of that game.

And then it clicked. 

Once you are out of the oppressive mirror matches with low tier Vanguard units, Planetfall is a veritable supernova of cool unit types, fun abilities, and absolutely awesome tactical maps.  There's Different weapon types, melee and ranged strikes, attack strengths, defense powers (the standard "hunker down" is for some units "deploy force field in a 3 tile radius").  There are all kinds of different support abilities.  There's flying and ground units for (I think) all factions.  The heroes are fairly customizeable.  

All of this variety is exemplified by the mod system.  Each unit can hold up to three mods, from your commander to your grunts to your best unit ever.  Being able to upgrade tier 1 units as you progress is pure genius, as it enables the fun aspects of the gameplay and allows you to focus on combat with minimal ferrying back and forth.  This is made all the better by the decision to have every mod give a baseline armor, shield, or damage upgrade.  No longer are you pondering whether you should take the straight damage upgrade or the bleed effect, or whether you should grab the health or the healing ability; you get both inherently!  It really pushes the ability-focused design in a way that I love.  Abilities should not be "me get stronger hit you harder."  Give me something cool! ... and Planetfall did. 

Back to the tactical map design really quickly.  I swear, I have not seen a repeat map yet.  Sure, they all fall into the basic category of "cover here, routes there," but I've played over 50 battles (thank you, annoying Steam achievement pop-up) and each battle has seemed incredibly fresh.  There are elevation differences, explosive terrain, city-scapes, forest battles, battles with void barriers...  It's been awesome.  Oh, and Age of Wonders rather annoying "the independents get a powerful ability at every site" has been reworked to allow you fight a battle before the battle to turn it off.  Great move!  

Bottom line: Planetfall is a tactical turn-based masterpiece.  

Of course, this is tacked on to the solid if fairly benign 4X overworld map.  To Planetfall's credit, I spend 80% of my time worrying about my armies, only going to my colonies to check on production when necessary.  You can min-max workers if you want, but its not a necessity a-la Stellaris or Civ.  The tech tree is also incredibly meaty - perhaps too much so for some, but as a guy who plays Endless Space, I don't find it nearly as overbearing as those games.  

At this point, I would highly recommend this game.  For what the developer lacks in their open salvo of storytelling, they more than make up in their gameplay and mechanics.

A quick public service announcement in closing: turn off sector outlines by default and set them to toggle on a hot-key.  The map is GORGEOUS when they are off and very busy when they are on; better to use them only when you need them.

54564355.review:
I have decided to cut this game some slack and after a period of in-game experimentation and testing I managed to overcome my initial dislike and found it fun and deep - if only in some of its aspect.

4X genre classification had overstayed its welcome and nowadays comprises such a ridiculous amount of completely different titles.This makes comparing this game to others in its genre sometimes missleading, if not outright confusing. 

If you are interested in this title main thing you should know is that this game is heavily combat focused. It delivers in this area, but it does so at the expense of other gameplay mechanics, mainly strategic map macro management  - which you might be looking for in a "4X" title. 

Yes there is some, it is also not completely meaningless and at least in sufficient multitude to allow several builds optimized for specific purpose to exist...but ultimately all this serves to better prepare for rich tactical combat experience, main focus of this game. 

I am a sucker for min-maxing. When I buy new strategic game I spent a lot of time restarting the game and experimenting with various starting builds and available options (because Byzantines ARE going to beat Ottomans in EUIV after "couple" of attempts :P). It was not obvious at the beginning and the game tutorial does not exactly help explaining how things work, but I have found plethora of efficient and completely different combinations, which led to rich and refreshing (combat-focused) gameplay experience - because yay, more options!

I have seend multiple reviewers complain about bland and unified tech-tree and I really had to giggle pretty hard, because this game have pretty bog standard (in unexciting) approach to teching. In turn-based/realtime-pause games you have usually two main ways how to approach tech tree. You either have completely different tech tree for each faction, but there are next to zero modification options for the actual units (Total War Warhammer, Heroes of M+M) OR you have similiar tech tree for every faction, but you have plethora of modification options for individual units (Stellaris, Endless Franchise). Because the depth is never present in first pick of hundred different options, but in subsequent of combinations of said options. You may have similiar tech for every faction - but those factions have units with different abilities and damage channels, so combinations of mentionned tech are completely different for them.

Or did you not know, that you can take synth +crit mod, then do Paragon quest line, take their mod for +crit, then take mod that increases range, then put it on a ranged unit with repeatable attacks, and because crit procs and the first attack and then applies for all attack of that unit, you will crit with every shot in your full attack, even if you base chance to hit was low, if you manage to roll crit, you will obliterate superior enemy units at max range. Naturally you also had your strategic dmg buff active and then you also activated your tactical dmg buff (if you stack everything as mentionned you will be surprised what can sniper hero one-shot), right?

Or did you not know, that you can take your faction-generic laser unit, give it mod which reduces resistance to burning attacks (basically dungeons and dragons DC vs saving throw),then combine it with promethean tech specific units and wreak havoc on enemy frontline.  Enemy elite unit with high dmg reduction? Nope, melted in one turn. This work also for other damage channels and can be used to reduce enemy defenses to apply status effects (debuffs).You have naturally chosen laser unit with repeatable attacks, so you get more procs at defense reduction right? You can for example rush tank "mount" for your vanguard hero for this purpose - choose veteran trait, get lvl 8 asap to pick advanced driving, have tank researched in military tech (does not take too long) - you do not need to build tank building, hero can equip it immediately.

Or did you not know, that you can combine smoke with psynumbra accuracy reduction aura and rush enemy frontline to render their unit worthless? You did also apply tactical accuracy reduction from psynumbra operation on said unit because it stacks, right? Or perhaps you used other obscured enabler like nanite tactical operation with obscure aura? You also used close combat hero with martial tradition to get in the middle of enemy frontline unschathed right? Trick is to run with said hero until you have your last action remaining, then use your ranged units to soften closest enemy, then you finish him with your secondary ranged attack on your hero - ta daa, action points refunded thx to martial traditions, stack up debuff auras and run into middle of their units and start carnage.

Just a couple of pointers, so you have easier exploration at the beginning if you choose to delve into this game. It is what it is - combat oriented strategy game with deep tactical concept at the expense of strategic one, which lets you explore multitude of available combinations without trying to actually explain anything to you - which might be frustrating to some, but was in the end enjoyable to me.

And now for something compeltely different:

Reading reviews, you have likely seen this game compared up and down to the Civ and Xcom series.  This game does have similarities to both, but I found the unit customization to be most similar to Endless Legends. That is what this review details on.

Ignoring many reviews claiming this game has very little content, I went ahead and purchased it based on my great opinion of, and 500+ hours in, AoW 3. This is a VERY different game, but I love what they have done with it.

The freedom you have with customizing your units goes beyond changing their attack or defence stats. You are able to change in-combat abilities, damage types, single target/AOE attacks, and more. The one thing the game does not allow you to change is the default weapon of normal units, but the damage amount, damage type, weapon range, and other factors can be altered with mods. This effectively leaves you with a different weapon (IMHO) even if you can't "actually" change it. An example of this would be attaching an incindiary ammo mod to a unit with a machine gun, changing the damage type and giving an AoE attack instead of a single unit attack. This limitation does not apply to hero units, which are able to use any weapon you choose, including vehicles like tanks or pterodactyl looking animals with (queue Dr. Evil's voice) frickin laser beams on their heads.

ONE WORD OF WARNING: I started this game with a fair bit of knowledge of Civ, AoW3, Xcom, and Endless Legends. If you do not have experience with some of these games, the amount of information thrown at you (without explanation) can be daunting. That being said, I have always found a steep learning curve generally leads to a game you can enjoy for quite a long time.

I am very torn on where I fall on this game.  As a fan of the particular games AoW3, Stellaris and CK2 I WANT to be able to recommend this game; however, the step backwards/lack of content on this and the lack of content in Imperator: Rome seems to be indicative of a new basic premise at Paradox as a publisher.  That being charge full price for a shell of a game and then charge $20 a pop to add basic features/content.  I'm sorry but in this day and age of disruption yes people expect your NEXT game in a series to have almost all of the content/features of the previous one post DLC, not half as much as on the previous one's release.  Let's look at some specific issues I have:

1.  No real variation in how any of the races play.
     Every race here plays essentially the same.  There are no interesting or unique mechanics that make any of the races stand out.  The Kir'Ko play identical to the Vanguard who play identical to the Amazons, which play no different than the Assembly.  Oh don't get me wrong there is some minor variations here and there in some of the things they do, such as the Dvar being able to build their own cover in battle, but overall they play identical as evidenced that their research trees are largely the same.

     It would have been nice to have seen something like the Undead in AoW3 that expanded by rebuilding razed towns, or the Total War Warhammer series where each race plays significantly differently with different research, methods to accomplish their goals, etc.  Such is not the case here where a tank is a tank is a tank, and the different races largely spread across the planet in the same way.  All of the variation is purely from a story telling aspect.

and that brings us to a related critique

2.  No real interesting decisions.
     There is never any point in time where you have to make a choice between A and B that has real extensive repercussions.  Sure there is the occasional 'Wipe out the humans or not, WARNING THIS WILL HAVE LONG TERM EFFECTS' but they really don't none that actually matter.  I get that there are many reasons people play games, but the thing I always liked about 4x and strategy games in general is the interesting decisions that come up, and the stories that those decisions create.  Here unfortunately there is no such decisions and no such story.  It is so bland and bare bones with no real decision making that it is simply not that interesting.

       Don't get me wrong there is a TON of 'content', the research tree is huge but  3/4 of it at any given time is mostly pointless.  There are tons of units, but they are all largely the same and all largely fill the same basic roles with not variation beyond 'archer a bit more powerful, armor but a bit more powerful'.  It all does the same work for the most part, and the customization through mods, while nice, essentially comes down purely to a 'throw the highest tier mod you got on to boost the unit strength and move on' with the functioning of the mods not really making a difference.

And that's my 2 cents.  It has promise, but the lack of being able to meet the level of content/completeness of a post DLC game from five years ago, and the complete lack of interesting decisions means I simply can't recommend it.  Perhaps when they've dome some content patches and refined it such as Paradox has done with Stellaris (which I can forgive as it was their first space 4x) I will be able to recommend it but until that happens I say save your money and wait for a sale.

This game is a prime example of taking a formula that works and destroying it by heaping on complexity. You're constantly assaulted with excessive amounts of information, to the point that it saps the fun out of the game and makes every decision mentally exhausting. And there's no small number of decisions

For example, completing research is something I constantly dread, because it means I'll have to figure out what to research next.

In Planetfall, you're faced with at least 4 (often upwards of 8-10) different options, each option containing 2-4 different benefits, each benefit containing a paragraph long description. That's up to 40 different paragraphs of text you need to read and compare. To make matters worse, the UI doesn't allow you to read all of the benefits associated with the option in a single place; instead, you have to mouse over each benefit individually, which makes it even harder to process what you're getting. And there are two parallel research trees, so after finally reading through the 40 paragraphs and deciding which set of benefits you want, you have to do it all over again with a completely different set of options.

The unit modding system suffers from the same problem. Mods are thrown at you left and right, and each mod comes with a wall of text. You end up in a situation where you're comparing a dozen different walls of text, then repeating the process for each of the three slots, and then repeating that process for each of your different unit types. The end result is that you just start ignoring mods, because you don't want to spend the time and energy figuring out what to equip.

I've logged hundreds of hours in the various Age of Wonders games, but I can't even manage to play a single scenario of Planetfall for more than an hour before losing all interest.

[b]Overall[/b]: 2+/5 (A delicious cocktail mixing 4x with turn based tactical combat that's actually fun, but you don't want to look too closely at every single ingredient.)

Planetfall has extremely strong visuals and mostly good UI, but a terrible soundscape and atrocious writing. It has great tactical combat, cool operations and an accessible simulation, but the campaign is slow and tedious. Alas, the rating gets dragged down by its more unfortunate elements, but Planetfall is a case in which the good more than outweights the bad and "objective" numbers don't tell the real story. For me, Planetfall outruns the beautiful, excellent and extremely well-written Endless series on the back of its accessibility and combat system.


[b]Presentation[/b]: 2/5 
Sometimes masterful, sometimes dreadful.

[u]Visual[/u]: 5-/5
+ Genius colour palette that manages to be unique, bright and lively while provinding enough contrast to remain readable.
+ Right amount of detail and good model sizes.
+ Resulting in the most beautiful campaign maps of any 4x game.
+ Nice Unit models.
+ Overall coherent design language.
- Underwhelming combat and operations animations.
- City buildings are not represented on the campaign map.

[u]Audio[/u]: 1/5
+ Synthwave wibes fit the general aesthetics.
- But overall weak soundtrack that doesn't contribute to the atmosphere.
- Hollow sound effects.
- No distinct button effect sounds for different actions or for select/execute.
- Few voicelines.

[u]UI/UX[/u]: 4-/5
+ Clear icon design and generally clean interface.
+ Good map readability.
+ Most informations are easily and intuitively accessible.
- Weird HUD choices that overrepresents design elements that don't relay much information. Text often is positioned at the bottom of the screen, exactly the opposite of where it needs to be. Hurts the damn neck.
- Rigid camera angle.
- Tech trees are awkward scrollbar hell, and the font & icons are too small (a common issue with 4x/grand strategy games).
- Weapon effects descriptions are buried in the (ingame) manual.

[u]Writing[/u]: 1-/5
+ Clear faction identities, iconic choices.
- Resulting in uninspired trope execution.
- Atrocious dialogue.
- Overly cheesy ("Dvar", wth?).
- SMAC style tech descriptions that range from cringeworthy to pointless and utterly fail to enrich the lore of the setting or create a specific atmosphere.
- Uses the bare minimum of exposition dumps to move the campaign plot along.


[b]Gameplay[/b]: 3-/5 
Good and accessible, does not burden itself with too much complexity and lets the player have fun with the mechanics. Planetfall is very much geared towards the tactical combat. Unfortunately, the campaign is severely lacking in everything.

[u]Simulation[/u]: 4/5 
+ Balanced progression system.
+ Growth model allows for some amount of catch-up.
+ Unit upgrades are often sidegrades rather than straight upgrades, resulting in sane amounts of power creep (looking at you, Endless Legend).
+ Operations are so cool and help setting the factions/playstyles apart so well they should become the standard for 4x games.
+ Generous economics, does not arbitrarily restrict the player with anti-fun mechanics (looking at you, Stellaris).
+ City/Sector separition makes things much more manageble while adding a new and interesting gameplay layer.
+ Absorbing other factions actually gives you some of their tech choices.
+ Very accessible.
- But city building lacks in variety.
- "Doomsday Weapons" don't bring enough doom.

[u]Tactical Combat[/u]: 4-/5
+ Very diverse unit types and everyone has a special ability.
+ Mods matter and always do more than simply giving you a +X% on some stat.
+ Yet things appear to be balanced, but that's hard to tell as there are very few AIs out there that can actually threaten the player.
- Enemies are seemingly randomized and not created to present specific challanges, even in the campaign.
- Very few straight forward units. Even the bugs have ranged attacks.
- There is simply too much of it. Way too much.

[u]Campaign[/u]: 2-/5
+ Parallel storytelling and mission objectives are pretty cool and the right choice for a 4x campaign.
+ Has you play not only as different factions, but with different secret weapon combinations.
- Pacing is way too slow. Too much pointless combat, too much space on the maps and not enough content within each mission.
- Other factions barely react to what you do, almost no scripted dialogue/events.
- Uninspired plot. Harsh transitions. Characters are rather blant and don't get explored very much.

Game is superficially similar to AoW3, but the differences are more substantial than first glance suggests and the game is much better for it.

The sector system is more detailed and satisfying than 3's somewhat drab domain expansion, but is still easy to manage - it doesn't steal the show, but it offers much more exciting choices than "how many structures can I fit in this fort".

The diplomacy is more fleshed out, both between players and with NPC factions.  Between the new 'influence' resource, covert operations, casus belli mechanics and trustworthiness, there's much more game in manipulating the map's diplomatic landscape to suit you than was present in 3.

The combat and unit depth are where the game especially shines.  AoW3 was poor in this regard - even after updates improved racial diversity, the differences between races were comparitively minor and you broadly played similarly no matter what you were running.  In planetfall, every race plays combat completely differently, with a host of different synergies, advantages and weaknesses - expanded further by secret tech and mod selection.  I get the same kind of satisfaction exploring a certain playstyle in planetfall as I would e.g. playing a different faction in a card game, and that's something 3 never really offered me.

I'm having more fun with the campaign in planetfall.  Three's campaigns were fairly linear, the stories weren't particularly grabby, and I generally had more fun playing random maps.  Planetfall's campaign maps are still random, and let you customize your start, and still manage to tell interesting stories exploring each of the races.  There's a fair bit of choice in how you play out each scenario with regards to how you treat the other factions, making each map much like a normal game, but the flavour response to how you act makes it that much more engaging.  

Downsides?
Game's not winning any awards for its UI.  It's servicable, and not much more.  Often I'd appreciate having x info visible while making a decision, and there's no way to get to it easily.  Often I'd like to be able to click an NPC faction's emblem to enter diplomacy, and it doesn't.  Some tooltips are just missing from where you'd expect them.  Triumph have shown they're willing to work on the UI in updates, however.

I would've preferred a little more asymmetry on the strategic layer.  Every player scouts the same way, colonizes and annexes the same way, builds 95% the same buildings, has the same covert ops.  All the incredible variation in the combat instantly evaporates once it ends.  I really think there could be more done here.

The whole AoW format is still an awkward fit in multiplayer.  They've certainly tried, with multiplayer allowing you to seamlessly switch between concurrent multiplayer and native PBEM.  There are 'combat cards' that optionally limit players' use of manual combat.  Nevertheless, if you're playing multiplayer and want to enjoy the manual combat - the game's entire reason to be - in a climactic siege against another player, everyone else is going to have to get up and leave for half an hour.  Perhaps worse, this makes multiplayer a real struggle when players are playing the game or a given race for the first time.  Unless they're allowed to manual combat some trivial AI battles (which will really slow everything down) they'll have no idea how to effectively control their army once the fights start to matter.  If your friends aren't already solid 4X fans who'll be willing to invest hours into playing solo to learn the game, this is going to be a hard sell.  Still, if you're playing with just a couple and willing to be patient, it can still be a good time.

 You still can costumize your hero in fair lot of ways. The playstile is now more dependent on the pick of the race and the secret tech. They are no gimmics but core elements of the game. This three parts together are still complex. For example: in Age of wonders 3 you got your units out from the rooster of the race in combination with your class. 54536614.review:
[H1]Soapbox Time! Good game, bad content practices.[/H1]

Planetfall reminds me a lot of Evolve. That's not a good memory to have. Where the game itself is actually very good but because of idiot marketing decisions you never feel like you've quite got the complete game. Evolve had so many possible pre-order versions that it was like trying to navigate the Crystal Maze and figure out which door got you closest to the finished product, and then purchasing the rest of the bits piecemeal.

Here you had a similar problem, bits of cosmetic content locked behind a time limited newsletter, bits of cosmetic content tied to pre-orders, bits of cosmetic content tied to a deluxe version, a planetary scenario (which turns out to be one of the five "officially listed" scenarios) locked to the deluxe or top version. So like, [i]really?[/i]. EDIT: The commanders that come as base do not use any DLC cosmetics. I'm not sure about random generated.

The game itself is good. Not great. But good. I suspect it will be great when Triumph eventually get around to finishing it some three expansions down the line. What we have here is a typical Paradox product. The core is well put together, but it's just that. The Core. This is not the complete experience. We'll get that and when we do it'll be magnificent, but you'll have to pay extra for that.

[H1]Paradox, this has to stop. It's time we talked about this.[/H1]

I get it. Your long term support of games is legendary. But Stellaris was a case in point. When it came out it was a mess, a buggy, confused, chaotic mess. There was a lot of promise and potential under the hood, and it had original ideas (some of which you've murdered on the altar of efficiency), It's become a much more mature and complete game as you've added to it, but once again, the cost of entry and the cost of what you need to make the damn thing what it is now are two very different things. Let's not get into Crusader Kings 2, that thing is a nightmare if you've not been fortunate enough to get the DLC on a sale.

Planetfall is slated for three expansions, by the end of which I strongly suspect we'll see how the game is supposed to feel like with everything it's supposed to have. Six factions and six secret techs is not exactly a bounty of options, and when you get into the meat of the game those secret techs just feel like different damage types as opposed to anything really ground shaking. Where's the cool tech specific buildings? I get that Age of Wonders games have been predominantly all about the units and making them unique and interesting but given there's been additional focus on making city development more significant with the advent of sectors it feels like one side got significantly more care than the other.

[H1]The way to win feels very defined, and being creative whilst welcomed at the micro level, is punished at the macro.[/H1]

You end up with a lot of units that overlap each other because your racial and your tech dump a lot of units out and if you want to blend the pair to max your hero potential you'll end up with similar damage paths for both tech and race. There's precious little to really make races stand out except for these ethereal "doctrines" which are passive buffs in the main. The real issue is your Commander defines your primary damage path and you're going to want to max that since then you get all the useful benefits from following the tree (so making sure you throw out lots of pyro toting units if you're running a promethean commander).

Running different *types* of commanders sounds like a good idea until you realise it puts you at a research disadvantage for your doomsday weapon victory path, so taking on non specced commanders means you'll only invest in those at a minimal level.

This game could have stood to have learned from Endless Legend in some aspects, such as integrating minor races (as opposed to just buying units from their leaders or only being able to integrate from their leading colony), and having more, and more diverse minor races as a result. The city building side is *nearly* there but again, lessons from Endless Legend would have been really helpful.

The area where Planetfall shines is tactical combat, where once again large scale battles can result in brilliant, drawn out tactical battles, and where individual units can be god damned heroes. AoW 3 before it shined in this regard, and that element hasn't dimmed, you just wish it had learned from other games to get the other small elements right.

And you wish Paradox had learned not to make their content model so opaque and unpleasant.

[H1]Closing thoughts[/H1]

It's good. It's held back from being great from a paucity of content and Paradox once again proving what you get in the box isn't the finished product, and due to the vagaries of pre-orders, various editions and time limited content campaigns, you may not even get everything even if you try.

The game marches very strongly in combat, but the stuff outside of it feels very much hollow, this was forgivable in AoW 3, it's *less* forgivable now. This is something that I had issues with previously, now it becomes a legitimate complaint. If Triumph decide to make another Age of Wonders, this is now something that -needs addressing-, because the empire management side feels perfunctory and misses elements that would make it feel more viable.

Verdict: [b]Recommend, on discount - How much of a discount depends on you.[/b]

54520867.review:
If you enjoyed Age of Wonders 3, then you will like this game.  It is similar enough to 3 that it should be fairly easy to get into, but also has enough new things to be both deeper and more interesting and provide a new experience.  If you have never played an Age of Wonders game or 4X in general, this is still a solid turn based strategy to dive into.

Pros
- High quality graphics with a broad color palette
- Solid music and sound effects
- Sector system makes the world feel valuable and gives deeper, more meaningful choices to expansion and warfare (Annex, Colonize, or make a Forward Base are all meaningful decisions for each sector)
- Unit modding and gear options are a lot deeper than 3 and makes even low tier units viable in the mid to late game
- World Gen... the maps for this game are pretty, and flow together nicely to feel like an alien world
- Passive scanner (this makes things like finding barbarian camps in the fog a lot easier, and means you aren't likely to have a marauding stack run in from the fog of war and cap an unguarded town in a single turn).
- New and Improved minor Factions that eventually become mututally exclusive
- Improved Diplomacy (from previous titles), Cassus Belli and claiming mechanics

Neutral
- Lack of a few freedoms from previous titles (i.e. building roads... they are now automatically made in owned sectors)
- Unit classification isn't as straight forward as in AoW 3 (fewer broad non-function based titles in Planetfall, instead of more specialized but easily understandable titles from AoW 3... i.e. Planetfall has a Core type, where as AoW 3 would have Archer, Infantry, or Pikeman as types... which type tells more about that unit from a glance?)
- Multiple science trees is fresh for the series, but players will likely quickly decide on optimal build paths, making decisions here less interesting.  This could be improved on by semi-randomization or other methods to mix up the fixed research trees (other 4X games have used the "pick one of many options" method where some or all tiers of research have mutually exclusive choices that makes it so players have to make important choices between tech options that impact an entire game).  This could even be an option at game creation (fixed trees vs. semi-random or pool system like 3).

Cons
- UI feels a bit cluttered in some places and some art choices make things not obvious to find or are hidden in menus
- No more dual/tri layer maps (AoW 3 had the underground layer, and AoW Shadow Magic had both the underground and the shadow realm in addition to the overworld map)... maybe one of the future DLCs can bring back this feature... this game being sci-fi, adding a space layer with ships and maybe even other planets or asteroids could bring a unique flavor to this
- No dungeons (mid to end game points of interest on the map housing some of the more challenging and rewarding fights in the game)

One of the nuances of the Age of Wonders series as a whole is that they tend to lean more towards the combat side of strategy and less towards things like diplomacy and espionage than other 4X games, making previous entries feel much more 4X-lite.  This title, while still having that combat leaning feels like more of the other "X"s to the 4X are fleshed out and more interesting than previous titles.  That said, I wouldn't mind a bit more depth to diplomacy and more non-combat interactions between players (human and AI), it's a new direction for the game to grow in (and it has made some good steps that way with this title).

Very thouroughly enjoying this game. It's a mid complexity grand strategy, not going as far out as say Crusader King or Hearts of Iron, but upping the complexity since Age of Wonders 3. The shift in setting from fantasy to scifi is an interesting one as well. As someone who prefers fantasy over scifi, but is open to either this game really has hit the sweet spot with me as it has something of a scifi fantasy going for it. The game itselves improves on a few of the failings of Age of Wonders 3 and has some unique and cool ideas in the way of sectors, but it also more heavily pushes faction uniqueness which is something I am very much a fan of.

Faction diversity is at an all time high in this installment of the Age of Wonders franchise from the insect like Kir'ko and their swarm mechanic, to the drone oriented human Vanguards to the crime houses of the Syndicate who dwell in slavery and subjugation, and so on. All the factions are diverse and have their own unique strengths. I hope to see Triumph keep pushing these diversity quality with future releases.

Gameplay itself is solid. The strategic map has it's strengths with wildlife, hazards, locations of interest and pick ups (some with some minor CYOA experiences). The choices of building and build order can be a mix of linear and strategical choice (some buildings you have to get, some are more of a strategic choice) and exploring is a big factor to the game. Diplomacy can be tricky to pull off, but when done right it can be very rewarding. Sometimes choices done by AI in diplomacy can be a bit counterproductive (they are struggling against an opponent and you offer to help them out and they still won't accept), but those moments are very rare and far apart. All in all I would say the strategic map gameplay is done well.

Combat aspect of the game is fantastic. It truelly feels tactical (and lethal if you don't play smart). You have to make maximum use of positioning, unit roles, unit abilities, tactical operations and terrain. A single mistake can cost you a unit. There is insane diversity in the units one can have access to, and each unit feel unique in their combat role, but on top of that you have the modification system which lets you mod your units to become more tanky, more damage dealer, give them support abilities or entirely new (and near magical) abilities like calling in a psionic storm. This really gives each unit a lot of depth and I would compare the combat to xcom in a bigger scale. The fact that each unit also rank up and get's better (and in some cases more unique traits and top rank) makes you invested in the units you have. The combat is to me the biggest strength of the game.

This is a terrific 4X game and I would highly recommend it. It can be a bit difficult in the beginning and there is a lot to take inn, but once you have it is an incredible deep game experience that you shouldn't miss out on.

Disclaimer: I was given a free copy of the game, but I elected to buy the game regardless and gave away the free copy I was given. A lot of my experience with the game is prior to release and updated after release.

Description:
Game is cross between AlphaCentauri/Beyond Earth with Civilization + XCOM. 4X but with interesting turn based tactical combat in the map during a fight (looks similar to XCOM but little bit simplified). It also has some RPG mechanisms as you can upgrade your hero/leader and change it visuals. 

Visuals:
Graphics are nice, animations on the main map are fluid, there is lots of stuff going on around on the map, it looks very alive - even during combat phase, when you have your team on the field. Did not notice any issues with the game in general.

Gameplay: 
Expansion is based on researching 2 types of technologies - Military and Society. They are being extended in sub categories (some kind of boosts) that you can enable during the campaign, and every researched technology gives u mods/weapon or some buildings to be build. You can choose several specializations for your main character (like biological warfare or some other - based on other technologies). Every colony (city) can be created and extended by surrounding sub-sectors. Nice idea in general as You can not create city next to the city so you will have some kind of a chain of colonies connected by sub-sectors and roads (roads are created automatically). Sectors are similar to Civilization tiles, but way bigger, and they also extend borders of your colony city that they are part of, you can choose to assimilate sector or create base in it if you dont have enough colonists.

Another nice feature is creating templates for your units, templates can be applied automatically to all of them so it lowers the amount of micromanagement. Every unit can be modded/upgraded with researched technology. There is a lot of replayability - I already started campaign 5x and every time it looked a little bit different. It plays like any typical 4x, with some fresh looks here and then so its not boring. I assume it will be upgraded with the DLCs (its Paradox after all) and free content - but this time Paradox learned its mistakes and did not release empty shell (like in case of Imperator:Rome) - so even now game has enough content to keep you busy. Its fresh, its nice, its interesting - so if you like 4X genre this is something you should have in your collection. 

Totally recommended!!!
