54506823.review:
I don't usually write reviews on games for which I have so little playtime.  In my opinion, a review should come from a perspective of thorough understanding—sometimes it is difficult to fully comprehend flaws or brilliance in design until you have played a game for a while.  After all, what could I possibly have to say about a game that I played for less than an hour? 

Quite a lot, apparently. 

As a disclaimer, I won't pretend that this is a complete review.  It picks at a few very specific aspects of the game that really destroyed any chance I had of enjoying the experience.  I really wrestled with whether to even write this.  I gave myself time to cool down.  I went to bed, woke up, and headed to work.  Now, sitting at my computer in my office, I haven't cooled off one bit.  I'm still annoyed, and I need to get this out.  If you are completely new to the [i]Age of Wonders[/i] franchise, or you don't care at all about multiplayer gameplay, maybe consider passing on this review.  I don't think it will serve you particularly well. 

Still here?  Well, then.  First, a bit of tedious history.  I may be dating myself, but I still have clear memories of the day, nearly twenty years ago, when I first played [i]Age of Wonders[/i].  At the time, I was practically addicted to [i]Heroes of Might and Magic III[/i], but I hadn't yet found my way to Sid Meier's [i]Civilization[/i] franchise.  Therefore, a lot of [i]Age of Wonder's[/i] mechanics were entirely new to me.  

I thought it was great.  I played it for hours at a time.  I would listen to the music and read the lore on the unit description pages.  Eventually, I played the game so much that it became rote—I knew the AI's tendencies, its weaknesses and patterns, and how to exploit them.  Winning was just a matter of solving a puzzle.  I became bored.  With fond memories, I put the game away, with no real desire to ever play it again.  I was 11 years old at the time. 

As time passed and I grew older, I would often think back on my experience with [i]Age of Wonders[/i] and (pardon the pun) wonder what had happened.  Why was it that I grew bored with the game in a way that I never did with [i]Heroes III[/i]?  As my tastes and understanding of gaming evolved, I realized the answer:  I played [i]Heroes III[/i] with friends.  My friends challenged me in ways that the AI never did.  I had to understand the game—truly understand it, not just know how to outsmart the feeble AI—in order to stand a chance of beating them.  The more we played, the better and better we got.  There were tactics and counter-tactics.  Feints.  Rushes.  

I never did convince any of my friends to play [i]Age of Wonders[/i].  No fault on the game; it was just circumstance. 

Fast forward to 2014.  Fifteen years of experiences had left me jaded.  The stories and lore no longer titillated in the way they once had.  The music was all on YouTube.  But even so, having skipped over all of the various permutations of [i]Age of Wonders II[/i], I was pleased to hear about the release of [i]Age of Wonders III[/i].  This time, I railroaded my friends into buying the game with me.  I was ready to enjoy a new, fresh multiplayer experience. 

We quickly ran into an obstacle.  "Simultaneous turns," a convenience which decades of fast-paced multiplayer games had left us ill-suited to do without, apparently did not include combat.  In fact, not only could two players not conduct combat simultaneously, but [i]everyone[/i] had to wait on the person who was in battle.  You couldn't do [i]anything[/i], not even take a look at your unit tiers or hero abilities.  Oh, you could also watch the other person's combat . . . thus potentially revealing the disposition of their units and their hero abilities.  That made a lot of sense.  

You can imagine how this could get out of hand with more than two players.  Sure, you could just auto every combat, but what's the point of that?  We were definitely disappointed.  No small amount of mockery was directed my way for having been the person who instigated the entire debacle.  Humiliated, I consoled myself by trying to play single player, only to find that it was . . . boring.  I wasn't that wide-eyed 11-year-old anymore, to be impressed by lore or the soundtrack.  I wanted [i]gameplay[/i] . . . and that was lacking.  Within a couple of games, I was destroying the AI on the hardest difficulty.  Overall, while it was a competent game, it felt like a weaker title than the original [i]Age of Wonders[/i], which shocked me.  After 15 years and multiple sequels, surely they could do better?  With a heavy heart, I shelved the game. 

Almost five more years later, enter [i]Age of Wonders:  Planetfall[/i].  I didn't bat an eye at the title.  Now beyond jaded, I couldn't care less as to whether the game took place in fantasyland or in space.  It could take place in South Africa for all I care.  [i]Just show me a good game.[/i]  Once again, I rallied the troops, convincing a friend to play with me on release day.  I didn't question that our multiplayer issue from last time would be fixed.  Plenty of people had complained about it before, and this was five years later.  There was no "early access" nonsense, this was a full release.  Of [i]course[/i] it would be fixed.  I didn't even bother asking.

We didn't bother with the tutorial.  We just jumped right into a multiplayer game.  Despite some people complaining of launch issues, we seemed good to go.  I was able to easily jump into my friend's game and we made our blind selections of faction, hero, and secret technology.  Everything was going smoothly.  I played my first turn, saw a nearby resource node guarded by some enemies, and sent my hero and his army to claim it.  Oblivious that anything untoward might be happening, I set about my self-appointed task:  the massacre of the independents that were standing on my resources.  That was when it happened. 

"Are you in combat?"  I hear the question, and my heart sinks.  I know what it means.  But I don't want to believe it. 

"Yes," I answer cautiously.  "Why?" 

"I can't do anything."

No!  Not again!  I'm simply blown away.  How?  How could they have done it?  Surely there is some mistake.  We quit out of the game and go to check the settings to make sure that we didn't miss the option to turn on simultaneous combat.  No such option exists.  I check the discussion board, and sure enough, the question has been asked and answered by a developer representative, who essentially says, "it was too difficult to bother with." 

My friend took one for the team and continued playing until it was too late for him to refund the game (though he surely tried after about four hours), so I do have some idea of how the game plays.  There's hardly anything new to see here.  It feels like someone slapped a futuristic skin over [i]Age of Wonders III[/i].  My friend was playing on the hardest difficulty, and before I had to stop watching and go to bed, I got the feeling that he was winning pretty handily.  Sure, there are a few tweaks and features here and there, but it doesn't matter at all.  The AI is . . . well, a computer, and the multiplayer doesn't work.  Where's the fun?  

I'm aware that some people will disagree with me on this.  That's okay.  To each their own, and if you enjoy battling the AI in single player, more power to you.  I just don't think there's any longevity in this title.  There's no challenge, no innovation, no soul.  Simultaneous combat was "too difficult" to implement? 54503580.review:
Disclaimer: Volunteer beta tester for Planetfall but *not* an employee of either Triumph or Paradox. More than 500hrs playtime with the beta build. 

It'd be easy to go on a long tirade but what it comes down to with Planetfall is a huge amount of customization, combinations and permutations in its gameplay. When you start thinking about all the possible combinations of races, secret tech, mods, NPC faction units and mods, commander traits, hero weapons and equipment, operations and map factors your mind begins to race with all the possibilities.

It's an awesome game not just for people who enjoy turn based strategy but even more so for those who enjoy coming up with different "builds", it's almost like an rpg in that way and the visual customization in Commander Creation certainly rivals character creation in many actual rpgs. 

Maybe you want a multi-racial Syndicate slave army that absorbs other races (peacefully or not), puts slave collars on their units, make them cheaper with the Indentured Contracts doctrine and then buffs, or even ressurrects them, with slave empowering support units while at the same time playing nice with neutral factions and establishing relations with them that are both peaceful and profitable. 

Or maybe you play with Synthesis tech, get friendly with the plant based Growth faction, get a bunch of Vine Bud units, put mods on them that allow them to regenerate, resurrect after dying and summon tiny aggressive "daemon" robots and then proceed to summon slews of tentacled vines, that can also regenerate and resurrect because they inherit those mods from the Vine Bud, tiny robots that can take over mechanical units upon death and then you use the Network Link unit to refresh Vine Buds' abilities to summon more vines and tiny robots and THEN as your enemies start to die the Network Link strips away their consciousness to refresh its refreshing ability which it uses to refresh the Vine Buds to make MORE vines and tiny robots. 

Maybe you could also give your entire army extra shielding and regeneration via tactical operations but that'd be crazy, right? :) I know this sounds confusing but it's a thing, I promise.

Or maybe you play a fiery Promethean Amazon whose Arborean Queens entangle whole armies allowing you to drop canisters of explosive, choking gas on them while preventing them from moving out of it. 

Of course you can always go for the classic tanks and artillery creeping barrage. 

There is also stealth, espionage, diplomacy, dire penguins, doomsday victory conditions, colony management, exploration and eldritch horrors and they all play into this buffet of gameplay options. 

My advice to new players is to read the tooltips, look at the unit info cards, take the time to understand unit abilities and how they interact. Gradually it will all click into place. 

Unlike in previous games Planetfall's tactical combat can now be fully played in asynchronous multiplayer, a.k.a. "play-by-email", no need to use auto-combat for PvP unless you want to. Sure, matches can take a very long time like this but you can play them at your leasure with no time pressure and if all players happen to be online at the same time you can seamlessly switch to direct multiplayer and then go back to asynchronous later. For the first time ever Age of Wonders multiplayer gets to have its cake and eat it too.

54500749.review:
(Note: I have 60+ hours in a pre-release version)

Age of Wonders 3 (AoW3) has been my favorite 4X game since it’s release back in 2014. So it comes as no surprise that Planetfall is in position to eclipse it. The setting in Planetfall, coupled with a lacing of Triumphs tongue-in-cheek humor (dinosaurs with lasers, finally!) makes this title standout in a big way. All things being equal, I love a good sci-fi setting (more than fantasy), and so Planetfall is destined to appeal.

Thankfully, Triumph Studios has crafted Planetfall’s mechanics and gameplay systems with the same thoroughness, attention to detail, and eye towards challenging gameplay that has been a hallmark of the entire Age of Wonders series. The factions are varied in lore and aesthetics, and when coupled with secret technologies provides scores of different unit, mod, and ability combinations to experiment with. All of the strategic dimensions of the game funnel into a best-in-class tactical combat system that feels even richer than AoW3’s already exceptional system. Bigger combat maps, more varied terrain, tons of unit abilities and synergies.

The empire management side of the game has been greatly expanded in complexity (and somewhat in depth) relative to Age of Wonders 3 (which was criticized for being too "lite"). The sector-based development system deepens the gameplay and puts players into direct competition for the choicest expansion sites. The race secure Cosmite (a strategic resource, can be tight!). When coupled with an aggressive AI and lots of opposing factions on dense and intricate gamemaps, it is an intoxicating mix. The minor (aka NPC) factions add a great wrinkle to the geopolitical game, forcing judicious use of the influence resource.

Of course, it isn’t all perfect. Lost in the translation from AoW3, is the seals victory system, which was among the more brilliant design moves of the series.  Hopefully we see a version of this return to Planetfall in the future. I also miss AoW3’s blind and randomized tech tree (cough… spell book) since it prevented players from settling into predictable build paths. And I also miss the magic specializations, as they greatly expanded the possible permutations of strategies at your disposal. But these are relatively minor gripes to overall solid experience.

All in all, Triumph Studios have outdone themselves yet again and stitched together one of the finest 4X games I’ve ever played. At release, the game is solid, robust, and complete feeling. Can't wait to see where Triumph takes this in the days to come.

Personally, I would not recommend this game, here's why:

I am a huge fan of both Paradox (the Publisher), and Triumph Studios, the notable Developers of Age of Wonders 3

Age of Wonders: Planetfall makes several missteps, the character design is less than advertised, quite bland compared to expectation based on some pre-release (admittedly old) statements, and the gameplay itself is a bit...well, boring to say the least. It lacks the dynamic, exceptional elements that were core in Age of Wonders 3, it feels almost like a cheap mod of 3, not a fully developed game on its own.

This is more comparable to Civilizations: Beyond Earth, than I think anyone is comfortable with. It offers a few solid steps into the future, but for the most part, the changes aren't that substantial, and the content is less than desirable. I made the mistake of purchasing the game through a third-party site, which means that I have no recourse in searching for a refund (Humble Bundle, though I have submitted an online refund request, we'll see how that goes), but after 91 minutes, I've seen the entire tech tree, and I've gotten a fair look at the content that awaits me.

The leveling / upgrade system is less extensive than it was in AoW 3 for your Leader, and the research system is honestly kinda small. It went with a Civilization-style system, but that doesn't really fit with the game, in my opinion, whereas the prior system in AoW 3 was all about choosing what kinds of interesting new things you wanted to add, this one lacks that.

Spells were changed to 'Operations', some of which were okay, but for the most part they're kinda boring. They add the occasional new factor, but the combat lacks the 'wow' moments that even Beyond Earth had (Civilizations), and especially none of the epicness that defined AoW 3, it feels like a less ambitious product.

As stated above, cosmetic character customization sucks, the female characters in particular look like men, wish I was kidding, and beyond that there's not a lot of you can do to differentiate yourself (beyond some edgy stuff).

Onto the meat of the game, the Strategic and Tactical content, the Strategic level is pretty much just a discount mix of Civilization or Endless Legends (more the latter than the former, as 6 has WAAAAY more in-depth than that, and I panned Civ 6, beginning to think unfairly, for a 'lack' of content, comparatively it is flushed in it). There's new zones you can expand into, non-interactive, you just plop down a demand for land once your Pop grows, pretty much. Minor factions are more or less a copy of Endless Legends, again, a downgrade.

In my 91 minutes, I did not encounter any of the interesting tidbits that AoW 3 had, such as Dungeons, the uber-dangerous Underground areas, which gave the game a LoTR feel (going through the Mines of Moria, dealing with massive dragons, running for your life to save on time).

AoW 3 also had an AMAZING loot system, gearing up your various characters felt like a light Dungeon Crawler, this one doesn't really have that either. 

Tactical Combat, rounds are over in the blink of an eye, the weapons feel like they lack a presence, the tactical elements of the prior entry feel...missing, they're kinda there, but not really. There's not as much crazy stuff that you can do either, just in general, the game feels like Beyond Earth did to Civ 5, as this does to AoW 3, there ARE improvements, but they're otherwise drowned out by the mediocrity of the rest of the game.

-

Edit:

A non-comprehensive review mainly intended for AoW veterans.

Only played a couple of hours and haven’t seen much of diplomacy, campaign, late game and multiplayer yet but here’s my thoughts so far.

Map is nice and colorful but it’s a bit too much on the latter; requires time to get used to because as of now, I have to (overly) glance on the screen to see what’s in front of me, everything looks roughly the same due to the colorful & cartoonish art.

For some reason there’s no edge scrolling in this game, which is shocking honestly. It may come in a future update but it’s just idiotic why it’s not even an option.  
Edit: They've added this in the latest patch.

Compared to most other 4X’s, AoW system is ‘lightweight’ empire-building (still). This time around though, you can’t/don’t-want-to build everything, everywhere, at all times like in AoW 3. This is great news as that game had utterly braindead city development system. The sector mechanic is the system responsible for this. You actually have to make difficult decisions now and they’ll have consequences. Influence is a resource worth mentioning as it can severely impact the game in a very non-linear and unpredictable fashion - this is always welcome in the often-stale-late-game 4X’s.

Units are VERY expensive to build thus unit preservation is always your #1 priority in battles. This means spamming armies is not really a thing (of the races I’ve played so far at least), which IMO is a good thing. But it could potentially mean games drag on for long periods of time without anyone decidedly dominating. Not sure if this is true, need to play some more and see the late game.

Races are all unique (regarding units & research not so much eco & diplomacy) if somewhat having that bland, generic sci-fi feel to them. Story is somewhat good but nothing out of the ordinary in the world of sci-fi/high fantasy. 

Battles have the same pacing issue as AoW 3, takes forever to resolve when more than 3 armies are involved (especially since cover is abundant this time around and AI always use it) but maybe some of you like it this way as it does have that “epic” feel to it. Seems that every single unit have some special ability or passive effect of some sort. And thus, all units are useful in some way and most are lethal when used correctly. This makes the game more tactical and difficult but also much more complex and unpredictable. 

Speaking of which, it seems like higher tier units aren’t at all your go-to units, as they’re incredibly expensive and have different strengths & weakness compared to lower tier units (in other words, high tier units are rarely straight “upgrades” of a previous tier unit) and may have different roles altogether. This is a welcome change compared to AoW 3 where T6 spam was the only viable late army ‘strategy’. Army customization is decent. Not much depth to it but then again we didn’t have this option in AoW 3. 

AI is competent in battles. Their units take cover and focus fire and use abilities appropriately whenever possible. This is a major requirement for me to recommend this game and they passed it.

Overall, significant improvements in the unit dynamics and army composition front massively adds to the enjoyment of the already excellent tactical battles from AoW 3 and improving the city-building aspect in a meaningful way is enough for me to recommend this game even with my low in-game hours.

Having been a long term fan and closed-beta tester for Age of Wonders 3; I was sceptical of the jump from fantasy to sci-fi. But having played Planetfall, I can safely say my scepticism was unfounded. Age of Wonders gameplay and a science fiction setting form the perfect match.

54489706.review:
Only played the Tutorial so far, so take this review for what it is: early days.

That said, I'm very, very happy with what I've seen so far:

Visuals are very good; not breathtaking and surely could be better, especially texture resolution and aliasing issues in certain areas (Commander/Hero Model faces for one), but the achieved visual style is very coherent and quite beautiful, at least to my aesthetics.

Gameplay will be fairly straightforward to anyone who has ever played any Civilisation game, though with the added twist of additional XCOM-esque turn-based combat, (which outside of tutorial fights can also be resolved automatically if so desired), and HoMM-esque Hero Management and Army Upgrading.

Unlike HoMM however, there aren't just vertical upgrades via replacing one unit type with a better, more evolved unit type that was unlocked through research -- that's just one of the ways to keep your troops ready for anything.
The other way is via Mods, and those aren't the (also fully supported) mods for the game itself, but rather ingame modifications you can apply to both your Commmander & Heroes, as well as your rank & file troops.

These mods can range from simple and straightforward weapons/munitions modifications that give your unit(s) more damage per shot, all the way up to adding additional effects, like Stagger, or even completely new skills & abilities to the modded unit.
Modded units also are automatically turned into a template, thus allowing you to comfortably upgrade all units at once to the same level, and even to build new units in your colony directly with all the most recent mods pre-"installed".

Another major improvement from the most recent Civilisation entry is the fact that -- THANKFULLY -- we are not limited to moving individual units across the map, but are rather able to create and command an entire "army", as the game calls it, although a more proper term would probably be multiple platoons rather.

Either way, we can combine up to six units into an individual "army", i.e. up to six units can inhabit a single hex tile at the same time, and move in unison.
Those can either be six regular units, or five of those plus either the one Commander or one of the Heroes.

Combat furthermore is a LOT better than it is with Civilisation as here, when you lay siege to an enemy stronghold with 4 of your armies, you don't just click "Siege" and wait turn after turn -- at any given turn, as long as at least one of your besieging armies still has actions left, you can choose to attack the hostile location -- with all your combined power of all those armies you brought into position.

The same goes for the enemy as well, should they have additional armies of their own in immediate (1 tile) vicinity of the ensuing battle.

Last but not least, your management tools for your Empire to be are also a bit different from what you might be used to with Civilisation games: 

Instead of Cities growing their zone of influence (cultural borders) automatically over time, you have to send your armies (or a single unit, if appropriate) to the neighbouring sectors around your Colony (=City) once the latter is ready to annex another one of the former, which in turn depends on how many Citizens are available, and if you can actually feed them at all.

If you furthermore have enough resources for the annexation itself, simply move your unit(s) into the central sector hex and choose the respective option.
If your City currently isn't capable of supporting additional annexed sectors, you can also opt to first simply stake your claim there without actually annexing the entire sector, meaning your zone of control won't be growing to include that area, but you will get sensor and visual coverage, and the forward post will also double as an obstacle for any possible invading hostile forces that they would have to overcome first.

Oh, and there's proper Espionage, and of course regular diplomacy.

All in all, if you love Civilisation, especially the 4th and not so much the newer ones, if you love HoMM and XCOM, this should appeal on all fronts to you -- but mostly you should be able to enjoy games like Civilisation, as that is *by far* the biggest aspect of gameplay here as well.

54487002.review:
[quote][h1]Full review (including score): https://youtu.be/vhdYOUfAIA8
Written review below![/h1][/quote]
[h1]The rundown:[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Great learning curve
+ Cool province system
+ In-depth tactical combat
+ Fun & dynamic quest system
[b]Cons:[/b]
- Lackluster AI
- Disappointing diplomacy
- Unplayable late game
- Technical issues

Age of Wonders is back, this time with a sci-fi theme instead of the fantasy theme seen in each of its predecessors. As someone that hasn’t played an entry in the series since the release of AoW3, I was excited to jump back into it and see what was in store.

[i][b]NOTE:[/b] Had to trim about half of the review to fit Steam char limit, check video for full version![/i]

[i]This is a review of the singleplayer only.[/i]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list][*][b]Great learning curve.[/b] As with most 4X strategy games, one thing I dread is having to spend hours reading tutorials just to grasp the basics and get rolling. With Planetfall though, I had no such difficulty getting into things. The game provided a tutorial that barely took an hour to complete, but managed to teach me just enough to get going on the campaign immediately afterwards. Within just a few hours, I was flying through combat, managing a bunch of colonies, and maintaining faction relations with ease. It did take longer to fully understand the combat, but I feel like the devs did a good job easing the learning curve overall.

[*][b]Cool province system.[/b] Part of the reason why the game has such a great learning curve is the general lack of micromanagement when it comes to colonies. This is done through the game’s use of a province system, where the entire map is divided up into a random amount of provinces dependent on map size. These provinces can serve as the foundation for a colony, an extension for a colony, or can be made into a smaller forward base.

The forward bases require no management outside of defending them and the colonies themselves are all managed on one space. There’s no need to place buildings on every space, no need to manage each province individually, and no need to shuffle around workers every turn. Now this may be a con for some, but given the combat-heavy focus of the game, it allowed me to spend more time having fun with the combat.

[*][b]In-depth tactical combat.[/b] On the surface, Planetfall looks just like your everyday 4X strategy game. However, once you get into combat, you’ll find that it’s effectively two games in one. On one side is the 4X strategy, but on the other is the in-depth turn-based tactical combat. I like to describe it as a blend of Civilization and XCOM, with both sides being equally developed and both sides being important to winning the game.

However, these two sides are not distinct from each other, they overlap in several key areas. For example, the entire tactical side to the game relies heavily on the unit mods applied to units when outside of battle. A huge chunk of the tech tree is dedicated to these unit mods, which affect everything from damage output, to accuracy, and even add some special abilities like being able to teleport. It was quite cool how both of these sides interacted with each other and the combat was made a lot more complex as a result. It’s the classic “easy to learn, hard to master” situation.

[*][b]Fun and dynamic quest system.[/b] Although Planetfall does have your standard victory conditions, there are also a variety of quests to take advantage of along the way. If you’re playing a regular scenario outside of the campaign, these usually come from factions. The tasks range from taking down pirate hideouts, to killing a certain number of units from a designated race, to even helping with production and research projects. [i]trimmed...[/i][/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list][*][b]Lackluster AI.[/b] When you’re in the tactical battles, the AI is actually pretty good and absolutely crushed me for the first several hours that I played the game. However, when playing the 4X side to the game, the AI is anything but good. I could not go a single game without running into an AI leaving their units standing still, walking around my own defenseless units, attacking my units in a way that doesn’t benefit them, and even outright ignoring victory conditions.

To give an example, I was going for the doomsday victory condition as the syndicate, which requires me to build 3 structures in 3 separate colonies and defend them for 10 turns. So upon triggering the countdown, a bunch of factions declared war on me, as they would lose the game otherwise. However, despite having a bunch of factions surrounding me at the time, only a couple of them tried to stop me, and only with a couple unit stacks each. I wasn’t that far ahead military-wise either, so it just came across as odd that all of these factions would just let me win.

[*][b]Disappointing diplomacy mechanics.[/b] As someone that generally likes to take the diplomatic approach in 4X strategy games, I was bit a disappointed with how useless it seemed to be here. My main issue is with how allied factions act when called to war. When forming a defensive pact or alliance, one of the conditions is that both parties be available to go to war if either is attacked. That sounds great in theory, but in practice it practically never happens. That is because the game allows the option to pull out of an alliance or defensive pact whenever either party is called to war.

As a result, the AI rarely helped me when I had war declared on me. In fact, in all of my time with the game, I only ever had 2 factions come to my aid. 95% of the time they would just shrug off my calls for help and break up the alliance or defensive pact. I don’t know if I’m just unlucky, but it really made my diplomatic efforts feel like a complete waste if the AI could just dissolve it like that.

[*][b]Unplayable late game.[/b] Unfortunately, Planetfall suffers from the same problem plaguing many other 4X strategy games: that being the very slow load times during the late-game. As I play a lot of these games, I’m used to seeing load times around a minute per turn, but Planetfall easily takes the cake. Once you get up to turn 80 or so on a decently-sized map, the load times can take upwards of several minutes. In fact, on one of the game’s earlier campaign missions, I managed to get past turn 100, where the load times ended up taking around 4-5 minutes to complete every turn. And this is with the game installed on an NVME SSD and running a Ryzen 3700x, so I imagine the situation will be much worse for those with older CPUs and slower hard drives. Most of the games I played finished well before this became a problem, but it was frustrating when I did run into it.

[*][b]Numerous technical issues.[/b] Planetfall also has a bunch of other technical issues. Among these are some more minor ones, like flickering textures and the varying volume of voiced lines. However there are several major ones that I kept running into, including units getting stuck when transitioning to new turns, units getting stuck spinning in circles while in battle, and even some bugs preventing me from progressing in campaign missions. Aside from those issues, I did run into a total of three crashes, although no progress was lost due to the game’s autosave. These are probably issues that are going to be patched with time, but as it stands, they are quite annoying.[/list]

[h1]Overall:[/h1]
Planetfall is a decent strategy game overall. The combat is fun, the province system is great, and the quest system is pretty cool. However, the game is brought down by its lackluster AI, disappointing diplomacy mechanics, and numerous technical issues. It may be worth waiting for a few patches to fix up those technical issues first, but in its current state, the game is at least still fun.

The big selling point is that for a 4x game this has the best tactical combat of any out there. Might and Magic or Age of Wonders, in space, with solid turn based combat. Hero and unit customization is a fantastic touch too with many upgrades and skills to learn for each unit. 

The maps are decently sized, but I wish that focusing more on diplomacy/economy was a viable option like many other 4x games. You have to fight in this game. 

Must have for 4x strategy fans who like faster paced games. 

The biggest complaint I have is that there are some poor UI design choices, but nothing that kills the game. The game has A TON of different status effects and unit modifies. During combat it is very difficult to tell what unit is effected by what, or what abilities they have unless you open their unit panel which can be a pain for large battles. If I could hover over a unit and see a little window of the statuses on the edge of the screen or something that would be a HUGE help. Same with which units have taken their turn and which units have yet to complete their turn in tactical combat. Unit turn order is a big deal when deciding how you want to buff/move your units... small fights of 1v1 armies it's manageable but once you have 18 armies on the board you really need some sort of helpful tool to help you manage the turns otherwise you make moves out of order and end up kicking yourself. 

The best feature of the game is the auto-resolve combat. Yes yes, it is just as bad as every other 4x out there, sometimes telling you that you lost your commander or something to a pathetic enemy.... instead of making you reload the previous save if something silly happens, it lets you wipe clean the result and enter tactical combat. It is a HUGE time saver for someone like me who is almost always going in to handle combat myself in these sorts of games because I don't want to have some absurd result force me to reload. 

Very little negative to say. Lean, faster paced 4x with great combat... don't go into this thinking you are getting a grand scale campaign you can spend a month or more on for one game, this is much faster in general.

It doesn't help that the save system is past my tolerance for use - too often my saves or entire empire is trashed because it tries to use the cloud even though I've turned the setting off.  I consider this a game breaking bug/feature that makes it unplayable (for me, anyway) in the current form.

90847338.review: Very childish game, there are no sci-fi elements or any logic. All advancements are silly and illogical like some card game.
